sourceString: Rapidly increasing cumulative incidence of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in the European Union/European Economic Area and the United Kingdom, 1 January to 15 March 2020
targetString: Nawudu ro futu kuli kwasabe koronabairos (COVID-19) dǝ European Union/European Economic Area-a United Kingdom-a, lan tǝrain dǝ tǝn 1 January sǝta 15 March 2020 ro isǝna dǝ

sourceString: The cumulative incidence of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) cases is showing similar trends in European Union/European Economic Area countries and the United Kingdom confirming that, while at a different stage depending on the country, the COVID-19 pandemic is progressing rapidly in all countries.
targetString: Futu kuli kwasabe coronvirus (COVID-19) dǝ waatǝ nzǝ dǝ jili tilo fǝlejin European Union/lardǝwa European ye kasuwunzǝ sǝdin-a United Kingdom-a dǝ ye tawatsǝna kǝla, nangam wo son lǝatar lardǝ dǝ ye ro, kwasa COVID-19 ye dǝ naudu ro tǝrain lardǝwi yo son.

sourceString: Based on the experience from Italy, countries, hospitals and intensive care units should increase their preparedness for a surge of patients with COVID-19 who will require healthcare, and in particular intensive care.
targetString: Futu Italy, lardǝwa, litariwa-a naa kam zauro dondi rotǝye son turuna dǝyeyi dawari nza sasara kǝla am kwasa COVID-19 ye zamzǝna dǝ nguwujin yen sandi dǝwo ne nǝlefa ro cistuwu tanas ma ro cistuwu kam zauro dondi ye mǝradzain yen.

sourceString: On 31 December 2019, a cluster of pneumonia cases of unknown aetiology was reported in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China.
targetString: Yim 31 December 2019 lan, jami la kwasa nimoniya ye zamzǝna ma dǝwo futu gotin ma dǝ kǝlanzǝ notǝnyi ma ye hawar tuwondǝna suro bǝla Wuhan ye, sidi Hubei ye lardǝ China ye dǝ lan.

sourceString: On 9 January 2020, the China Center for Disease Control and Prevention reported the causative agent as being a novel coronavirus now referred to as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
targetString: Yim 9 January 2020 lan, cidaram kwasa kaltǝye lardǝ China ye dǝ ye hawar awo kwasa dǝga suwudin ye cina kǝla shima kwasa bǝlin dǝwo koronabairos lan buwotin ma dǝ dǝ gullono kuru sha kwasa yintǝ dabtǝgǝ ye sha koronabairos 2 (SARS-COV-2) lan notǝna dǝ wono.

sourceString: Since, the illness resulting from SARS-CoV-2 infection has been named coronavirus disease (COVID-19).
targetString: Tǝn loktu adǝn, kǝndondi dǝwo SARS-CoV-2 men wazuna wo so kwasa coronavirus yen buwotin (COVID-19).

sourceString: Evidence to date is that ca 80% of individuals with COVID-19 have a mild disease, i.e. a respiratory tract infection with or without pneumonia, and most of these recover.
targetString: Kuwo so ro awo shadatǝna dǝ shima kashi 80% am dǝwo COVID-19 kwasa kambayi la sandi lan mbeji, i.e kwasa yintǝ ye nimoniya aw ba ma, kuru nguwunza so ngazana.

sourceString: In ca 14% cases, COVID-19 develops into a more severe disease requiring hospitalisation while the remaining 6% cases experience critical illness requiring intensive care.
targetString: ca lan kashi 14% kwasa COVID-19 ye so, kwasa kǝraw ro lezǝ waljin shi dǝwo ne litarin buna mǝradǝzǝna ma kuru kashi 6% gabsǝna dǝ kwasa kǝraw ye sandiya zamjin shi dǝwo ne zauro cistuwu mǝradǝzǝna ma.

sourceString: The mortality of patients hospitalised due to COVID-19 is ca 4%.
targetString: Batǝ dǝwo am COVID-19 ye litarin bozǝgǝna dǝ ye dǝ kashi ca 4%.

sourceString: In this study, we assess the trends in the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 in each European Union/European Economic Area (EU/EEA) country and the United Kingdom (UK) and compare them to that of Hubei Province, China.
targetString: Suro nazarǝ adǝ yen, ande ye futu watǝ COVID-19ye dǝ kulasnyen suro lardǝwa European Union/lardǝwa European Union ye kasuwu sǝdin (EU/EEA) kuru United Kingdom (UK)-a yen sha Hubei lardǝ China ye dǝga ratalnye ruyen.

sourceString: We also compare the current number of COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK with that in Italy during 31 January–15 March 2020.
targetString: Ande ye kuru man nǝm nguwu am kwasa COVID-19 ye suro lardǝ EU/EEA-a UK-a kǝrma ye dǝga lardǝ Italy ye dǝga ratalnye ruyen suro yim 31 January -15 March 2020 suwudǝnan.

sourceString: COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK
targetString: Kwasa COVID-19 suro lardǝwa EU/EEA-a UK-a yen

sourceString: Subsequent to China, COVID-19 underwent further geographical spread and the dynamic of the COVID-19 pandemic in the rest of the world currently follows that of this country.
targetString: Ngawo China yen, kwasa COVID-19 ye dǝ tartǝyina kara lardǝwa dinaben kuru futu COVID-19 ye dǝ dina gabsǝna dǝn lejin dǝ futu lardǝ tudu yeyi ro lejin.

sourceString: On 11 March 2020, the Director General of the World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic.
targetString: Yim 11 March 2020 yen, Cidama kura karabka Nǝlefa ye Dinaye ma dǝ ye shi kwasa COVID-19 dǝ kwasa dina samma so ye ro wurmawono.

sourceString: In the 5 March issue of Eurosurveillance 2020, Spiteri et al. reported on the first European confirmed COVID-19 cases according to the WHO case definition.
targetString: Yim 5 March lan lamar Eurosurveilance 2020, Spiteri etal. hawar kǝn hawal me COVID-19 ye cina futu WHO ye bayanzǝna ye dǝ yeyi.

sourceString: In the EU/EEA, the first three confirmed cases were reported by France on 24 January 2020 in persons returning from Wuhan, Hubei Province, China.
targetString: Suro EU/EEA yen, am kwasa dǝ zamzǝna tawatkata sandi yakkǝ dǝ lardǝ France ye mauzǝ yim 24 January 2020 lan suro am dǝwo Wuhan, sidi Hubei ye lardǝ China yen isana so dǝ yen.

sourceString: As at 15 March 2020, COVID-19 cases had been detected in all 30 EU/EEA countries and the United Kingdom (UK), whereby between 31 December 2019 and that date included, 39,768 cases and 1,727 deaths had been reported, with 17,750 cases and 1,441 deaths from Italy alone.
targetString: Yim 15 March 2020 lan, am kwasa COVID-19 ye zamzǝna so dǝ suro lardǝwa 30 EU/EEA-a United Kingdom (UK)-a ye samma son tuwondǝna, kuruman kate kate 31 December 2020-a kuru kawu kuntawu ye shima dǝn kunten, am kwasa dǝ ye zamzǝna 39,768-a am 1,727 bazana-a hawar tina, kuru am kwasa dǝ zamzǝna 17,750-a am 1, 441 bazana suro Italy ye runzǝ man.

sourceString: Obtaining cumulative number and cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases
targetString: Futu adadu jumla am kwasa COVID-19 ye zamzǝna ye fando

sourceString: At the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), the notified COVID-19 case counts in each country worldwide, obtained from only official sources such as the countries’ Ministry of Health, national and regional health authorities and the WHO, are updated each day at 8:00 a.m.
targetString: Na dawudi kwasa ro cistuwu ye Europ ye (ECDC) dǝ, hawar am kwasa COVID-19 ye zamzǝna lardǝwi yo so ye isabtin dina samma son, fantǝram maila yen tuwondǝna men alama lardǝ dǝ ye cidaramnzǝ nǝlefa ye so yeyi, wumawa nǝlefa ro cistuwu ye lardǝ ye so, WHO, soro hawar sadin wajiya son sa 8:00 a.m.

sourceString: These data were used for assessing the trends of COVID-19 in EU/EEA and the UK, and comparing them to that in Italy.
targetString: Katabwa adǝn faidatǝ letǝ COVID-19 ye dǝ suro EU/ EEA-a UK-a ye dǝ ngaltin kuru sha Italy ye dǝga rataltǝyin.

sourceString: As a proxy of the prevalence of active COVID-19 cases, we calculated the 14-day truncated cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases, thus taking into account the natural course of COVID-19, in each EU/EEA country and the UK, during the 1 January–15 March 2020 period.
targetString: Alama tartǝ kwasa COVID-19 ye dǝ wakiltǝ yeyin, nde ye jumla am kwasa COVID-19 dǝ ye zamzǝna ye kawu-14 ye komnyiye, adǝyeyi men futu kwasa COVID-19 ye dǝ Alayi men gotin dǝ ye ro hangal gǝnayena, suro lardǝwa. EU/EEA-a UK-a wo son, yim 1 January-15 March 2020 ro isǝna yen.

sourceString: We also presented the cumulative number of notified cases of each country as at 15 March 2020 8:00 a.m. compared with that of Italy for the 31 January–15 March 2020 period.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma ande ye jumla adadu am kwasa dǝ ye zamzǝna ye nowata ma lardǝwi so hayena yim 15 March 2020 8:00 a.m sandiya Italy dǝga rataljiye 31 January-15 March 2020 ro suwudǝnan dǝga.

sourceString: Trends of COVID-19 in EU/EEA countries and the UK
targetString: Letǝram COVID-19 ye suro lardǝwa EU/EEA- UK-a dǝ ye

sourceString: The trends in the 14-day truncated cumulative incidence of COVID-19 cases in EU/EEA countries and the UK generally followed that of Hubei Province (China) (Figure 1).
targetString: Letǝram COVID-19 ye kasarrata ma kawu-14 ye ma suro EU/EEA-a UK-a ye dǝ nguwu so jili Hubei (China)ye dǝ zasaa (Sura1).

sourceString: For the EU/EEA and the UK overall, the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 started to increase around 21 February and then increased sharply around 28 February 2020 (Supplementary material).
targetString: EU/EEA-a UK-a samma son, jumla COVID-19 watǝ COVID-19ye ye dǝ yim 21 February ga tǝra badiwono kuru gana waltǝ kara 28 February 2020ye dǝn tǝrana (Hujjawa duno cin ma).

sourceString: This was mostly driven by the rapid increase in the number of reported cases from Italy, but all other EU/EEA countries and the UK showed similar increasing trends of the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 (Supplementary material).
targetString: Adǝ nguwu so adadu dǝwo am kwasa dǝ ye zamzǝna ye lardǝ Italy ye futu nagaduro tǝrain dǝ hawaratǝna lan tuwongatǝ, amma lardǝwa gade EU/EEA-a UK-a so dǝ letǝram futu COVID-19 ye tǝrain dǝ jili tilo fǝlezǝ (Hujjawa duno cin ma).

sourceString: Figure 2 shows the cumulative number of COVID-19 cases, in EU/EEA countries and the UK compared with that in Italy for the 31 January–15 March 2020 period.
targetString: Taswira 2 dǝ fǝlejin adadu jumla am COVID-19 zamzǝna suro lardǝwa EU/EEA-a UK-a ye dǝ fǝlejin, kuru futu sha Italy ye dǝga rataltǝna dǝ yim 31 January-15 March 2020 ye ma dǝ.

sourceString: It highlights that, as at 15 March 8:00 a.m., 15 other EU/EEA countries and the UK had already reported a total number of cases comparable to that of Italy just 3 weeks prior or less.
targetString: Shi dǝ fǝlezǝna kǝla, yim 15 March 8:00 a.m, lan lardǝwa gade EU/EEA-a UK-a so ye hawar buroza sadǝna kǝla jumla am kwasa dǝ ye zamzǝna ye ma dǝwo Italy ye ma dǝro ratallata ma dǝ mawu ǝ kawu dǝwo ro aw shin cidaan.

sourceString: Our results indicate that the number of notified cases of COVID-19 is rapidly increasing in the EU/EEA and the UK.
targetString: Kulashinde ye fǝlezǝna kǝla adadu am dǝwo kwasa dǝ ye zamzǝna ma nowata ma so dǝ nagaduro tǝrain suro EU/EEA-a kuru UK-a ye dǝn.

sourceString: The observed trends in the cumulative incidence of COVID-19 suggest that the pandemic is progressing at a comparable speed in all countries.
targetString: Futu letǝram suro jumla wawa COVID-19 ye dǝro hangal gǝnatǝna dǝ ye fǝlezǝna, kwasa dinaram adǝ nagaduro tǝrain jili tilo ro lardǝwa samma son.

sourceString: This is despite countries being at different stages, variations in national public health responses, and possibly different case definitions in countries and different protocols for selecting patients that must be tested for confirmation of COVID-19, including catch-up testing.
targetString: Adǝ ye lardǝwa samma hal dasana dǝ gade gade son yayi, nǝm gade nǝlefa jamaye ro cistuwu ye, kuru waneye dǝlǝu kam kwasa COVID-19 ye sǝtana ngaltǝye, kuru man dǝlǝu kam kwasa COVID-19 ye sǝtana ngaltǝye, ngaltǝ am dareye so-a kunten.

sourceString: Early March 2020, doctors in the affected regions of Italy described a situation in which ca 10% of patients with COVID-19 required intensive care and media sources reported that hospitals and intensive care units in these regions had already reached their maximum capacity.
targetString: Badiyaram kuntawu March 2020 ye, litawa naa zamtǝna suro Italy ye dǝ ye bayanzǝna kǝla ca 10% dǝwo COVID-19 ye zamzǝna so dǝ zauro cistuwu mǝradǝzǝna kuru fatowa hawar ye so gulzana kǝla litariwa so-a ba zauro am ro cistuwu ye so-a ba kek sǝmbuluwuna wada.

sourceString: Data on admission of COVID-19 cases in a hospital and/or an intensive care unit are currently available at EU/EEA level for only 6% and 1% cases, respectively (data not shown).
targetString: Katabwa kǝla am COVID-19 ye sǝtana so litarin kuru/aw naa am ro zauro cistuwu ye so ba EU /EEA-a yen tuwondin 6%-a 1%-a jong yin ndaso wo so (katab dǝ fǝletǝnyi).

sourceString: They should, however, be collected in a systematic fashion to complement current surveillance data that focus on the number of reported cases and the number of deaths.
targetString: Kuru adǝyeyi ma, sandiya kǝla fasal yen sabtǝ, bayan sabtǝ am zamtǝna ye kǝrmaro tǝdin dǝga banatǝ ro shi dǝwo ne kǝla am zamtǝna-a am bazana-a ro hangal cina ma dǝ.

sourceString: A study performed in 2010–11 showed a large variation in the availability of intensive care and intermediate care beds in Europe, ranging from 29.2 in Germany to 4.2 beds per 100,000 population in Portugal.
targetString: Nazarǝ la 2010-11 lan tǝdǝna dǝ ye zauro naa zauro am ro cistuwu dǝ-a baa am daudau ro cistuwu ye dl-a lan zauro faltǝna ro fǝlezǝna suro Europe ye dǝn, 29.2 lan tai Germanye lan diyelwa 4.2 tǝadir jama 100,000 wo son suro Portugal yen.

sourceString: This means that countries may have more or less resources than Italy (12.5 intensive care and intermediate care beds per 100,000 population in 2010–11).
targetString: Adǝbe fǝlezǝna lardǝwa do waneye Italy ga razǝwu nozain aw satinmba ( diyelwa 12.5 naa zauro am ro cistuwu ye-a naa am ro cistuwu dawu dawu ye-a tǝadir jama 100,000 suro 2010-11).

sourceString: Modelling scenarios related to healthcare capacity saturation, with estimates for each EU/EEA country and the UK of the prevalence of hospitalised COVID-19 cases associated with a > 90% risk of exceeding intensive care bed capacity, are provided in the sixth update of the ECDC rapid risk assessment on COVID-19.
targetString: Halla la nǝm kura nǝlefa ro cistuwu ye tandǝm tulo, lardǝwa EU/EEA-a UK-a so ro tǝadirrata kǝla am COVID-19 zamzǝ litarin rotǝna dǝ ye >90% so diyelwa naa zauro am ro cistuwu ye dǝga nǝm nguwun kozain yen, bayanzǝna suro kulashi duwaye kǝla tajirwa COVID-19 ye ECDC ye dǝn.

sourceString: Since cases have so far clustered in certain regions in EU/EEA countries and the UK, and hospitals and intensive care units usually serve a defined regional catchment population, information about cases and intensive care beds should preferably be made available at the Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics 2 (NUTS-2) level.
targetString: Am zamtǝna so dǝ suro lardǝwa EU/EEA-a UK-a ye dǝn nǝm nguwunza zauro na kozuna dǝga, kuru litari so-a naa zauro am ro cistuwu ye so dǝ naa kureyata musamman ro cidayin mbeji dǝga, hawar kǝla am zamtǝna so ye dǝ-a diyelwa naa zauro am cistuwuye dǝga ca mbeji ma ngǝlawo na su ndaraye so tǝkin dǝn yisawu 2 (NUTS-2) nankaro.

sourceString: The experience from Italy and the current trends in other countries show that the COVID-19 pandemic is progressing rapidly in the EU/EEA and the UK.
targetString: Futu Italy lan turuna dǝyeyi kuru futu letǝram lardǝwa gade son kǝrmaro wajin dǝ ye fǝlezǝna kǝla kwasa dinaram ye COVID-19 dǝ nagaduro tǝrain suro EU/EEA-a UK-a ye dǝn.

sourceString: Countries, hospitals and intensive care units should thus prepare themselves for a scenario of sustained community transmission of SARS-CoV-2 and an increase in the number of patients with COVID-19 requiring healthcare, and in particular intensive care, such as the one occurring in the affected regions of Italy.
targetString: Lardǝwa, litariwa-a naa zauro am ro cistuwu ye-a adǝ nankadǝro kǝlanza dawarza kǝla dawari ba kǝla klalan suro jama yen SARS-COV-2 tartǝyina yen kuru adadu am COVID-19 ye zamzǝna dǝ tǝrain yen sandi dǝwo ne nǝlefa ro cistuwu mǝradǝzǝna yen, kuru tanas maro zauro cistuwu, futu jili naa dǝwo zamtǝna Italy ye dǝ yeyi.

sourceString: As pointed out in the recent ECDC rapid risk assessment, a rapid, proactive and comprehensive approach is essential to delay the spread of SARS-COV-2, with a shift from a containment to a mitigation approach, as the anticipated rapid increase in the number of cases may not provide decision makers and hospitals enough time to comprehend, accept and adapt their response accordingly if not implemented ahead of time.
targetString: Futu suro ECDC ye kulashi nzǝ duwa duwabe kǝla tajirwa ye karǝngǝ ye dǝn fǝlezǝna dǝ yeyi, fasal la duwa duwaye, datelaye, kuru kǝzǝbkǝ ma dǝ zauro faida SARS-COV-2 dǝ tartǝgǝ nzǝ dǝga wahartǝge ro, cistuwu lan citǝ fasal kaltǝgǝye ro gǝrta ro, futu adadu am zamtǝna ye duwa duwa ro tǝrain ro tǝmatǝna dǝ ye waneye muwonzǝ shawari kamtǝma so-a litari so-a ro loktu kǝzǝbkǝ cǝ lamar dǝga ngǝlaro asuzainmba, samoyinmba, kuru nanza so dǝga kalkalzayinmba date lan cidatǝ baditǝnyi ma.

sourceString: The rapid risk assessment also lists the public health measures to mitigate the impact of the pandemic.
targetString: Kulashi duwa duwa ye kǝla tajirwa ye dǝ kuru man katabwa nǝlefa jamaye dǝye isabsǝ suwudin kaziyi kwasa dinaram ye dǝga kambaitǝgǝ ro.

sourceString: There is a short window of opportunity during which countries have the possibility to further increase their control efforts to slow down the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and decrease the pressure on healthcare.
targetString: Dǝlǝu la loktu gana ye mbeji loktu shima dǝn lardǝwa so muwonzǝ kasadǝnza SARS-COV-2 tǝ tartǝ nzǝ dǝ waharzayin kuru kǝrau kǝla nǝlefa ro cistuwu ye dǝga fuluzain.

sourceString: Failing this, it is likely that the healthcare systems of other EU/EEA countries will face a surge of patients that require intensive care within the coming days or weeks.
targetString: Adǝ dewo ro teriya, tǝmatà fasalla nǝlefa ro cistuwu ye lardǝwa EU/EEA-a ye dǝ am dondi dǝwo zauro cistuwu mǝradǝzǝna kada rurutayin ro suro kaw gana aw mawwa ishin dǝ yen.

sourceString: The outbreak of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has thus far killed over 3,000 people and infected over 80,000 in China and elsewhere in the world, resulting in catastrophe for humans.
targetString: Fǝlangtǝ kwasa coronavirus (COVID-19) ye dǝ, shi dǝwo ne kwasa yintǝ dabtǝgǝ ye dǝwo (SARS) Koronabairos 2 (SARS-COV-2) ye suwudǝnan dǝ, ba burozǝ kǝrmaro am 3000 kǝn samin yeyi cezǝna kuru am 80,000 zamzǝna suro lardǝ China ye-a naa gade suro dina yen-a son, sǝkǝ tajirwa kura adam gana ro suwudǝnan.

sourceString: Similar to its homologous virus, SARS-CoV, which caused SARS in thousands of people in 2003, SARS-CoV-2 might also be transmitted from the bats and causes similar symptoms through a similar mechanism.
targetString: Futu kuli kwasabe shiga samǝn ma dǝ yeyi, SARS-COV, shi dǝwo ne am duwu kada ro SARS suwudǝnan dǝ suro saa 2003, shi SARS-COV-2 dǝ ye waneye batata men gotin kuru alamawa kǝndondibe jili tilowa ma fǝlejin fasal jili tilowa men.

sourceString: However, COVID-19 has lower severity and mortality than SARS but is much more transmissive and affects more elderly individuals than youth and more men than women.
targetString: Son yayi, COVID-19 dǝ nǝm zau-a tajirwa-a lan SARS ye dǝyeyi sǝtǝnyi amma shi dǝ zauro tartǝyina kuru shi dǝ am ngǝlinza lezǝna ma zauro sǝtain wo zairowa yayiro kuru kongawa ma nguwu ro sǝtain wo kamuwa yayiro.

sourceString: In response to the rapidly increasing number of publications on the emerging disease, this article attempts to provide a timely and comprehensive review of the swiftly developing research subject.
targetString: Futu nagaduro kitawwa kǝla futu kwasa dǝ falangjin dǝ yen lǝbtǝ tǝrain dǝ yen, ruwo adǝ ye bayanna suro loktu yen duwa duwa ro cin kǝla mauduwa kulashi ilmu yen.

sourceString: We will cover the basics about the epidemiology, etiology, virology, diagnosis, treatment, prognosis, and prevention of the disease.
targetString: Ande ye suro dǝn awowa buro hawal yin notiya sandǝna so kǝrenyen kǝla nazaru ilmuye kǝla futu kwasa tartǝyin-a kaltǝyin-a ye-a, nazaru ilmuye kǝla futu garram aw fǝrtǝ kwasabe-a, nazaru ilmuye kǝla kuli kwasabe, kulashi kǝla alamawa kǝndondiben, kurun diwo, shawari liyitaye kǝnjo, kwasa dǝn yitkawo-a

sourceString: Although many questions still require answers, we hope that this review helps in the understanding and eradication of the threatening disease.
targetString: Korowa kada jawaw mǝradǝzana son yayi, tǝmanyena bayan adǝ ye banazǝ kwasawa tajirwa dǝga asutin kuru kǝriwu tin.

sourceString: The Spring Festival on January 25, 2020 has become an unprecedented and unforgettable memory to all Chinese who were urged to stay indoors for all the holiday and for many weeks after due to the outbreak of a novel viral disease.
targetString: Kawuske bikaye January 25 2020 be dǝ, awo dǝwo tǝmatǝnyi kuru awo dǝwo ngaltema njastinmba ye ro walzǝna am lardǝ China ye samma so ro dǝwo sandiya sakǝ faton zakta namzana so loktu batalla shima dǝyen kuru mawwa kada ro ngawo shima dǝyen sawo falangtǝ kwasa la kǝla notǝnyi yen.

sourceString: The virus is highly homologous to the coronavirus (CoV) that caused an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003; thus, it was named SARS-CoV-2 by the World Health Organization (WHO) on February 11, 2020, and the associated disease was named CoV Disease-19 (COVID-19).
targetString: Kuli kwasabe dǝ zaumaro coronavirus (CoV) dǝwo kwasa yintǝ ye (SARS) 2003; dǝ suwudǝnan dǝga samǝn adǝ sǝkǝ, karabka Nǝlefa ye Dinaye (WHO) sha SARS-COV-2 lan buwono yim February 11, 2020, kuru kwasa dǝwo shi men tuwondin dǝ kwasa-19 CoV yen buwotǝ (COVID-19).

sourceString: The epidemic started in Wuhan, China, and quickly spread throughout the entire country and to near 50 others all over the world.
targetString: Kwasa dinan fomjin adǝ bǝla Wuhan, China, kuru duwa duwa ro lardǝ samma so ro tarratǝgǝ kuru lardǝwa 50 yeyi ro kǝla dina yen tarratǝgǝ.

sourceString: As of March 2, 2020, the virus has resulted in over 80,000 confirmed cases of COVID-19, with more than 40,000 patients discharged and over 3,000 patients who died.
targetString: Yim March 2, 2020, kuli kwasabe dǝ am 80,000 samin yeyi COVID-19 zamzǝna ro tawatkata, kuru am 40,000 samin yeyi salamtǝna kuru am 3000 samin yeyi bazana.

sourceString: WHO warns that COVID-19 is “public enemy number 1” and potentially more powerful than terrorism.
targetString: WHO be sumo gǝrzǝna kǝla COVID-19 dǝ shima watǝma jamabe kǝn falmi 1" yo wono kuru man muwonzǝ gǝradewa ma dunon kojin.

sourceString: According to PubMed (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/), in less than two months, over 200 papers have been published on COVID-19 including its virology, epidemiology, etiology, diagnosis, and treatment since the first report on January 7, 2020 that determined the sequence of the virus isolated from multiple patients.
targetString: Futu PubMed (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/) tuwondǝna ye dǝyeyi, suro kǝntawu indin cidaan yin, kakkadiwa 200 samin kǝla COVID-19 yen lǝbtǝna, suro dǝn nazaru ilmuye kǝla kuli kwasaben, nazaru ilmuye kǝla futu kwasa tartǝyin-a kaltǝyin-a ye-a, nazaru ilmuye kǝla futu garram aw fǝrtǝ kwasabe, kulashi kǝla alamawa kǝndondibe ye-a kurun diwo-a, tǝn loktu hawal hawar tuwondǝna dǝn yim January 7, 2020 lan shi dǝwo ne kuli kwasabe dǝga am gade dondi so gayerzǝna.

sourceString: This review attempts to summarize the research progress in the new and swiftly developing subject area.
targetString: Nazaru adǝ kulashi ilmu ye dǝga kasarjin nasha mauduwu dǝwo maudu ro wajin ma yen.

sourceString: Whenever possible, we will try to compare COVID-19 with SARS and another CoV-caused disease, Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS, an outbreak in 2012).
targetString: Sai yayi muwongono wa, ande ye COVID-19 dǝga SARS-a kuru kwasawa la-CoV ye suwudin so-a, kwasa yintǝ ye Middle East ye (MERS, an outbreak in 2012) dǝro ratallǝyen.

sourceString: We will also discuss what we have learned so far regarding the prevention and prognosis of the disease as well as some remaining yet urgent questions.
targetString: Ande ye kuru man gashibtǝyen kǝla awowa dǝwo ngawon liyena yen kǝla yitkawo-a awo kwasa dǝga suwudin-a kuru adǝyeyi ma korowa la gabsǝna gade dǝwo zauro faida so-a.

sourceString: CoVs have been traditionally considered nonlethal pathogens to humans, mainly causing approximately 15% of common colds 4.
targetString: CoVs dǝ ada lan kwasa dǝwo kam so cejinmba ro nowata, alama tǝadir 15% tantayi nowata 4 suwudin.

sourceString: However, in this century, we have encountered highly pathogenic human CoVs twice, i.e., SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, which caused an outbreak originally in China in 2003 and Saudi Arabia in 2012, respectively, and soon spread to many other countries with horrible morbidity and mortality.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, suro karno adǝ yen, kwasa CoVs ye zauro tartǝyina ma indi kalkal ro andeya zamzǝna, i.e., SARS-CoVs, shi dǝwo ne sǝkǝ falangzǝna dǝ buro hawal yin China 2003 lan kuru Saudi Arabia lan 2012 lan, tussǝnyi kuru man lardǝwa kada ro tarratǝgǝ tartǝgǝ riyata-a tajirwa-a lan.

sourceString: Therefore, the current COVID-19 is the third CoV outbreak in the recorded history of humans.
targetString: Adǝ nankadǝro, COVID-19 kǝrmaye adǝ shima falangtǝ CoV ye kǝn yakkǝ me ye wo suro tarihi adam gana ye nowata lan.

sourceString: As shown in Fig. ​Fig.1,1, clusters of pneumonia that had unknown origins were first reported from Wuhan on December 31, 2019 to the China National Health Commission.
targetString: Futu Fig. Fig.1,1 fǝltǝna dǝ yeyi, kwasa nimoniya ye kǝla notǝnyi ma buro hawal yin Wuhan lan falangzǝna yim December 31, 2019 China ye cidaramnzǝ nǝlefa ro cistuwu ye dǝro hawarratǝgǝna.

sourceString: Seven days later the sequence of the CoV was released.
targetString: Ngawo kawu tulur yen falangtǝ CoV ye tutǝlo.

sourceString: On January 15, 2020 the first fatal case from Wuhan was reported.
targetString: Yim January 15, 2020 hawar buro hawal ye Wuhan lan tuwondǝna.

sourceString: Meanwhile, the epidemic rapidly spread to the neighboring cities, provinces, and countries.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, kwasa dǝ tiinyi ro bǝlawa mashi so, bǝrniwa so, lardǝwa so ro tarratǝgǝ.

sourceString: On January 20, the infection of health-care providers was reported, suggesting that human-to-human transmission was possible.
targetString: Yim January 20, liyitawa zamtǝna ye hawar tina, fǝlezǝna kǝla kam-kam ro fǝltǝgǝ dǝ muwonjin ro.

sourceString: On January 23, the city of Wuhan was locked down with all its public transportation stopped.
targetString: Yim January 23, bǝrni Wuhan ye dǝ kǝrǝb zakkatǝgǝ awonza kǝmbaye samma dawono.

sourceString: On January 24 the first clinical study on the disease reported that, out of 41 patients with confirmed cases, only 21 had direct contact with the Wuhan seafood market that was considered the starting site of the infection from an unknown animal source.
targetString: Yim January 24 nazaru liyita ye buro hawal ye kǝla kwasa dǝ yen hawar sadǝna kǝla suro am dǝwo 41 kwasa dǝ zamzǝna ro tawatkata dǝn, am 21 njong kasuwu dabba ye Wuhan ye dǝro fatta shi dǝwo ne nadǝman kwasa shima dǝ badiwono ro gotǝna dǝ dabba la notǝnyi lan ro tǝmatǝna.

sourceString: On January 30, WHO declared the outbreak a global health emergency.
targetString: Yim January 30, WHO ye kwasa fǝlangtǝ dǝ kaziyi nǝlefa ye dinaye duwasashi ye sǝ mauwono.

sourceString: By the time of this report, the disease has already spread throughout China and near 50 other countries all over the world (Fig. ​(Fig.2).2).
targetString: Loktu rifot adǝ tin dǝn, kwasa dǝ ba China sammaso ro tartǝgǝna kuru lardǝwa 50 samin dinaye sammaso ro (Fig.(Fig.2).2).

sourceString: As the situation is rapidly evolving, the final scope and severity of the outbreak remain to be determined.
targetString: Hal adǝ nagaduro tǝrain lan, nangam darelaye-a nǝmkǝraunzǝ dǝga dǝ kwamison notǝnyi.

sourceString: On February 11, 2020, a multi-center study on 8,866 patients including 4,021 confirmed COVID-19 patients presented a more updated illustration of the epidemic as follows (https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/UlBi-HX_rHPXa1qHA2bhdA).
targetString: Yim February 11, 2020, nazaru la fella kada kǝllataye kǝla am dondi 8,866 yen suro dǝn 4,021 dǝn am tawatkata COVID-19 ye zamzǝna ma so dǝye bayan kǝzǝbkǝ kǝla kwasa dǝ yen cina futu adǝyeyi ro (https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/UlBi-HX_rHPXa1qHA2bhdA).

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 infected people of all ages, but mainly at the age of 30-65.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 dǝ am ngǝliwi ye so zamzǝna, amma nguwu so 30-65.

sourceString: Almost half (47.7%) of the infected individuals were over 50 years old, very few were under 20, and only 14 infected individuals were under the age of 10.
targetString: Alama reta yeyi (47.7%) am zamtǝna dǝ ye yeyi saanza 50 kozǝna wo, saa 20 cidaan dǝ zauro gana, kuru am zamtǝna 14 saa 10 cidaan wo.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 infected more men (0.31/100,000) than women (0.27/100,000).
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 dǝ kongaa ma nguwo ro zamzǝna wo (0.31/100,000) kǝla kamuwaye ro (0.27/100,000).

sourceString: COVID-19 expanded in clusters mainly in and around Hubei.
targetString: COVID-19 dǝ Kashi Kashi men suro Hubei-a dǝrinǝm kǝllenzǝga dǝn tarratǝgǝ.

sourceString: COVID-19 took an average of 5 (2-9) days from onset to diagnosis.
targetString: COVID-19 dǝ alama kawu 5 (2-9) ye dǝyeyi gozǝ baditǝnzǝn tai kulashi liyita ye kude dǝn.

sourceString: The average incubation period was 4.8 (3.0-7.2) days.
targetString: Loktu nzǝ kalzǝ tambin dawu-dawu ye dǝ kawu 4.8 (3.0-7.2).

sourceString: The average time from onset to death was 9.5 (4.8-13) days.
targetString: Loktu nzǝ dawu-dawu ye baditǝnzǝn sǝta nonzǝ ro isǝna dǝ kawu 9.5 (4.8-13).

sourceString: The basic reproductive number (R0) was 3.77 (95% CI: 3.51-4.05), and the adjusted R0 was 2.23-4.82.
targetString: Adadunzǝ tambin (R0) dǝ shima 3.77 (95% Cl: 3.51-4.05), kuru R0 tatana dǝ shima 2.23-4.82.

sourceString: The number of infected people increased exponentially before 23 Jan. 2020, matching the time of massive transportation before the Spring Festival in China.
targetString: Adadu am dǝwo zamtǝna dǝ ye taidaze tǝrana kawu 23 Jan. ye ro. 2020, loktu dǝwo kawuske aw kǝmbaye suro China ye dǝga kalkal zǝna.

sourceString: The mortality of patients with confirmed cases was 1.44% (95% CI: 1.10-1.86%), and the adjusted mortality of all the patients was 3.06% (95% CI: 2.02-4.59%).
targetString: Kǝrmu am dǝwo kwasa dǝ zamzǝna ro tawatkata dǝ ye dǝ 1.44% (95% Cl:1.10-1.86%), kuru kǝrmu dǝwo am dondi samma so ye tatana ma dǝ 3.06% (95% Cl:2.02-4.59%).

sourceString: Three major risk factors for COVID-19 were sex (male), age (≥60), and severe pneumonia.
targetString: COVID-19 ye awowanzǝ tajirwa ro asutaye Kura kura yakkǝ dǝ shima jinsu (konga), ngǝli (≥60), kuru nimoniya kǝraw-a.

sourceString: CoVs are a subfamily of large and enveloped viruses containing a single strand of sense RNA.
targetString: CoVs so dǝ yalla kulliwa kwasabe kura kura ye suronzan je RNA ye fal dǝgana ma.

sourceString: They can be divided into four genera, i.e., alpha, beta, gamma, and delta, of which alpha- and beta-CoVs are known to infect humans.
targetString: Muwonzǝ sandiya kashi samǝnga diyew ro yaktin, i.e., alpha, beta, gamma, delta, suro dǝn CoVs alpha-a beta-a sandima am so ga zamjin ro nowata wo.

sourceString: The envelope spike (S) glycoprotein binds to its cellular receptors angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) and dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) for SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, respectively, and then membrane fusion occurs.
targetString: Ngǝrǝwu spike (S) glycoprotein ye dǝ awo dǝwo cellular receptors angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) dǝ ro kǝrtǝna kuru dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) SARS-CoV ye-a kuru MERS-CoV so ro, kǝlatilowa ro, daji kuru membrane fusion wajin.

sourceString: The viral RNA genome is released into the cytoplasm; after replication of the viral genome, genomic RNA accompanied by envelope glycoproteins and nucleocapsid proteins forms virion-containing vesicles, which then fuse with the plasma membrane to release the virus.
targetString: Kuli kwasabe RNA genome dǝ suro cytoplasm ye fitǝyin; ngawo kuli kwasabe genome kawaktǝ nguwuzǝna yen, genomic RNA dǝ ngǝrǝwu glycoproteins ye sortǝna yen, kuru nucleocapsid proteins sǝtandin virion-suro dǝn vesicles la ma, daji kuru plasma membrane dǝ ro kǝrtǝyin kuli kwasabe dǝ fituwu ro.

sourceString: The first genomic sequence of SARS-CoV-2 was reported on January 10, 2020.
targetString: Wawtǝ SARS-CoV-2 buro hawal ye dǝ yim January 10, 2020 lan fangatǝ.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 was found to be a new type of beta-CoV with more than 99.98% genetic identity among 10 sequenced samples collected from the original site of the outbreak, the Huanan Seafood Market in Wuhan.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 dǝ shima jili beta-CoV bǝlin wo ro asutǝna samǝnram 99.98% ga suro awowa kulashi ro ba buro hawal yin falangzǝna dǝn gotǝna dǝ yen, kasuwu kǝmbu suro nji ye ma Wuhan ye dǝn.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 is genetically more similar to SARS-CoV than to MERS-CoV.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 dǝ alau men shima SARS-CoV ga samǝn wo MERS-CoV yayi ro.

sourceString: Through transmission electron microscopy, SARS-CoV-2 particles were found in ultrathin sections of human airway epithelium.
targetString: Zawal transmission electron microscopy ye men, bǝrbǝr SARS-CoV-2 ye turuna suro zawal yintǝ ye adamngana ye dǝwo sha ultrathin sections of human airway epithelium lan buwotin dǝn.

sourceString: Human ACE2 was found to be a receptor for SARS-CoV-2 as well as SARS-CoV.
targetString: ACE2 adamngana ye dǝ shima SARS-CoV-2 dǝ-a SARS-CoV dǝ-a muwoma wo ro asutuna.

sourceString: However, the S protein of SARS-CoV-2 binds to human ACE2 more weakly than that of SARS-CoV, which is coincident with the fact that SARS-CoV-2 causes less severe infection in patients than SARS-CoV.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, S protein SARS-CoV-2 ye dǝ ACE2 adamngana ye dǝ ro lawu ro kǝrrata kǝla SARS-CoV ye yayiro, adǝ ye SARS-CoV-2 dǝ kamma zamztǝ nzǝ dǝ SARS-CoV yeyi sǝtǝnyi dǝ ye dalil.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 can also form a novel short protein encoded by orf3b and a secreted protein encoded by orf8.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 ye kuru man raksǝ da gana la bǝlin ma sǝdin suro orf3b kuru da fiyata suro orf8 yen gǝrata.

sourceString: The orf3b of SARS-CoV-2 may play a role in the viral pathogenicity and inhibit the expression of IFNβ; however, orf8 does not contain any known functional domain or motif.
targetString: orf3b SARS-CoV-2 ye dǝ kuli kwasabe dǝ ye wuratǝ nzǝ dǝ ro takal suwudin kuru IFNβ bayantǝnzǝ dabcin; adǝyeyi ma, orf8 dǝ suro nzǝn abima faida nowata ba.

sourceString: On February 18, 2020, Zhou, et al., reported the cryo-EM structure of the full-length human ACE2 at 2.9 Å resolution in complex with the amino acid transporter B0AT1.
targetString: Yim February 18, 2020, Zhou, et al., ye bayanzǝna kǝla cryo-EM siffanzǝ full-length human ACE2 kǝla nur 2.9 Å yen amino acid transporter B0AT1 ratallata.

sourceString: They found that the complex, which had open and closed conformations, was assembled as a dimer and the ACE2-B0AT1 complex can bind two S proteins, which provides evidence for CoV recognition and infection.
targetString: Sandi ye asuzana kǝla complex dǝ, shi katǝram-a zaktǝrm-a ma dǝ, sha dimer yeyi ro kǝllatǝ kuru ACE2-B0AT1 complex dǝ raksǝ S proteins ndi kǝljin, adǝ dalil CoV asuta-a zamtǝnzǝ-a ye fǝlejin.

sourceString: B0AT1 may become a therapeutic target for drug screening to suppress SARS-CoV-2 infection.
targetString: B0AT1 dǝ waneye shima kurun kwasa CoV-2 ratkǝm fulutǝ ye ro waljin.

sourceString: The origin and intermediate host
targetString: Fǝrtǝ dǝ-a gǝnatǝna nzǝ dawu dawu ye-a

sourceString: It has been known that both SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV originated from bats and were transmitted to humans via civet cats and camels, respectively.
targetString: Notǝna ye dǝ yeyi SARS-CoV dǝ-a MERS-Cov dǝ-a so fǝrtǝnza batata men ciwono kuru am so ro ngam-a kalimo-a men tarratǝgǝ.

sourceString: Through a phylogenetic comparison of SARS-CoV-2 with other CoVs, bats were considered the native host of SARS-CoV-2 as the new virus is 96% identical to two SARS-like CoVs from bats called bat-SL-CoVZX45 and bat-SL-CoVZX21.
targetString: Fasal nzudu rataltǝye dǝwo phylogenetic comparison of SARS-CoV-2 dǝ men rokko CoVs gade so dǝ-a, batata so dǝ sandima ngawar SARS-CoV-2 ye wo ro gotǝna dalil dǝ kuli kwasabe bǝlin dǝ 96% ro SARS-like CoVs dǝga samǝn wo batata la sha bat-SL-CoVZX45 dǝ-a kuru bat-SL-CoVZX21 dǝ-a lan buwotin dǝ lan.

sourceString: However, what intermediate host helped the virus cross the species barrier to infect humans remains unknown, and the transmission route is yet to be elucidated.
targetString: Ade yeyi ma, gǝnatǝna dawu dawu yé ndaso kuli kwasabe dǝga banaze awo kam so tartǝgǝ dǝga fanjin ma dǝga farzǝ kozǝ ma ro notǝnyi, zawal zǝga tartǝgǝna dǝ ye kwamison asutǝnyi.

sourceString: Ji, et al., proposed snakes as a carrier of the virus from bats to humans which involved homologous recombination within the S protein.
targetString: Ji, et al., ye kurunzǝ dǝn kadi shima kuli kwasabe dǝga batata lan gozǝ kam so ro tarjiwo shi dǝwo ne S protein na jili tilo ro kǝltana.

sourceString: According to a study, researchers in Guangzhou, China, suggested that pangolins - long-snouted, ant-eating mammals often used in traditional Chinese medicine - are the potential intermediate host of SARS-CoV-2 based on 99% genetic homology in a CoV discovered in pangolins and SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Nazaru ilmuye lan, kulashiwu so Guangzhou, China lan, dabba la pangolins - kuruwu-sungullata, cidacida-kǝmbuma nguwu so ro sha kurun kǝska ye China yen faidatain ma- sandima gǝnatǝna SARS-CoV-2 dawu dawu ye ro waljin wada futu 99% ro CoV dǝwo pangolins-a SARS-CoV-2 lan tuwondǝna dǝga samǝn dǝ.

sourceString: However, 1% difference spread all over two genomes is still a big difference; thus, conclusive results for concrete evidence are awaited (Fig. ​(Fig.33).
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, tartǝgǝ 1% dǝwo tǝraiya yayi zauro ma ro kura, adǝ ye sǝkǝ, dalila kǝzǝbkǝ dunowa dǝ gǝretin (Fig. Fig.33).

sourceString: The physicochemical properties of SARS-CoV-2 are largely not yet known.
targetString: Futu SARS-CoV-2 dǝ fafaltin so dǝ nguwu so kwamison notǝnyi.

sourceString: SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV can survive in vitro for 48 hours in a dry environment and up to 5 days under 20 °C and 40%-50% humidity.
targetString: SARS-CoV dǝ-a MERS-CoV dǝ-a raksa suro kalwa yen awa 48 ro kǝnǝngatain ma ngamdu lan kuru kawu 5 ro kawdo 20 °C cidaan lan na kulongunzǝ 40%-50%.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 may possess similar properties.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 dǝ waneye siffa jili tilo wa ro waljin.

sourceString: It has been reported that SARS-CoV-2 is sensitive to ultraviolet rays and heat at 56 °C for 30 minutes; ether, 75% ethanol, chlorine-containing disinfectant, peracetic acid, chloroform, and other fatty solvents, but not chlorhexidine, can effectively inactivate the virus.
targetString: Rifot tina kǝla SARS-CoV-2 shi dǝ nur shiro ultraviolet sayin dǝga wazǝna kuru kawudo 50 °C minti 30 ro ; ndin fal, 75% ethanol, chlorine-kurun kuli yazo ye-a kǝllatǝ ma, peracetic acid, chloroform, kuru awowa sha fatty solvents lan buwotin dǝ-a, amma chlorhexidine gǝnyi ma, raksǝ ngǝlaro kuli kwasabe dǝga cejin.

sourceString: The entire human population generally lacks immunity to SARS-CoV-2 and hence is susceptible to the novel virus.
targetString: Adamngana so samma so tiyinza dǝ raksǝ SARS-CoV-2 dǝga kǝriwjinmba adǝ nankaro tiinyi kuli kwasabe bǝlin dǝ ye sha sǝtain.

sourceString: Currently, no detailed study has been reported regarding the immunological response to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Kǝrma dǝro, Rifot nazaru la kǝzǝbkǝ ye kǝla futu tiyi kamma ye SARS-CoV-2 dǝga kǝriwjin ye ba.

sourceString: Thus, we can only refer to previous studies on other CoVs, especially SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV (Fig. ​(Fig.4).4).
targetString: Adǝ nankadǝro, nazaruwa ngawon kǝla CoVs gade yen tǝdǝna ma so dǝ ruyen, musamman ma ro SARS-CoV dǝ-a MERS-CoV dǝ-a (Fig. (Fig.4).4).

sourceString: In general, after a virus invades the host, it is first recognized by the host innate immune system through pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) including C-type lectin-like receptors, Toll-like receptor (TLR), NOD-like receptor (NLR), and RIG-I-like receptor (RLR).
targetString: Nguwu so ro, ngawo kuli kwasabe dǝ tiyi kamma zamjiya, buro salak lan kam dǝye tiyinzǝn alaunzǝ kwasa kǝriwtǝye dǝ asujin zawal asutǝramnzǝ dǝwo sha (PRRs) lan buwotin dǝ men, C-type lectin-like receptors Toll-like receptor (TLR), NOD-like receptor (NLR), kuru RIG-I-like receptor (RLR).

sourceString: Through different pathways, the virus induces the expression of inflammatory factors, maturation of dendritic cells, and synthesis of type I interferons (IFNs) which limit the spreading of the virus and accelerate macrophage phagocytosis of viral antigens.
targetString: Diwalla kada men, kuli kwasabe sǝkǝ futǝ suwudin, wuratǝ dendritic cells, kuru synthesis type I ye-a interferons (IFNs) shi dǝwo ne kuli kwasabe tartǝgǝ dǝga fulujin kuru sǝrayin macrophage phagocytosis of viral antigens dǝga.

sourceString: However, the N protein of SARS-CoV can help the virus escape from the immune responses.
targetString: Ade yeyi ma, N protein SARS-CoV ye dǝ raksǝ kuli kwasabe dǝga banaze balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝye tiyi ye dǝn soshin.

sourceString: Soon, the adaptive immune response joins the fight against the virus.
targetString: Karǝngǝn, balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝye tiyi dǝ ye kuli kwasabe kǝriwtǝ dǝ ro kǝltǝyin.

sourceString: T lymphocytes including CD4+ and CD8+ T cells play an important role in the defense.
targetString: T lymphocytes rokkozǝn CD4+ kuru CD8+ T cells dǝ taidaza faitǝ dǝn banazain.

sourceString: CD4+ T cells stimulate B cells to produce virus-specific antibodies, and CD8+ T cells directly kill virus-infected cells.
targetString: CD4+ T cells dǝ B cells dǝga kulleccin balimiwa kwasa kǝriwtǝye dǝ tulo ro, kuru CD8+ T cells dǝ kuli kwasabe dǝga kǝla tilowa ro cejin.

sourceString: T helper cells produce proinflammatory cytokines to help the defending cells.
targetString: T helper cells dǝ proinflammatory cytokines sutuluyin cells faijin ma dǝga banatǝ ro.

sourceString: However, CoV can inhibit T cell functions by inducing apoptosis of T cells.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, CoV dǝ raksǝ cida T cell ye dǝro takkal suwudin shi apoptosis T cells dǝga gǝrǝbtǝgǝ men.

sourceString: The humoral immunity including complements such as C3a and C5a and antibodies is also essential in combating the viral infection.
targetString: Balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝye tiyi humoral dǝ banama alama C3a dǝ-a kuru C5a dǝ- a kuru balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝye tiyi so-a so zauro faida kuli kwasabe kǝriwtǝ dǝ ro.

sourceString: For example, antibodies isolated from a recovered patient neutralized MERS-CoV.
targetString: Misallo, balimiwa kwasa kǝriwtǝye tiyi dǝwo tiyi kam ngazǝna yen tutuluwuna dǝ MERS-CoV dǝga cezǝna.

sourceString: On the other hand, an overreaction of the immune system generates a large number of free radicals locally that can cause severe damages to the lungs and other organs, and, in the worst scenario, multi-organ failure and even death.
targetString: Hal gadǝn, fasal balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝye tiyi ye dǝ ye naa kuzǝna ro cidajiya awo la shiro free radicals gultin dega surayin nguwu ro sutuluyin shi dǝwo ne lezǝ fufu-a kǝndǝwu gade so-a, kuru sa bannatiya kǝndǝwu kada cidazainmba ro waljin kuru kǝrmu yayi ro surutsǝyin.

sourceString: The SARS-CoV-2 infection, featured by clustering onset, is more likely to affect elderly people with comorbidities and pregnant women.
targetString: Zamztǝ SARS-CoV-2 ye dǝ, futu badiyaram lan sabtin fǝlezǝna dǝ yeyi, am ngǝlinza lezǝna ma tiynzan kwasa gadeya -a kamuwa surowa-a ma ma nguwo ro sǝtain wo.

sourceString: It is common that for people who are exposed to a large number of viruses or whose immune functions are compromised, they have higher chance to be infected than others.
targetString: Nowata ye dǝ yeyi, am dǝwo kuli kwasabe nguwu ye zamzǝna so dǝ aw am dǝwo balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝye tiyinza ye so nuna dǝ, sandima nguwu so ro zamtin wo am gade dǝ yayi ro.

sourceString: The estimated mean incubation period of SARS-CoV-2 is 1-14 days, mostly 3-7 days based on a study of the first 425 cases in Wuhan.
targetString: Loktu dǝwo ngazata SARS-CoV-2 ye bǝbǝntǝgǝ tambin dǝ shima kawu 1-14, nguwu so ro kawu 3-7 futu nazaru kǝla am 425 buro hawal yin zamtǝna bǝla Wuhan ye dǝ ye fǝlezǝna dǝ yeyi.

sourceString: However, a study on 1,099 cases demonstrates that the incubation period was 3 days on average and ranged from 0 to 24 days.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, nazaru kǝla am 1,099 zamtǝna dǝ yen fǝlezǝna kǝla loktu bǝbǝntǝgǝ tambin dǝ shima nguwu so ro kawu 3 kuru kate kate kawu 0 sǝta 24 lezǝna yen.

sourceString: A more recent study, as described above, demonstrates that the incubation period was 4.8 (3.0-7.2) days based on the demography of 8,866 cases.
targetString: Nazaru la karǝngǝ dǝ ye dǝ ye, fǝlezǝna kǝla loktu bǝbǝntǝgǝ tambin dǝ shima kawu 4.8 (3.0-7.2) lǝatar nǝm nguwu jama 8,866 zamtǝna yen.

sourceString: It is very important for health authorities to adjust the effective quarantine time based on the most accurate incubation period, thus preventing infected but symptomless people from transmitting the virus to others.
targetString: Humawa nelefa ro cistuwu ma so dǝ loktu kǝla kortǝ ye sandǝna ma dǝga kalkaltǝgǝ dǝ zaumaro faida, lǝatar loktu bǝbǝntǝgǝ tambin dǝwo zauro kalkal ma ye ro, adǝyeyi men, am dǝwo zamtǝna amma alamawa kǝndondibe fǝlezainmba ma so dega am gade ro kuli kwasabe dǝ tartǝgǝ ro dabtin.

sourceString: As a common practice, individuals exposed to, or infected by, the virus are usually required to be quarantined for 14 days.
targetString: Futu tǝdin nowata ye dǝ yeyi, am dǝwo kuli kwasabe dǝro hatana, aw zamtǝna ma so sandiya kawu 14 ro kortin.

sourceString: Should the quarantine time be extended to 24 days?
targetString: Loktu kortǝ ye dǝ tǝra kawu 24 ro waljin wa?

sourceString: Fever is often the major and initial symptom of COVID-19, which can be accompanied by no symptom or other symptoms such as dry cough, shortness of breath, muscle ache, dizziness, headache, sore throat, rhinorrhea, chest pain, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.
targetString: Kange dǝ shima alama kwasa COVID-19 kura kuru buroye wo, ngawo dǝn dayi alama gade ba aw alamawa gade misallo kadawu ngamdu, yintǝ kǝraw, tiyi sǝrǝn, kǝla dǝri, kǝla sǝrǝn, daw lilimta, klanza saktǝ, karuwu sǝrǝn, shi dada, karuwu lalam, kuru fitǝ-a.

sourceString: Some patients experienced dyspnea and/or hypoxemia one week after the onset of the disease.
targetString: Am dondi la dǝ ye yintǝ kǝraw-a/ aw kwasa bu lan kasam gantǝ ye shiro hypoxemia sayin dǝ mawu fal ngawo kwasa badizana yen fanzana.

sourceString: In severe cases, patients quickly progressed to develop acute respiratory syndrome, septic shock, metabolic acidosis, and coagulopathy.
targetString: Sa zau jiya, am dondi so dǝ nagaduro koza kwasa yintǝ kǝraw ye zau ma, kǝrawu kwasadǝ be nankaro kamma hangallin sutulin (septics shock), metabolic acidosis, coagulopathy-a tatain.

sourceString: Patients with fever and/or respiratory symptoms and acute fever, even without pulmonary imaging abnormalities, should be screened for the virus for early diagnosis.
targetString: Kam dondi dǝwo kange-a kuru/aw alamawa kwasa yintǝ ye kuru kange kǝrawwa, awo dǝwo ne shiro pulmonary imaging abnormalities gultin ba yayi kuli dǝro daten kulastǝ.

sourceString: A demographic study in late December of 2019 showed that the percentages of the symptoms were 98% for fever, 76% for dry cough, 55% for dyspnea, and 3% for diarrhea; 8% of the patients required ventilation support.
targetString: Nazaru la jama ye daren December 2019 ye dǝn tǝdǝna dǝ ye fǝlezǝna adadu alamawa kǝndondibe dǝ kashi miya lan Sandi ma 98% kange ye, 76% nzasǝra ngamdu ye, 55% dyspnea ye, kuru 3% shidada ye; 8% am dondi dǝ ye so bana yintǝram ye mǝradǝzana.

sourceString: Similar findings were reported in two recent studies of a family cluster and a cluster caused by transmission from an asymptomatic individual.
targetString: Hawar jili tilowa ma nazaru la ndi karǝngǝn kǝla yalla zamtǝna-a yalla dǝwo alamawa kǝndondibe fǝlezainmba yen tǝdǝna ye fǝlezǝna.

sourceString: Comparably, a demographic study in 2012 showed that MERS-CoV patients also had fever (98%), dry cough (47%), and dyspnea (55%) as their main symptoms.
targetString: Rataltǝgǝ men, nazaru la kǝla jama yen suro 2012 yen tǝdǝna dǝ ye fǝlezǝna kǝla am MERS-CoV ye sǝtana dǝ ye kangeya (98%), nzasǝra ngamdu (47%), kuru yintǝ kǝraw (55%) shima alamawa kǝndondibe nza wo.

sourceString: However, 80% of them required ventilation support, much more than COVID-19 patients and consistent with the higher lethality of MERS than of COVID-19.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, kashi 80% wo so bana yintǝram ye mǝradǝzana, COVID-19 ye sǝtana dǝga kozǝna ro kuru MERS ye loru dǝ COVID-19 ye dǝga kuzǝna.

sourceString: Diarrhea (26%) and sore throat (21%) were also observed with MERS patients.
targetString: Shidada (26%) kuru dawu lilimta (21%) ye am MERS ye sǝtana dǝn turuna.

sourceString: In SARS patients, it has been demonstrated that fever (99%-100%), dry cough (29%-75%), dyspnea (40%-42%), diarrhea (20-25%), and sore throat (13-25%) were the major symptoms and ventilation support was required for approximately 14%-20% of the patients.
targetString: Am SARS ye zamzǝna dǝn, (99%-100%) fǝlezǝna, nzasǝra ngamdu (29%-75%), yintǝ kǝraw (40%-42%), shidada (20-25%), kuru dawu lilimta (13-25%) sandima alamawa kǝndondibe kura wo kuru bana yintǝram ye mǝradǝtǝna tǝadir 14%-20% am dondi dǝ ye.

sourceString: By February 14, the mortality of COVID-19 was 2% when the confirmed cases reached 66,576 globally.
targetString: February 14 lan, loru COVID-19 ye dǝ 2% sa adadu am zamtǝna dǝ ye dǝ 66,576 dina samma son nazǝgǝ na dǝn.

sourceString: Comparably, the mortality of SARS by November 2002 was 10% of 8,096 confirmed cases.
targetString: Rataltǝgǝ men, loru SARS ye dǝ November 2002 la dǝn 10% of am tawadǝro zamtǝna 8,096 ye dǝn.

sourceString: For MERS, based on a demographic study in June 2012, the mortality was 37% of 2,494 confirmed cases.
targetString: MERS ye dǝ, lǝatar nazaru la jama ye June 2012 yen tǝdǝna dǝn, loru dǝ 37% am 2,494 tawadǝro zamtǝna yen.

sourceString: An earlier study reported that the R0 of SARS-CoV-2 was as high as 6.47 with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 5.71-7.23, whereas the R0 of SARS-CoV only ranged from 2 to 4.
targetString: Nazaru la ngawon tǝdǝna dǝ ye fǝlezǝna kǝla R0 SARS-CoV-2 ye dǝ nǝm nguwu nzǝ dǝ 6.47 sǝtǝna 95% confidence interval (CI) ga 5.71-7.23 ye, adǝyeyi ma R0 SARS-CoV ye dǝ kate kate 2 sǝta 4 isǝna njong yen kara.

sourceString: A comparison of SARS-CoV-2 with MERS-CoV and SARA-CoV regarding their symptoms, mortality, and R0 is presented in Table ​Table1.1.
targetString: Rataltǝgǝ la SARS-CoV-2 dǝga MERS-CoV kuru SARA-CoV yen tǝdǝna dǝn kǝla alamawa kǝndondibe nzan, loru, kuru R0 ye-a dǝ fǝlǝtǝna suro Tewur 1.1.

sourceString: The above figures suggest that SARS-CoV-2 has a higher ability to spread than MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV, but it is less lethal than the latter two.
targetString: Adaduwa samiye dǝ ye fǝlezǝna kǝla SARS-CoV-2 dǝ shima raksǝ tartǝgǝyin wo kǝla MERS-CoV dǝ-a SARS-CoV dǝga yen, amma shi sandi ndi dareye dǝga tajirwan sǝtǝnyi.

sourceString: Thus, it is much more challenging to control the epidemic of SARS-CoV-2 than those of MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV.
targetString: Adǝ nankadǝro, kwasa SARS-CoV-2 ye dǝ shima kaltǝgǝ zauwwa wo kǝla MERS-CoV -a SARS-CoV dǝ-a yen.

sourceString: Clustered onset often happens in the same family or from the same gathering or vehicle such as a cruise ship.
targetString: Badiyaram lan kǝltǝ dǝ nguwu so ro yalla fal yin aw samno fal yin aw awo kǝmbayen alama mara njiye so yeyi lan.

sourceString: Patients often have a history of travel or residence in Wuhan or other affected areas or contact with infected individuals or patients in the recent two weeks before the onset.
targetString: Kam dondi dǝwo can bǝlarozǝna aw Wuhan lan nabsǝna aw naa gade kwasa dǝ fǝlangzǝna lan aw kam kwasa dǝ ye zamzǝna ro letǝgǝna suro mawuwa indi karǝngǝ yen.

sourceString: However, it has been reported that people can carry the virus without symptoms longer than two weeks and cured patients discharged from hospitals can carry the virus again, which sends out an alarm to increase the time for quarantine.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, hawar tuwondǝna kǝla am so raksa kuli kwasabe dǝga alama kǝndondibe ba ro gozain mawu ndiya kozǝna ro kuru kam ngazǝ sha litarin salamtǝna yayi raksǝ waltǝ kuli kwasabe dǝga gojin, adǝ ye dayi je ya nzǝndin kǝla loktu kortǝ ye yira yen.

sourceString: Patients have normal or reduced number of peripheral white blood cells (especially lymphocytes) at the early stage.
targetString: Am dondi dǝwo adadu bunza bella kimiyaso (musamman ro lymphocytes) ye dǝ kalkal ma aw fulutuna ma so dǝ badiyaram dǝn.

sourceString: For example, lymphopenia with white blood cell count < 4×109/L including lymphocyte count < 1×109/L, and elevated aspartate aminotransferase levels and viremia were found in 1,099 COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Misallo, lymphopenia suro zǝn white blood cell count < 4×109/L rokkozǝn lymphocyte count < 1×109/L, kuru elevated aspartate aminotransferase levels and viremia dǝ tuwondǝna suro am 1,099 COVID-19 ye zamzǝna yen.

sourceString: The levels of liver and muscle enzymes and myoglobin were increased in the blood of some patients, and C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation were increased in the blood of most patients.
targetString: Nǝm nguwu liver-a muscle enzymes-a kuru myoglobin -a ye dǝ suro bu am dondi la so yen tǝrana, kuru C-reactive protein-a erythrocyte sedimentation-a dǝ suro bu am dondi nguwu so yen tǝrana.

sourceString: In patients with severe cases, the level of D-dimer, a fibrin degradation product present in the blood, was elevated, and lymphocyte count was progressively reduced.
targetString: Am zauro dondi so lan, nǝm nguwu D-dimer ye, awo la suro bu ye dǝn fibrin nyetǝma, habtǝna, kuru nǝm nguwu lymphocyte ye gana ganan fulutǝn.

sourceString: Abnormalities in chest radiography are found in most COVID-19 patients and featured by bilateral patchy shadows or ground glass opacity in the lungs.
targetString: Foto karuwuye am COVID-19 ye zamzǝna dǝn gotǝna dǝn awowa la kalkalgǝnyi turuna kuru tiyidǝn suli ndi ndiya aw awo dǝwo ne shiro ground glass opacity sayin ma suro fufu dǝyen na.

sourceString: Patients often develop an atypical pneumonia, acute lung injury, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
targetString: Am dondi dǝ nguwu so kwasa pneumonia kǝla notǝnyiya, tuno fufuye zau ma, kuru kwasa yintǝ ye acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) sayin dǝga.

sourceString: When ARDS happens, uncontrolled inflammation, fluid accumulation, and progressive fibrosis severely compromise the gas exchange.
targetString: Sa ARDS wajiya, futǝ kaltǝyinmb, nji sabtǝ, kuru awo dǝwo ne sha progressive fibrosis lan buwotin dǝ ye zauro yintǝ ro takal suwudin.

sourceString: Dysfunction of type-I and type-II pneumocytes decreases the surfactant level and increases surface tension, thus reducing the ability of the lungs to expand and heightening the risk of lung collapse.
targetString: Bannatǝ type-I-a type-II pneumocytes-a ye dǝ nǝm tǝlala dǝ fulujin kuru nǝm kǝrsasa sǝrayin, adǝ nankadǝro fufu raksǝ fijin ba ro waljin kuru fufu dǝ cetro Bannatǝ waajin.

sourceString: Therefore, the worst chest radiographic findings often parallel the most severe extent of the disease.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, kulashi foto karuwu ye zau ma dǝ nguwu so ro kwasa dǝ ye zaunzǝ dǝga kalkal.

sourceString: On February 18, 2020, the first pathological analysis of COVID-19 demonstrated the desquamation of pneumocytes, hyaline membrane formation, and interstitial lymphocyte infiltration, and multinucleated syncytial cells in the lungs of a patient who died of the disease, consistent with the pathology of viral infection and ARDS and similar to that of SARS and MERS patients.
targetString: Yim February 18, 2020 ln, kulashi kǝla COVID-19 yen buro hawal ye ma dǝ fǝlezǝna shiltǝ pneumocytes ye, hyaline membrane formation, kuru interstitial lymphocyte infiltration, kuru multinucleated syncytial cells suro fufu dǝwo kam kwasa dǝ ye cezǝna yen, pathology zamtǝ kuli kwasabe dǝga kuru ARDS-a kuru jili am SARS-a MERS-a zamzǝna ye dǝga samǝn.

sourceString: The detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA via reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was used as the major criteria for the diagnosis of COVID-19.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 RNA dǝga asuta zawal reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) ne dǝn shima kaida kura wo ro faidatǝ kulashi COVID-19 ye tǝdo.

sourceString: However, due to the high false-negative rate, which may accelerate the epidemic, clinical manifestations started to be used for diagnosis (which no longer solely relied on RT-PCR) in China on February 13, 2020.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, (false-negative rate), nguwu dǝ ye sǝkǝ, shi dǝwo ne raksǝ kwasa dǝga sǝrayin, shaidawa litari ye kulashi dǝn faidatǝ baditǝna (shi dǝwo ne kǝrma dǝ RT-PCR runzǝ lang ro kǝrtǝyinmba) China lan yim February 13, 2020.

sourceString: A similar situation also occurred with the diagnosis of SARS.
targetString: Hal jili adǝyeyi wazǝna kulashi SARS yen.

sourceString: Therefore, a combination of disease history, clinical manifestations, laboratory tests, and radiological findings is essential and imperative for making an effective diagnosis.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, tarihi kwasa ye, dalilla liyitariye, kulashi jim kulashi ye, dalilla fotoye-a, zauro faida na kulashi ngǝlama duwo yen.

sourceString: On February 14, 2020, the Feng Zhang group described a protocol of using the CRISPR-based SHERLOCK technique to detect SARS-CoV-2, which detects synthetic SARS-CoV-2 RNA fragments at 20 × 10-18 mol/L to 200 × 10-18 mol/L (10-100 copies per microliter of input) using a dipstick in less than an hour without requiring elaborate instrumentation.
targetString: Yim February 14, 2020, Feng Zhang group ye bayan fasal la ye nzundu CRISPR-based SHERLOCK lan faidatǝ SARS-CoV-2 asuta ro, shi dǝwo ne synthetic SARS-CoV-2 RNA fragments at 20 × 10-18 mol/L to 200 × 10-18 mol/L (10-100 copies per microliter input) ye son dipstick lan faidatǝ awa fal yin cidaan awo kuratǝgǝ ye mǝradǝzǝnyi ro.

sourceString: Hopefully, the new technique can dramatically enhance the sensitivity and convenience if verified in clinical samples.
targetString: Tǝmata, nzundu bǝlin dǝ raksǝ futu ajabba ro cidanzǝ dǝga ngalaunzǝyin sa litari men tawattǝgǝ ya.

sourceString: Due to the lack of experience with the novel CoV, physicians can mainly provide supportive care to COVID-19 patients, while attempting a variety of therapies that have been used or proposed before for the treatment of other CoVs such as SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV and other viral diseases (Table ​(Table2).2).
targetString: Sawo CoV dǝga notǝna yen, liyitawa so bana cistǝgǝ ye bas am dǝwo COVID-19 ye zamzǝna dǝro sadin, sa kurunwa wa gade so jarabsain dǝn sandi dǝwo ne faidatǝna ma aw shawari tina ma kawu dǝro CoVs dǝ kuruntǝ ro aw SARS-CoV-a and MERS-CoV-a kuru kwasawa kuli kulimi gade so-a (Table (Table2).2).

sourceString: These therapies include current and potential treatments with antiviral drugs, immunosuppressants, steroids, plasma from recovered patients, Chinese medicine, and psychological support.
targetString: Kurunwa adǝ Kurunwa kǝrmaro tǝdin-a fuwun tǝdǝn-a Kurunwa kuli kwasabe dǝ yen, immunosuppressants, steroids, plasma na kam ngazǝna yen, Kurunwa China ye, kuru hangal kǝdistǝgǝ-a.

sourceString: Even plasma from recovered patients was proposed to be used for treatment.
targetString: Plasma kam ngazǝna ye ma kurun ro faidatin ro shawari tina.

sourceString: Pharmaceutical companies are racing to develop antibodies and vaccines against the virus.
targetString: Kamfoniwa kurun tandoye so dǝ gaska sadin katenzan kǝla kurun-a kalimi-a kuli kwasabe dǝ ro matǝgǝ ro.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 mainly attacks the lungs in the beginning and probably also attacks, to a lesser degree, other organs that express ACE2, such as the gastrointestinal system and the kidneys.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 dǝ nguwu so ro fufu dǝ buron sǝtain daji kuru man waneyi kambayi ro kǝnduwuwa gade ACE2 sǝtain, alama zawal kalǝm ye -a kǝmadkǝn-a yeyi.

sourceString: Nevertheless, respiratory dysfunction and failure are the major threat to the patients and the major cause of death.
targetString: Son yayi, yintǝram Bannatǝ dǝ shima awo kura dǝwo kam dondi dǝro tajirwa kǝrmu-a suwudin wo.

sourceString: Thus, respiratory support is critical to relieve the symptoms and save lives and includes general oxygen therapy, high-flow oxygen, noninvasive ventilation, and invasive mechanical ventilation depending on the severity of the disease.
targetString: Adǝ nankaro, bana yintǝram dǝ ro zauro faida alamawa kǝndondibe dǝ kambaitǝgǝ ro kuru ro wa yitka ro kuru suro dǝn general oxygen therapy, high-flow oxygen, noninvasive ventilation, kuru invasive mechanical ventilation lǝatar kǝraw kwasa dǝ yen.

sourceString: Patients with severe respiratory symptoms have to be supported by extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), a modified cardiopulmonary bypass technique used for the treatment of life-threatening cardiac or respiratory failure.
targetString: Am dondi dǝwo alamawa kǝndondi yintǝye zauwwa ma so dǝ sandiya extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) lan banatin, shima nzundu ǝdwo bǝlintǝgǝna ma cardiopulmonary bypass shi lan kurun kam zauro kǝraw ro kwasa yintǝ ye zamzǝna tǝdin.

sourceString: In addition, the maintenance of electrolyte balance, the prevention and treatment of secondary infection and septic shock, and the protection of the functions of the vital organs are also essential for SARS-CoV-2 patients.
targetString: Ngawo adǝ yen, awo dǝwo ne shiro electrolyte balance dǝ fando ro, zamtǝ kǝn ndi me ye ro yitkawu-a ngatǝgǝ-a kura kwasa septic shock y-a, kuru cidawa kǝndǝwu kura kura so ye dǝga yitkaa dǝ am SARS-CoV-2 ye sǝtana dǝro zauro faida.

sourceString: It has been known that a cytokine storm results from an overreaction of the immune system in SARS and MERS patients.
targetString: Asutǝna kǝla shi cytokine storm dǝ balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝye am SAR MERS-a zamzǝna tiyi ye dǝ wazǝna.

sourceString: Cytokine storm is a form of systemic inflammatory response featured by the release of a series of cytokines including TNFα, IL-1β, IL-2, IL-6, IFNα, IFNβ, IFNγ, and MCP-1.
targetString: Cytokine storm dǝ shima futa la dǝwo cytokines suro dǝn TNFα, IL-1β, IL-2, IL-6, IFNα, IFNβ, IFNγ, and MCP-1 tulo wa kǝllata.

sourceString: These cytokines induce immune cells to release a vast number of free radicals which are the major cause of ARDS and multiple organ failure.
targetString: Cytokines dǝ balimi tiyi ye dǝga sǝkǝ awo dǝwo ne shiro free radicals gultin dega nguwu ro sutuluyin kuru sandima ARDS kǝndǝwu Bannatǝ dǝga suwudin.

sourceString: Immunosuppression is essential in the treatment of cytokine storms, especially in severe patients.
targetString: Immunosuppression dǝ zauro faida na cytokine storms kuruntǝgǝ ye dǝn, musamman ma ro am kǝraw ro zamzǝna dǝ.

sourceString: Corticosteroids and tocilizumab, an anti-IL6 monoclonal antibody, have been used to treat cytokine storm.
targetString: Corticosteroids dǝga tocilizumab, an anti-IL6 monoclonal antibody dǝga, faidatǝna cytokine storm ngatuwu ro.

sourceString: Other immunosuppression treatments for cytokine storm include the modulation of T cell-directed immune response; the blockade of IFN-γ, IL-1, and TNF; JAK inhibition; blinatumomab; suppressor of cytokine signaling 4; and HDAC inhibitors.
targetString: Duno kamma fulutǝ dǝ shima cytokine storm ngatǝyin dǝ shima modulation of T cell-directed immune response; the blockade of IFN-γ, IL-1, and TNF; JAK inhibition; blinatumomab; suppressor cytokine ye-a signaling 4; and HDAC inhibitors.

sourceString: Steroids, as immunosuppressants, were widely used in the treatment of SARS to reduce the severity of inflammatory damage.
targetString: Steroids, immunosuppressants yeyi ro, nguwu ro faidatǝna SARS kuruntǝ ro nǝm zaw futa ye dǝ fulutǝ ro.

sourceString: However, steroids at high dosages were not beneficial to severe lung injury in SARS and COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, steroids nguwu ro gotǝ dǝ tuno fufuye kǝraw dǝro faidajin ba kam SARS -a COVID-19 ye sǝtana dǝro.

sourceString: Instead, they may cause severe side effects, especially avascular osteonecrosis, dramatically affecting the prognosis.
targetString: Susu dǝro, waneye illa kura saudin, musamman ma avascular osteonecrosis, prognosis dǝga lejin ma.

sourceString: Nevertheless, short courses of corticosteroids at low-to-moderate doses have been recommended to be used prudently for critically ill COVID-19 patients.
targetString: Son yayi, corticosteroids gana gana kǝnjodǝ mǝradǝ-ata kam COVID-19 ye zamzǝna dǝro yo tǝrana.

sourceString: At the time of writing, no effective antiviral therapy has been confirmed.
targetString: Sa ruwo adǝ tǝdin dǝn, kwamison kurun kuli kwasabe la kǝzǝkkǝ ma tǝwandinyi.

sourceString: However, intravenous administration with remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, has been found to be efficacious in an American patient with COVID-19.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, remdesivir zarro ikkodǝ, a nucleotide analog, dǝ kam America ye COVID-19 ye zamzǝna dǝro faidazǝna.

sourceString: Remdesivir is a novel antiviral drug developed by Gilead initially for the treatment of diseases caused by Ebola and Marlburg viruses.
targetString: Remdesivir dǝ kurun bǝlin kuli kwasabe ye Gilead ye sǝtandǝna buro hawal yin kwasa Ebola ye-a kuli kwasabe Marlburg-a kuruntǝ ro.

sourceString: Later, remdesivir also demonstrated possible inhibition of other single stranded RNA viruses including MERS and SARS viruses.
targetString: Dare lan, remdesivir waltǝ kuli kwasabe gade RNA -a MERS-a SARS-a ro faidajin ro fǝletǝ.

sourceString: Based on these, Gilead has provided the compound to China to conduct a pair of trials on SARS-CoV-2-infected individuals, and the results are highly anticipated.
targetString: Dalil a adǝro, Gilead ye China ro fahm dǝga chaino kǝla am SARS-CoV-2- ye zamzǝna dǝn jarabtǝ ro, kuru jawaw dǝ ku so ro gǝretin.

sourceString: In addition, baricitinb, interferon-α, lopinavir/ritonavir, and ribavirin have been suggested as potential therapies for patients with acute respiratory symptoms.
targetString: Ngawo adǝyen, baricitinb, interferon-α, lopinavir/ritonavir, and ribavirin dǝ shawari tina kǝla kwasa yintǝ ye kǝraw ma dǝ ye kurun ro.

sourceString: Diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, liver damage, and other adverse reactions can occur following combined therapy with lopinavir/ritonavir.
targetString: Shidada, karuwu lalam, fita, kǝntǝnu bannatǝ, kǝndondi la gade so wajin ngawo lopinavir/ritonavir faidatǝna yen.

sourceString: The interaction of these treatments with other drugs used in the patients should be monitored carefully.
targetString: Kurunwa adǝga kurun gade-a kǝltǝ kam dondi ro tina dǝro ngǝla ro hangal gǝnatǝ.

sourceString: Plasma from recovered patients and antibody generation
targetString: Plasma tiyi kam dondiyen gotǝna-a balimi tiyi ye-a

sourceString: The collection of the blood from patients who recovered from a contagious disease to treat other patients suffering from the same disease or to protect healthy individuals from catching the disease has a long history.
targetString: Tiyi kam la kwasa tartǝgǝyin ma ye sǝta ngazǝna yen bu gonǝm am gade jili kwasa shima dǝga ro kurun diwo aw am nǝlefa kwasa dǝn faitǝ ro dǝ zauro tussǝna.

sourceString: Indeed, recovered patients often have a relatively high level of antibodies against the pathogen in their blood.
targetString: Tawadǝro, am dǝwo ngazana so dǝ bunzan balimi kwasa dǝ kǝriwtǝ ye dǝ nguwu mbeji.

sourceString: Antibodies are an immunoglobulin (Ig) produced by B lymphocytes to fight pathogens and other foreign objects and they recognize unique molecules in the pathogens and neutralize them directly.
targetString: Duno tiyiye kwasa kǝriwuji so dǝ sandima immunoglobulin (Ig)ye sandiya sǝwudin kwasawa-a awowa gade kusotoa kǝriwtǝ ro kuru sandi dǝ awo musamman ye tiyi kwasa dǝ yen asuzaiyya dai tiinyi sha chemin.

sourceString: Based on this, plasma was collected from the blood of a group of patients who recovered from COVID-19 and was injected into 10 seriously ill patients.
targetString: Dalil adǝ nankaro, plasma gowotǝ suro bu am COVID-19 lan ngazana yen kuru tiyi am zauro dondi 10 ye ro tǝko.

sourceString: Their symptoms improved within 24 hours, accompanied by reduced inflammation and viral loads and improved oxygen saturation in the blood.
targetString: Alamawa nza kǝndondibe dǝ suro awa 24 ye lan ngǝlawono, ngawo dǝn futa ye fuluwotǝ kuru kuli kwasabe dǝ ye fuluwotǝ kuru kasam gǝrtǝ ye ngǝlawono.

sourceString: However, verification and clarification are necessary to propose the method for large-scale use before specific therapies are not yet developed.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, tawattǝgǝ-a bayan-a dǝ zauro faida nzundu dǝn kǝla am nguwu yen faidatǝ ro shawari yo dǝ kawu kurun la musamman ye tǝnandin dǝro.

sourceString: In addition, given the therapeutic effects, some disadvantages associated with the plasma should be considered carefully.
targetString: Ngawo adǝyen, kurun dǝro wutǝya, illawa la plasma dǝro kǝllatǝ dǝro hangal gǝnatǝ.

sourceString: For example, antibodies can overstimulate the immune response and cause cytokine release syndrome, which is potentially a life-threatening toxicity.
targetString: Misallo, balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝbe tiyibe dǝwo antibodies gultin dǝ raksǝ duno tiyibe dǝga naa kozǝna ro gǝrǝbsǝyin kuru sǝkǝ cytokine release syndrome dǝ wajin, shi dǝwo ne anasku ro tajirwa ma.

sourceString: The concentration of antibodies in the blood is usually low, and the demand for the plasma is large to treat critically ill patients.
targetString: Balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝbe tiyibe dǝ suro bu dǝ ben nguwu so ro zauro gana, kuru mǝradǝ plasma ye dǝ nguwu Kam zauro dondi ngatǝgǝ ro.

sourceString: It is difficult to develop and produce specific antibodies rapidly enough to fight against a global epidemic.
targetString: Balimiwa kwasa kǝriwtǝybe tiyibe nagaduro tandǝm tuluwum kwasa dinalabe kǝriwtǝ dǝ zau.

sourceString: Thus, it is more critical and practical to isolate B cells from recovered patients and identify the genetic codes encoding effective antibodies or screen for effective antibodies against essential proteins of the virus.
targetString: Adǝ nankaro, B cells dǝ tiyi kam ngazǝna yen tulo dǝ shima ngalau kuru and identify the genetic codes encoding nzǝ dǝ effective antibonuyin aw sasǝrtin balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝbe tiyibe ngalaw kuli kwasabe dǝga kǝriwtǝ ro.

sourceString: This way, we can readily scale up the production of the antibodies.
targetString: Zawal adǝ men, rangye balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝbe tiyibe dǝga nguwu ro tanden.

sourceString: TCM has been used to treat a variety of diseases in China for thousands of years.
targetString: TCM dǝ faidatǝ shilan kwasa jili kada ngatǝgǝna lardǝ China ye lan saa duwu kada ro.

sourceString: However, its effects largely rely on a combination of multiple components in a formula that varies depending on the diagnosis of a disease based on the theories of TCM.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, faida nzǝ dǝ awowa kada kǝltǝ men kara shi dǝwo ne fafaltin ma lǝatar kulashi kwasa dǝ yen futu kaidawa TCM ye suwudǝnan ro

sourceString: Most of the effective components remain unknown or are vague as it is difficult to extract and verify such components or their optimal combinations.
targetString: Awowa faida nguwu so notǝnyi aw asuta zaiwa sawo shi dǝ nzunnǝm tuluwum tawatta ro aw tuskanonzǝ haiyyabe dǝ notǝ ro zau.

sourceString: Currently, due to the lack of effective and specific therapy for COVID-19, TCM has become one of the major alternative treatments for patients with light to moderate symptoms or for those who have recovered from severe stages.
targetString: Kǝrmaro, dalil kurun tǝanas ye COVID-19 ba dǝga, TCM dǝ shima am dondi dǝwo kwasanza kambayi aw dawu dawu ma so dǝro kurunjin wo aw am dǝwo zauro dondizan ngazana so ro.

sourceString: For example, Shu Feng Jie Du capsules and Lian Hua Qing Wen capsules were found to be effective for COVID-19 treatment.
targetString: Misallo, Shu Feng Jie Du capsules dǝ-a Lian Hua Qing Wen capsules dǝ-a dǝ COVID-19 dǝga ngazǝnyin ro asutuna.

sourceString: Top cure rates in the treatment of COVID-19 patients were observed in several provinces in China that used TCM in 87% of their patients, including Gansu (63.7%), Ningxia (50%), and Hunan (50%), whereas Hubei province, which used TCM in only approximately 30% of its COVID-19 patients, had the lowest cure rate (13%).
targetString: Adadu nguwu am COVID-19 lan ngazana ye bǝlawa kada Chinabe lan turuna sandi dǝwo TCM lan faidatan kǝla 87% amnza dondi dǝ ye lan ma dǝ, dawudǝn Gansu (63.7%), Ningxia (50%), kuru Hunan (50%), amma bǝla Hubei ye dǝ, shi dǝwo ne TCM alama kashi 30% njong kǝla amnzǝ COVID-19 ye zamzǝna dǝn faidatǝna dǝ, adadu am ngazana ye zauro gana tuwondǝ (13%).

sourceString: However, this is quite a rough comparison as many other impact factors such as the number and severity of the patients should be included in the evaluation.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, adǝ ma adǝ Rataltǝgǝ sami samiye dalil dǝ awo fǝlejin ma kada alama adadu-a nǝm zau kam dondibe-a so dǝ kǝltǝnyi dǝro.

sourceString: On February 18, 2020, Boli Zhang and coworkers published a study to compare western medicine (WM) treatment alone with combined treatment of WM and TCM.
targetString: Yim February 18, 2020 lan, Boli Zhang-a Cidawu-a ye nazaru la lǝbsa satoluwuna kǝla kurun nasarabe (WM) tilonzǝ-a kurun WM-a TCM-a tuskata yen.

sourceString: They found that the times needed for body temperature recovery, symptom disappearance, and hospitalization were remarkably shorter in the WM+TCM group than in the WM only group.
targetString: Sandi ye asuwada kǝla loktu dǝwo mǝradǝtǝna kǝla kawudo tiyibe fandoye, alamawa kǝndondibe ba ro waltǝ, kuru litarin buna-a ye dǝ gana WM+TCM dǝ lan kǝla WM runzǝ ye dǝ lan.

sourceString: Most impressively, the rate for symptomatic worsening (from light to severe) was remarkably lower for the WM+TCM group than for the WM only group (7.4% versus 46.2%) and the mortality was lower in the WM+TCM group than WM only group (8.8% versus 39%).
targetString: Awo kangurnobe dano, adadu nǝm kǝrawu alama kǝndondibe dǝ (kambayi lan cizǝ kǝraw ro waltǝ) dǝ zaumaro gana kashi WM+TCM ye dǝn kǝla WM runzǝ ye dǝ lan (7.4% versus 46.2%) kuru kǝrmu dǝ gana kashi WM+TCM ye dǝn kǝla MW runzǝ ye dǝn (8.8% versus 39%).

sourceString: Nevertheless, the efficacy and safety of TCM still await more well-controlled trials at larger scales and in more centers.
targetString: Son yayi, nǝm kǝzǝbkǝ-a nǝm nǝlefa-a TCM ye dǝ kwamison rizabtǝ dǝwo zauro hangal gǝnata ma-a nguwu ro kuru dawudiwa kada lan diwo mǝradǝzǝna.

sourceString: It would also be intriguing to characterize the mechanism of actions and clarify the effective components of TCM treatments or their combinations if possible.
targetString: Kurun TCM ye dega siffatǝ-a nzundu kǝndobe-a kuru nashanzǝ faida dǝga bayantǝ dǝ zauro tamtamma ro waljin.

sourceString: Patients with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 mostly experience great fear of the highly contagious and even fatal disease, and quarantined people also experience boredom, loneliness, and anger.
targetString: Am dondi dǝwo COVID-19 ye zamzǝna ro tǝmatǝna so dǝ nguwu nza so karuwukam kwasa zauro tartǝgǝyin ma kuru tajirwa dǝye fǝlezain, kuru dǝwo kortǝna so dǝ ye kǝlan kowo, nǝm tilo, kuru gǝratǝ-a fǝlezain.

sourceString: Furthermore, symptoms of the infection such as fever, hypoxia, and cough as well as adverse effects of the treatments such as insomnia caused by corticosteroids can lead to more anxiety and mental distress.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, alamawa kwasa dǝ be alama kange yeyi, tiyi lan kasam gana dǝwo sha hypoxia lan buwotin dǝyeyi, kuru nzasǝra yeyi, adǝyeyi ma awowa kurun dǝ ye suwudin so alama kǝnǝm ba yayi so shi dǝwo ne jili kurun corticosteroids ma dǝ ye suwudin so dǝ lezǝ karuwun kǝngai-a hangal bǝna ba -a ro sǝkin.

sourceString: In the early phase of the SARS outbreak, a range of psychiatric morbidities including persistent depression, anxiety, panic attacks, psychomotor excitement, psychotic symptoms, delirium, and even suicidality were reported.
targetString: Sa badiyaram kwasa SARSbe dǝ fǝlangzǝna dǝn, kwasawa hangal wa lezǝna kada tuwondǝna, surodǝn karwuza kamtinmba so, karwunkǝngai so, karuwukam so, aw dǝwo ne shiro psychomotor excitement gultin iso, psychotic symptoms so, delirium so, kuru hatta kǝla yezo yeyi so tuwondǝna.

sourceString: Mandatory contact tracing and quarantine, as a part of the public health responses to the COVID-19 outbreak, can make people more anxious and guilty about the effects of the contagion, quarantine, and stigma on their families and friends.
targetString: Mburo am letǝgǝna -a sursuri kǝnga-a kortǝ-a dǝ, nǝlefa jamaye banatǝ ye kǝla fǝlangtǝ COVID-19 ye dǝ ye falnzǝ, am so wa raksǝ karuwunkǝngai nguwuwa kuru kwasa dǝ tartǝgǝ dǝn biunza yeyi ro fanzain, kortǝ, kuru yallanza-a sawaanza-a njutu-a.

sourceString: Thus, mental health care should be provided to COVID-19 patients, suspected individuals, and people in contact with them as well as the general public who are in need.
targetString: Adǝ nankaro, nǝlefa hangalbe ro cistuwu am COVID-19 ye zamzǝna, am zortǝna, kuru am dewo letaana-a kuru jama samma so kam dǝwo mǝradǝzǝna so ro tin.

sourceString: The psychological support should include the establishment of multidisciplinary mental health teams, clear communications with regular and accurate updates about the SARS-CoV-2 outbreak and treatment plans and the use of professional electronic devices and applications to avoid close contact with each other.
targetString: Bana hangal kǝrdistǝgǝ ye dǝ suronzǝn cidawu nǝlefa hangal ye nasha kada wuzǝna ma kokta mbeji ro walzǝ, bayan farak-a kǝla-kǝlan bayan kǝla SARS-CoV-2 ye dǝn diwo-a, dawari kurun diwo ye-a karaiyya konnuyen zaman ye ilmu men faidatǝ-a wande am so dǝ kamanza ro fattanyi ro.

sourceString: Effective vaccines are essential for interrupting the chain of transmission from animal reservoirs and infected humans to susceptible hosts and are often complementary to antiviral treatment in the control of epidemics caused by emerging viruses.
targetString: Kalimi ngǝla ma dǝ zauro faida kǝla tartǝgǝ dǝga na sabtǝram nzǝ dabbabe-a kam zamtǝna-a gǝnatǝmanzǝ-a yen sabtǝ dǝ kuru sandi nguwu so ro kurun kuli kwasabe ye dǝga banajin kwasa dinalabe dǝga katǝgǝ ro shi dǝwo ne kuliwa kwasabe bǝlin ro saluwin dǝ ye saudin so dǝ.

sourceString: Efforts have been made to develop S protein-based vaccines to generate long-term and potent neutralizing antibodies and/or protective immunity against SARS-CoV.
targetString: Kasadǝ tǝdǝna kǝla kalimi dǝwo ne shiro S protein-based gultin dǝ tando ro balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝbe tiyibe dǝwo tusshin ma dǝ diwo ro kuru/aw balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝbe tiyibe dǝwo SARS-CoV kǝriwjin ma.

sourceString: Live-attenuated vaccines have been evaluated in animal models for SARS.
targetString: Kalimi dǝwo duno kuli kwasabe dǝye cejin ma kǝla dabba yen jarabtǝna SARS ro.

sourceString: However, the in vivo efficacy of these vaccine candidates in elderly individuals and lethal-challenge models and their protection against zoonotic virus infection have yet to be determined before a clinical study is initiated.
