targetString: Lamar SARS-CoV-a MERS-CoV-a yedei, nǝm gade gade futu sandibe fuwun gawonno issanadǝye yi SARS-CoV-2-a RaTG13ye-a dǝ zauro kura sandi ro nǝm ya/awa gǝnatǝgǝ ro.

sourceString: That is to say, bats might not be the immediate reservoir host(s) of SARS-CoV-2 unless almost identical bat CoVs are found in future.
targetString: Adǝ ma’ananzǝ, batata so gǝnyi guwom au tanki sototǝma SARS-CoV-2YE buro salakye wo ro walzayin, wande karaa lan CoV batataye zauro samun kǝnngatayin tuwangatǝ gǝnyi'a.

sourceString: Presumably, the intermediate animal hosts of SARS-CoV-2 should be among the wildlife species sold and killed at the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, with which many of the initial cases of COVID-19 were associated, indicative of a probable animal-to-human transmission event.
targetString: Dabba sototǝma dawube SARS-CoV-2ye dǝ suro dabbawa karaaye kasuwu Huananye lan tǝladin dǝ ro zantǝgǝna, shi doni kessa COVID-19ye ngǝwu so'a leyata ma dǝ, daji adǝye fǝlejin faltǝgǝ au tartǝgǝ ndi kate dabba-a adammana-ayen.

sourceString: Several recent studies based on metagenomic sequencing have suggested that a group of endangered small mammals known as pangolins (Manis javanica) could also harbour ancestral beta-CoVs related to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Kǝra'a au kulashi ilmuye kada karungu ro kǝla "metagenomic sequencing"yen tǝdǝnaye fǝlejin, jam'u dabbawa sǝnanaye sandiro pangolin sayin dǝye kuliwa kwasabe beta-CoV do SARS-CoV-2-a samun dǝ tiyinzan mbeji.

sourceString: These novel pangolin CoV genomes share 85-92% nucleotide sequence homology with SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: 'CoV genome'Dabba pangolinye dǝ ci 85 - 92% 'nucleotide sequence homology'nzaye SARS-COV-a tilo wo.

sourceString: However, they are equally closely related to RaTG13 with about 90% identity at the level of nucleotide sequence.
targetString: Kuru adǝgai ma, sandi dǝ zauro saiyya RaTG13 zauro karungu, ci 90% karunga daraja nǝm samunye "nucleotide sequence" ye.

sourceString: They cluster into two sub-lineages of SARS-CoV-2-like viruses in the phylogenetic tree, one of which share a more similar receptor binding domain (RBD) with SARS-CoV-2, with 97.4% amino acid sequence identity.
targetString: Jam'u sǝnana ndi kuliwa kwasaye SARS-CoV-2 a samun ro yektayin suro kǝska "phylogeny"ye lan, falnza dǝ SARS-CoV-2 -a awo shiro 'receptor binding domain" sayin dǝ jili tilo karunga faidatayin, ci 'amin acid sequencing identiy' 97.4%- a.

sourceString: In stark contrast, the RBDs of SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 are more divergent, albeit a higher degree of sequence homology genome-wide.
targetString: RBD SARS-CoV-2 ye-a RaTG13 ye-a dǝ gade gade, daraja "sequence homolgy"ye dǝ kura yaye.

sourceString: An earlier study on diseased pangolins also reported the detection of viral contigs from lung samples, which turn out to be similarly related to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Kǝra au kulashi buron kǝla 'pangolin'yen tǝdǝna dǝye sǝkkǝ awo shiro 'viral contigs' sayin dǝ samfǝr fufube lan turuna, shi doni SARS-CoV'a zauro samun ro walzǝna ma dǝ.

sourceString: This study adopted different assembly methods and manual curation to generate a partial genome sequence comprising about 86.3% of the full-length viral genome.
targetString: Kǝradǝye duluwuwa na fallo saptaaye-a mukko lan saptaye-a kaanzǝzǝgǝ 'genome sequence' gana laa tuwandǝna, shi do suro dǝn ci 86.3% datǝ kaamil 'viral genomeye'a ma.

sourceString: We cannot exclude the possibility that pangolin is one of the intermediate animal hosts of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Mowontǝ do dabba pangolin dǝ shima dabba daudawube sototǝmma SARS-CoV-2ye dǝ rangye tuluye kollemba.

sourceString: However, currently there is no evidence in support of a direct pangolin origin of SARS-CoV-2 due to the sequence divergence between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs.
targetString: Ammana, kǝmaa dǝ ro dalil/shada do SARS-CoV-2 pangolinyen katambo fǝlejin ma ba dalil nǝm gade gade ndikate SARS-CoV-2ye-a beta-CoVwa SARS-CoV-2 pangolin-a ye dǝye sǝkkǝ.

sourceString: In addition, the distance between SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 is even shorter than that between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs.
targetString: Adǝ ro kǝltǝyin, nǝm cintu ndikate SARS-CoV-2-a RaTG13-aye dǝ nǝm cintu ndikate SARS-CoV-2-a beta-CoVwa pangolin SARS-CoV-2ye-a ma ro koriwo.

sourceString: The evolutionary pathway of SARS-CoV-2 in bats, pangolins and other mammals remains to be established.
targetString: Diwal tarihi fǝlamtǝye SARS-CoV-2 tiyi batatabe-a, pangolinbe-a, dabbawa gadeye-a dǝ fuwun do gultin.

sourceString: Whereas the highest sequence homology has been found in the RBDs between SARS-CoV-2 and pangolin, SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs, SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13 share the highest genome-wide sequence homology.
targetString: Nǝm samun halaktǝnzabe gana gana zauro turuna suro RBDwa ndikate SARS-CoV-2-a, pangolin-a, beta CoVwa batataye SARS-CoV-2-a leyata tuwandǝna dǝn, beta CoVwa SARS-CoV-2 batataye-a leyata-a, SARS-CoV-2-a, RaTG13-a dǝ "genome-wide sequence homology" kuruwu shiyeyi ba ma dǝ sandiye kaanza fal.

sourceString: It is highly speculative that the high degree of similarity between the RBDs of pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs and SARS-CoV-2 is driven by selectivity-mediated convergent evolution.
targetString: Nǝm samun ndikate RBDwa beta-CoV SARS-CoV-2-a leyata pangolinbe-a SARS-CoV-2 -a ye dǝ awo shiro "selectivity-mediated convergent evolution" sayin dǝ sǝkkǝ ro zauro tǝmatǝgǝna.

sourceString: A counter-proposal is in favour of a recombination between a pangolin SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoV and RaTG13 in the third wild animal species.
targetString: Shawari kulashi waltǝm diobe dǝ, beta-CoVwa SARS-CoV-2'a leyata pangolinbe-a RaTG13-a waltǝm tiyi dabba kǝn yakkǝme dǝyen kǝltǝ ro majin.

sourceString: As a driving force in evolution, recombination is widespread among beta-CoVs.
targetString: Duno fǝlamtǝ fuwuro zuzǝyin ye naptǝn, waltǝm kǝltǝ dǝ dawu beta-CoVwa yelan zauro ngǝwu.

sourceString: The jury is still out on the immediate zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Sharawa (jury) kuwa yaye na SARS-CoV-2 dabba lan cizǝ dabba gade ro faltǝyin dǝ mazayin

sourceString: Besides the highly pathogenic HCoVs, the zoonotic origin of HCoV-229E, HCoV-OC43, HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-HKU1 have also been studied.
targetString: HCoVwa zauro nǝm dondi gǝrzayindǝn guron, na buro salakye HCoV-229E-a, HCoV-OC43-a, HCoV-NL63-a, HCoV-HKU1-a ciza faltayin dǝ kulastǝ notǝna.

sourceString: Phylogenetic evidence indicated that both HCoV-NL63 and HCoV-229E might have originated from bat CoVs, while the parental viruses of HCoV-OC43 and HCoV-HKU1 have been found in rodents.
targetString: Dalilla do fuwutǝ au fafaltǝ dabbaye bayanjin dǝye fǝlezǝna HCoV-NL63-a HCoV-229E-a dǝ CoVwa batatayen ciyada, kuru kuliwa kwasabe HCoV-OC43-a HCoV-HKU1-a dǝ tiyi dabba jili julwa soyen ciyada.

sourceString: It has been reported that a bat CoV termed ARCoV.2 (Appalachian Ridge CoV) detected in North American tricolored bat displayed close relationship with HCoV-NL63.
targetString: Rifot tǝdǝna CoV batataye shiro ARCoV.2 gulzayin dǝ. Shi doni tiyi batata North Americaye kala yakkǝ'a ma dǝyen turuna dǝ, alaka karunguye ndi kate sha HCoV-NL63-a fǝlezǝna.

sourceString: On the other hand, HCoV-229E was genetically related to another bat CoV, termed Hipposideros/GhanaKwam/19/2008, which was detected in Ghana, while camelids have also been suspected as its intermediate host.
targetString: Mukko fallan, HCoV-229E dǝ sha CoV batataye gade sunzǝ Hipposideros/GhanaKwam/19/2008 dǝ-a zauro karungu wo, shi doni lardǝ Ghanaye lan fodutǝna dǝ, kuru kalimo sandima sototǝma ndikate wo ro tǝmatǝna.

sourceString: For clarity, the current knowledge on animal origins of known HCoVs is summarized in Figure ​1 and Table 2.
targetString: Ngǝla ro asutǝ nanka ro, ilmu kǝrmaa ro kǝla dabbawa do HCoVwa sandi men tuwandǝnaye dǝ fig. 1-a tewur 2 lan kasartǝna.

sourceString: Phylogenetic analysis has provided evidence for interspecies transmission events of HCoVs in the history.
targetString: Kulashi kǝla fǝlamtǝ au fafaltǝ yen tǝdǝnaye dalil tartǝgǝ HCoVwa ye ndi kate dabbawa gade gadeyen suro tarihiyen wakajin fǝlezǝna.

sourceString: When HCoV-OC43 crossed species to infect humans from domestic livestock around 1890, a pandemic of respiratory infection was recorded.
targetString: Sa HCoV-OC43 dabbawa fatoyen fartǝ adammana so sǝtana dǝ saa 1890 lan, wawa kwasa yintǝbe turuna.

sourceString: The interspecies transmission history of HCoV-229E is less clear.
targetString: Tarihi HCoV-229Eye jili dabbaye fallen cine jili gade ro dǝ kone ngǝla ro asutǝnyi.

sourceString: Bat alpha-CoVs closely related to HCoV-229E have been found.
targetString: Alpha CoVwa batataye so dǝ sandiya HCoV-229Eya zauro karungu.

sourceString: Between them there is an alpaca alpha-CoV.
targetString: Ndikatenzan kuli kwasabe shiro 'alpaca alpha-CoV' sayin dǝ mbeji.

sourceString: Several lines of evidence support the transmission of virus from bats to humans directly.
targetString: Shadawa kadaye kuli kwasabe batata lan cizǝ adammana ro faltǝgǝye ngawo satana.

sourceString: First, humans but not alpacas might have contact with bats in a shared ecological niche.
targetString: Buro salakyen, adammana so sandima batata so'a leta alpaca so gǝnyi, sau kor kǝnǝnganzaye fal nanka dǝ ro.

sourceString: Instead, humans have close contact with alpacas.
targetString: Susu dǝ ro, adammana so sandima alpaca'a leta.

sourceString: Second, HCoV-229E-related bat alpha-CoVs are diverse and non-pathogenic in bats, whereas alpaca alpha-CoV caused an outbreak of respiratory disease in infected animals.
targetString: Kǝn indimi, HCoV-229E alpha-CoV batataye'a leyata dǝ sandi jilinza ngǝwu kuru tiyi batata soyen kwasa suwudimba, amma alpha-CoV alpacaye dǝye kwasa yintǝbe dabbawa zamtǝna lan sǝkkǝ fǝlangzǝna.

sourceString: Finally, alpaca alpha-CoV has not been found in feral animals.
targetString: Dare dajiram lan, alpha-CoV alpacaye dǝ tiyi dabbawa ca faton rotǝna do karaa ro waltanayen tuwandǝnyi.

sourceString: Thus, the possibility cannot be excluded that alpacas obtain the HCoV-229E-related alpha-CoV from humans.
targetString: Adǝgai lan, mowontǝ doni alpaca soye HCoV-229E alpha-CoV'a leyata dǝ na adammana soyen cuwanda dǝ rangnye tuluyemba wo.

sourceString: In fact, bats are the direct source of human pathogenic viruses including rabies virus, Ebola virus, Nipah virus and Hendra virus.
targetString: Mana dǝye yanzǝ dǝ, batata so dǝ kuliya kwasabe adammana soye ngǝwu so sandi lan tuwandin, jili kuli kwasa rebisye so, kuli kwasa Ebolaye so, kuli kwasa Nipahye so-a kuli kwasa Hendrabe'a.

sourceString: It is therefore not too surprising that bats might transmit HCoV-229E to humans directly.
targetString: Adǝ nanka dǝ ro, batata soye adammana so ro HCoV-229E daata ro falzayin dǝ awo ajabye gǝnyi.

sourceString: Alternatively, whereas bat alpha-CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoV-229E, alpacas and dromedary camels might serve as intermediate hosts that transmit viruses to humans, exactly as in the case of MERS-CoV.
targetString: Na alpha CoV batataye sodǝ naptǝ sandi lan HCoV-229E tuwandǝnayen kasharu yaye, alpaca so-a kalimowa so-a dǝ naptǝ sototǝma dawube do kuli kwasabe dǝ'a adammana so ro falzayin yen kasharu, jili lamar MERS-CoV yedei hak biya.

sourceString: MERS-CoV serves as an excellent example of interspecies transmission from bats to dromedary camels and from dromedary camels to humans.
targetString: MERS-CoV dǝ misal zauro ngǝlama faltǝgǝ ndi kate dabbawa gade gadeyen, batata lan kalimo ro kuru kalimo lan adammana so ro.

sourceString: The evolutionary origin of MERS-CoV from bats is known at its initial identification and has also been strengthened by subsequent findings.
targetString: Tarihi baditǝ au fǝlamtǝ MERS-CoVye tiyi batata soyen dǝ shima sha notǝram buroye wo kuru awowa darebe tuwandǝnaye adǝ ro duno cina.

sourceString: It is obvious that bats provide a rich pool of virus species for interspecies exchange of genetic fragments and interspecies transmission.
targetString: Batata so dǝ nowata kuli kwasabe ngǝwuwa sawudin, ndikate dabbawa gade gadeyen awo 'genetic fragment' gulzayin dǝ yeyektǝ ro kuru ndi kate dabbawa gade gadeyen kuli kwasabe tartǝgǝ ro.

sourceString: Longevity, densely packed colonies, close social interaction and strong ability to fly are all favourable conditions for bats to be an ideal 'virus spreader'.
targetString: Kawu kuruwu-a, jami ngǝwu na fallo sapkata-a, mu'amala zauro karinguye suro jamiyen-a kuru raktǝ fartǝbe dunowa-a anyi samma kǝndawa do batata ro kǝjima kuli kwasabe tartǝgǝma shiyeyi ba ro waltǝ ro.

sourceString: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has been introduced to dromedary camels for decades.
targetString: Mukko fallan, MERS-CoV dǝ kalimowa ro yita gattǝgǝna dǝ saa kada.

sourceString: It is well adapted to these camels that have turned from an intermediate host to a stable and natural reservoir host.
targetString: Kalimowa anyiya zauro sǝli kaanzǝzǝgǝna hatta sototǝma dawube lan cizǝ guwom sototǝma alameye ro wallono.

sourceString: MERS-CoV causes very mild disease and maintains a relatively low mutation rate in these animals.
targetString: MERS-CoV dǝ kwasa sǝnana suwudin kuru futu faltǝ jili gade ro waljinye zauro idiyazǝna tiyi dabbawa anyiye lan.

sourceString: Its sporadic transmission to humans is an accident and humans remain a dead-end host of MERS-CoV as its transmission cannot be sustained.
targetString: Adammana so ro faltǝgǝnzǝ dǝ tajirwa men waka'ano kuru adammana so dǝ sandi ma sototǝma MERS-CoVye datǝrambe wo, saunzǝ faltǝgǝnzǝ loktu ngǝwu ro dǝgayimba.

sourceString: In contrast to the role of camels in the transmission of MERS-CoV, the role of pangolins, if there is any, in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is different.
targetString: Katap kalimowabe MERS-CoV tartǝgǝ lan gowotsayin dǝ ro gadezǝna lan, katap pangolinye, katap laa gowotcin ma mbeji maa, nasha SARS-CoV-2 tartǝgǝye ye dǝn dǝ gadezǝna.

sourceString: Particularly, pangolin beta-CoVs are highly pathogenic in pangolins.
targetString: Taganasma ro, beta-CoVwa pangolinbe dǝ zauro dabba pangolin sayin dǝ ro kwasa au nǝm dondi suwudin.

sourceString: They might be a dead-end host for SARS-CoV-2-related beta-CoVs, similar to civets in the case of SARS-CoV.
targetString: Sandi dǝ wajiya sototǝma darebe beta-CoVwa SARS-CoV-2'a leyata maye, civet so'a samun suro lamar SARS-CoVye lan.

sourceString: Several possibilities for interspecies transmission of SARS-CoV-2 from animals to humans have to be ruled in or ruled out in future studies.
targetString: Mowontǝwa kada kǝla tartǝgǝ SARS-CoV-2 ye ndi kate alauwwa au dabbawa gade gade yen, dabba lan adammana ro faltǝgǝye gotin au koltin kulashiya ilmube fuwu lan tǝdinyen.

sourceString: First, bats could be the reservoir host of a SARS-CoV-2-related virus almost identical to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Kǝn tilomi, batata so dǝ sandima guwom au tanki sototǝma kuli kwasabe SARS-CoV-2'a samunye wo, SARS-CoV-2'a jilinza tilo yedei.

sourceString: Humans might share the ecological niche with bats through butchering or coal mining.
targetString: Adammana so dǝ batata so'a kor kǝnǝngaye fal faidatayin ro waljin nǝm sunuri men (dabba duwatǝ) au cidi lanǝm kǝlimi shiro 'coal' gulzayin dǝ tulo men.

sourceString: Second, pangolins could be one of intermediate amplifying host to which a SARS-CoV-2-related virus had been newly introduced.
targetString: Kǝn indime, pangolin so dǝ sototǝma dawube ro walzayin shi doni belin ro kuli kwasabe SARS-CoV-2'a samun shiro tǝkkǝna ma.

sourceString: Humans contract the virus through butchering and consumption of game meat.
targetString: Adammana so dǝ kuli kwasabe dǝ dabbawa karaabe yezo-a danza gǝro-a men gozayin.

sourceString: It is possible that many mammals including domestic animals are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Dabbawa kada dauwnzan dabbawa fatobe`a so sandiya mowonzǝ SARS-CoV-2 ye sǝtayin.

sourceString: A survey of domestic and wild animals for antibodies is warranted.
targetString: Sofiyo dabbawa fatobe-a karaabe-a tǝdǝ awo tiyinzabe 'antibody' sayin kwasa kǝriujin ma dǝ kulastaye dǝ amartǝna.

sourceString: Third, as mentioned above, recombination and adaptation of SARS-CoV-2 might have occurred in a third species that has contact with both bats and pangolins.
targetString: Kǝn yakkǝme, futu buron gultǝna yedei, waltǝm SARS-CoV-2'a kǝltǝ-a kuru na dǝ kaanzǝtǝgǝ-a dǝ jili dabbaye gade kǝn yakkǝme do batata-a pangolin-a ndiso'a letana lan wakawono.

sourceString: The search for the animal origins of SARS-CoV-2 is still on.
targetString: Kulashi badiyaram SARS-CoV-2 ye tiyi dabbawa yen dǝ kuwayaye tǝdinna kara.

sourceString: Apart from different types of the animal hosts, three major factors on the viral side are also important in facilitating CoVs to cross species barriers.
targetString: Sototǝma dabbaye gade gade so dǝn kasǝn, awowa yakkǝ muhimmi nasha kuli kwasabeye dǝ sandiye zauro faidazayin nasha CoV so banatǝ dabba gade gade ro faltǝgǝ men.

sourceString: First of all, their relatively high mutation rates in RNA replication.
targetString: Buro salakyen, zauro faltǝ ngewu sadin suro "RNA replication" ye lan.

sourceString: In comparison to other single-stranded RNA viruses, the estimated mutation rates of CoVs could be regarded as “moderate” to “high” with an average substitution rate being ~10-4 substitution per year per site 2, depending on the phase of CoV adaptation to novel hosts.
targetString: Kuliwa kwasabe RNAbe je falla gade so'a gǝrenǝmiya, nǝm ngǝwu faltǝ CoVwa ye dǝ mowonzǝ daraja ganaye lan tai ngǝwu ro yadeye gultin, fafaltǝ saa lan gana yaye ~10-4 yedei ro faltin.

sourceString: CoVs have a proof-reading exoribonuclease, deletion of which results in exceedingly high mutability and attenuation or even inviability.
targetString: CoV so dǝ tiyinzan awo shiro “proof-reading exoribonuclease" gulzayin dǝ mbeji, sha cintǝ dǝ fafaltǝ naa kozǝna-a, duno gana-a, au hatta faidajimba ro waltǝ suwudin.

sourceString: Interestingly, the nucleotide analogue Remdesivir is known to suppress CoV replication through inhibition of this exoribonuclease and the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
targetString: Awo hangal gǝrjin dǝ, awo shiro "nucleotide analogue Remdesivir" sayin dǝ ngǝwutǝ CoVye ratsǝ rojin ro noata, diwal 'exoribonuclease dǝ-a RNA-dependent RNA polymerase dǝ-a daptǝ men.

sourceString: Remdesivir is one of most promising anti-SARS-CoV-2 agents to be tested in clinical trials.
targetString: Remdesivir dǝ shima kurun SARS-CoV-2ye zauro faidajin ro tǝmatǝna do litarin jarabtǝna ma wo.

sourceString: Nevertheless, mutation rates of CoVs are about a million times higher than those of their hosts.
targetString: Adǝn yaye, faltǝ CoV sobe dǝ nǝm ngǝwu lan faltǝ sototǝmanzabe'a ci niliyon fal yedei lan kozana.

sourceString: In addition, mutation rate is often high when CoVs are not well adapted to the host.
targetString: Adǝ ro kǝllǝgǝ ne, faltǝ dǝ sa CoV so dǝ sototǝmanza'a salinyi maa shima zauro ngǝwujinno.

sourceString: Compared to SARS-CoV with a high mutation rate, the mutation rate of SARS-CoV-2 is apparently lower, suggestive of a higher level of adaptation to humans.
targetString: SARS-CoV do fafaltǝ ngǝwu'a dǝ'a kǝllǝmiya, fafaltǝ SARS-CoV-2ye dǝ shima gana wo, adǝye fǝlejin tiyi adammana soye kǝlo cetto.

sourceString: Presumably, it has already been adapted to another host close to humans.
targetString: Sototǝma gade adammana so'a karungu gade ro napsǝgǝna ro tǝmatǝna.

sourceString: In addition to SARS-CoV-2, this also applies to MERS-CoV, which is well adapted to dromedary camels.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 ro kǝllǝgǝmiya, adǝgai dǝ MERS-CoV yen waajin, shi doni zauro kalimowa sǝlina au kaanzǝzǝgǝna.

sourceString: Theoretically, it is unlikely that genetic drift would render vaccines and antivirals against SARS-CoV-2 ineffective quickly.
targetString: Mana ngai me dǝn maa, gǝrtǝgǝ awo shiro 'genes' sayin ye dǝye kalimi so kurunna SARS-CoV-2 kǝriutǝbe'a faidajimba sǝdin ro tǝmatǝnyi.

sourceString: Second, the large RNA genome in CoVs exerts extra plasticity in genome modification for mutations and recombination, thereby increasing the probability for interspecies co-evolution, which is advantageous for the emergence of novel CoVs when the conditions become appropriate.
targetString: Kǝn indimi, 'RNA genome' kura suro CoV soye dǝ banazǝgǝ faltǝ-a waltǝm kǝltǝ-a wakajin, daji adǝgai men mowontǝ fǝlamtǝ ndikate dabbawaye fuwuzǝyin, shi doni luwo CoV wa soye ro zauro kǝji sa kǝndawa so kalkal jiya.

sourceString: This is supported by the copious unique open reading frames and protein functions encoded towards the 3′ end of the genome.
targetString: Ngawo adǝye awo do shiro "copious unique open reading frame" sayin dǝ-a "protein functions encoded towards 3' end of the genome" ye-a ye satana.

sourceString: Third, CoVs randomly and frequently switch templates during RNA replication through a unique “copy-choice” mechanism.
targetString: Kǝn yakkǝme, CoV so dǝ fasal ba'a ro kuru ngǝwu ngǝwu ro 'template' falzayin sa RNA ngǝwu ro sadin ma nzundu "copy-choice" be shi yeyi ba men.

sourceString: In a host that serves as the mixing vessel, strand switching occurs frequently during CoV RNA transcription.
targetString: Tiyi sototǝma do naptǝ awo suro dǝn tuskatinye lan dǝgana dǝ, je faltǝ ngǝwu ngǝwu ro wakajin sa CoV RNA kǝratin lan.

sourceString: Highly homologous full-length and subgenomic RNAs could recombine to generate new CoVs.
targetString: RNAwa sandiro "highly homologous full length and subgenomic" sayin dǝ raksa walta kǝlta CoVwa bǝlin satandin.

sourceString: Phylogenetic evidence of natural recombination has been found in both HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-OC43, as well as animal CoVs such as bat SL-CoV and batCoV-HKU9.
targetString: Shada waltǝm kǝltǝ alamen wakajinye tuwandǝna suro HCoV-HKU1 be-a HCoV-OC43 be-a ndi son, kuru adǝgaima CoVwa jili SL-CoV batataye-a kuru bat-CoV-HKU9-a.

sourceString: Virus-host interaction in relation to transmission
targetString: Mu'amala ndi kate kuli kwasabe-a sototǝmabe-a faltǝgǝ au tartǝgǝ ro wungǝmmiya.

sourceString: Besides three viral factors stated above, viral interaction with host receptor is another key factor influential on interspecies transmission.
targetString: Awowa kuli kwasabe wuzǝna yakkǝ somtǝna anyi dawun ba ro, mu'amala kuli kwasabe-a sototǝma kuli kwasaye sǝmoyinnaye ndikate dǝ zauro faidajin nasha faltǝgǝ au tartǝgǝ ndikate dabbawabe lan.

sourceString: Herein, recombination of SARS-CoV is taken as a typical example, which also showed evidence of positive selection during interspecies transmission events.
targetString: Na allan, waltǝm kǝltǝ SARS-CoVye dǝ shima misal ro gotin, shi doni kartǝ ngǝla fǝlezǝna sa faltǝgǝ bayna dabbawa gade gadeyen wakajin maa.

sourceString: Based on the comparative analysis between isolates of human and civet SARS-CoVs, SARS-CoV is thought to undergo rapid adaptation in different hosts, particularly with mutations at the RBD of the S protein.
targetString: Kulastǝ gǝretabe do SARS-CoVwa tiyi adammanabe-a civet-a yen tǝdǝna dǝ ro wungǝmmiya, SARS-CoV dǝ tini sototǝma so sǝlin, taganas ma ro sa faltǝ RBDye wakajiya.

sourceString: Generally, the RBD in the S protein of a CoV interacts with the cellular receptor and is intensely selected by the host antibody response.
targetString: RBD suro 'S protein' CoVye dǝ mowoma suro tiyibe dǝ fantayin au mu'amala sadin kuru awowa kwasa kǝriutǝbe tiyi sototǝmaye dǝye tini sandiya karjin.

sourceString: In SARS-CoV, the RBD is in the 318th to 510th amino acids on the S1 fragment, which binds to the human ACE2 as well as its coreceptors for viral entry.
targetString: SARS-CoV lan, RBD shima 'amino acid' kǝn 318 sǝta 510 ro saadǝna dǝ kǝla 'S1 fragment'ye lan, shi doni ACE2 adammanabe ro kǝrtǝyin gawo kuli kwasabe ye nankaro.

sourceString: The RBD of SARS-CoV is capable of recognizing the ACE2 receptors of various animals, including bat, civet, mouse and raccoon dog, allowing interspecies transmission of the virus.
targetString: RBD SARS-CoVye dǝ raksǝ mowoma ACE2 dabbawa jili gade gadeye asujin, dawu dǝn batata-a, 'civet'-a kuru' racoon dog'-a mbeji, faltǝgǝ ndikate jiliwa dabbaye gade gade kolzǝ wakajin.

sourceString: In fact, only 6 amino acid residues were observed to be different from human and civet viral isolates in the RBD and 4 of them locate in the receptor-binding motif for interaction with the ACE2 receptor.
targetString: Manaye yanzǝ dǝ, 'amino acid'wa arakkǝ njong kwasa kuli suwudin tiyi adammanbe-a civetye-a lan firtǝna suro RBDyen gade gade ro asutǝ kuru diyeu 4 dǝ na shiro 'receptor binding motif gulayin dǝn kara, mowoma ACE2'a mu'amala dio nanka ro.

sourceString: Civet SARS-CoV has K479N and S487T mutations in its RBD, which might increase the affinity of the interaction of spike protein with human ACE2 receptor.
targetString: SARS-CoV civetye dǝ RBDnzǝn faltǝ shiro K479N-a S487T gulzayin dǝ mbeji, shi doni mu'amala "spike protein" be-a mowoma ACE2 adammanabe-a ndikaten mu'amala dio suwudin dǝ.

sourceString: In other words, these two amino acid substitutions might be critical to viral adaption to humans.
targetString: Ma'ana, 'amino acid'wa ndi anyi sandiya faltǝ dǝ zauro faida'a kuli kwasabe adammana liyo ro.

sourceString: It is noteworthy that SARS-CoV-2 shares the same cellular receptor with SARS-CoV.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 dǝ sha SARS-CoV'a mowomanza tilo.

sourceString: A 30% difference between SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV in the S1 unit of the S protein implicates that the binding affinity of its S protein with human ACE2 might have altered.
targetString: Nǝm gade ci 30% ndikate SARS-CoV-2-a SARS-Cov-a suro 'S1 unit protein"ye dǝye fǝlejin 'S proteinye ACE2 adammanabe'a kǝltǝ dǝ gana bannatǝna.

sourceString: Indeed, a cryo-EM study indicates a 10- to 20-fold higher affinity of this binding than that between human ACE2 and SARS-CoV S protein.
targetString: Tawadǝ ro, kǝra cryo-EMye kǝltǝ adǝye wakatǝnzǝ ci 10 - 20 lan kǝltǝ ACE2 adammanabe-a SARS-CoV S protein be-a kozǝna fǝlezǝna.

sourceString: It will also be of interest to determine whether any other coreceptor might be required for SARS-CoV-2 transmission.
targetString: Mowoma gǝdima gade faltǝgǝ SARS-CoVye ro mǝradǝtǝna la mǝradǝtǝnyi ro notǝ dǝ tǝraana.

sourceString: Intriguingly, HCoV-NL63 also binds to ACE2 but with a different part of S.
targetString: Awo ajabba dǝ, HCoV-NL63 ye ACE2 ro nasha Sye gade men kǝltǝyin.

sourceString: There exist many other HCoV receptors, such as aminopeptidase N for HCoV-229E, and 9-O-acetylated sialic acid for HCoV-OC43.
targetString: Mowoma HCoVye gade kada mbeji, misallo "aminopeptidase N" HCoV-229E ro, kuru "9-O-acetylated sialic acid" HCoV-OC43 ro.

sourceString: They might also account for successful adaptation of these CoVs in humans after interspecies transmission from their animal hosts.
targetString: Sandi anyi raksa futu CoVwa anyiye adammana so kǝlon kǝnasartana dǝ guljin, ngawo faltǝgǝ ndikate dabbawa gade gadeyen sǝkkǝ tiyi dabbawanzayen gozana.

sourceString: In addition to cellular receptors, the outcome of interspecies transmission of HCoVs is also governed by other host dependency and restriction factors.
targetString: Mowoma 'cellular'ye ro kǝllǝgǝmiya, tamoram faltǝgǝ HCoVwabe ndikate dabbawa jii gade gadeye dǝ sototǝma gade ro tǝngatǝgǝ-a awowa gade faltǝgǝ dapcin-a kǝla dǝn huwom sǝdin.

sourceString: The divergence of these host proteins between humans and natural reservoir hosts of HCoVs such as bats, dromedary camels and rodents might constitute a barrier to interspecies transmission.
targetString: Nǝm gade gade "protein"wa sototǝma anyiye ndi kate adammana so-a guwom sototǝma alamen waajin HCoVwaye jili batata so, kalimo so, kuru dabbawa sǝnana julwa yedei so-a yedǝ, kalangai ro walzayin dabba falyen gade ro faltǝgǝ ro.

sourceString: HCoVs have to usurp host dependency factors and subvert host restriction factors for a successful interspecies transmission.
targetString: HCoV so dǝ lamarra do sǝkkǝ sototǝma ro tǝngatayin dǝ ba ro sadǝ kuru lamarra do sǝkkǝ sototǝmaye sandiya dapcin dǝ wurzayin, kǝnasar faltǝgǝ ye ndikate dabbawa gade gadeyen fando nankaro.

sourceString: In this regard, molecular determinants in this important area of virus-host interaction remain to be identified and characterized.
targetString: Adǝ ro wungǝmmiya, molekyulla do nasha mu'amala kuli kwasabe-a sototǝma-aye asuzayin dǝ zauro sandiya asutǝ faidajin.

sourceString: An unbiased genome-wide screening of host dependency and restriction factors for SARS-CoV-2 using the state-of-the-art technology of CRISPR might be fruitful.
targetString: Skǝrinin ngǝla kǝla sototǝma ro tǝngatǝgǝyen-a kuru lamarra faltǝgǝ dapcin-a SARS-CoV-2ye tǝdǝna ma ngǝlawo, nzundu zamanye CRISPR dǝ faidatǝ dio dǝ zauro faidajin.

sourceString: Emergence of novel HCoVs: back to ground zero
targetString: Luwo HCoVwa bǝlinye: badiyaram ro waltǝ.

sourceString: The diversity of bat CoVs provides ample opportunities for the emergence of novel HCoVs.
targetString: Nǝm gade gade CoVwa batataye dǝ duluwuwa luwobe HCoVwa bǝlin ro cina.

sourceString: In this sense, bat CoVs serve as the gene pool of HCoVs.
targetString: Mana adǝ ro wungǝmmiya, CoVwa batataye dǝ sandima HCoVwa bǝlin so dǝ'a sasambǝ.

sourceString: In addition, rapid mutation and genetic recombination also drive HCoV evolution and serve as two important steps in this process.
targetString: Adǝ ro yira, fafaltǝ duwa duwabe-a 'genetic recombination'-a dǝ sandima fǝlamtǝ HCoVye fuwuro zuzayin kuru naptǝ katapwa faida'a indiye sadin duluwu adǝ lan.

sourceString: For example, the acquisition or loss of novel protein-coding genes has the potential to drastically modify viral phenotypes.
targetString: Misallo, awo shiro "novel protein-coding genes" sayin dǝ fando au fattǝgǝ dǝ raksǝ 'viral phenotypes' saashin.

sourceString: Among SARS-CoV accessory proteins, ORF8 has been thought to be important in adaptation to humans, as SARS-CoV-related bat viruses were isolated but found to encode divergent ORF8 proteins.
targetString: Dawu protinna faida'a SARS-CoV ye dǝn, ORF8 dǝ zauro nasha tiyi adammana liyo be dǝn faida'a ro fantin dǝ, dalilnzǝ dǝ kuliwa kwasaye batataye do SARS-Cov'a leyata dǝ firtǝ tutuluwuna amma sandiye protin ORF8 gade gade nozana.

sourceString: A 29-nucleotide deletion characteristic of SARS-CoVs has been found in strains isolated at the beginning of the human epidemic.
targetString: Hal SARS-CoVye niukǝliyotayid 29 cintǝbe dǝ suro jili do tiyi adammanaben firtǝna dǝn mbeji badiyaram wawa adammanabe dǝn.

sourceString: This deletion splits ORF8 into ORF8a and ORF8b and is thought to be an adaptive mutation that promotes the switch of hosts.
targetString: Cintǝ dǝye ORF8'a ORF8a-a ORF8b-a ro yekcin, kuru adǝ faltǝ liyo be do sototǝma faltǝ fuwuzǝyin ma ro turin.

sourceString: Besides, SARS-CoV has a possible recombination history with lineages of alpha- and gamma-CoVs, where a large number of smaller recombinant regions were identified in the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
targetString: Adǝ dawun ba man, SARS-CoV dǝ tarihinzǝ waltǝm CoVwa alfa-a gama-a kǝltaye mbeji, na do nasha sǝnana waltǝm kǝltabe kada fodutǝna tiyi "RNA polymerase" do RNA ro tǝngatǝgǝ na yen.

sourceString: Recombination locations were also identified in the nsp9, most of nsp10, and parts of nsp14.
targetString: Nasha'a waltǝm kǝltabbe na'a shiro nsp9 gulzayin dǝ-a, nsp10-a, kuru na'a laa nsp14be-a dǝ fodutǝna.

sourceString: Likewise, it has been shown that the epidemic MERS-CoV experienced recombination events between different lineages, which occurred in dromedary camels in Saudi Arabia.
targetString: Adǝgaima, wawa MERS-CoVye turuna dǝ kǝlele waltǝm laiyya gade gaden kǝlta ro fǝletǝna, shi doni tiyi kalimowa Saudi Arabia yen wakazǝna dǝ.

sourceString: Besides SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, recombination events have also been observed in other HCoVs, in which the HCoVs recombine with other animal CoVs in their non-structural genes.
targetString: SARS-CoV'a MERS-CoV'a guron, kǝlelewa waltǝm kǝltabe dǝ HCoVwa gade lan turuna, suro dǝn HCoVwa dǝ CoVwa dabba'a gadebe'a kǝltayin.

sourceString: It should also be cautioned that artificial selection can contribute to unintended changes in viral genomes, most likely resulting from relieving viruses from selection pressures exerted, such as by the host immune system.
targetString: Kuru adǝgaima sumo'a gǝrtǝ kartǝ ngai kamma dǝ fafaltǝ nyiyatǝnyi suro "viral genome" ye dǝn suwudin dǝ ro, adǝye awo suwudin dǝ kuliwa kwasabe dǝ'a kazǝyi kartǝbe ro sǝtkayin, misallo askǝrra tiyi sototǝmaye dǝ.

sourceString: An example of these effects is the loss of a full-length ORF4 in the HCoV-229E prototype strain, owing to a two-nucleotide deletion.
targetString: Misal tamoramwa anyi be dǝ shima fattǝgǝ datǝ kaamil ORF4ye tiyi HCoV-229E ye lan, adǝ sawunzǝ niukliotide indi cinta.

sourceString: While intact ORF4 could be observed in bat and camel viruses related to HCoV-229E, the alpaca alpha-CoV displays a single nucleotide insertion, resulting in a frameshift.
targetString: ORF4 letǝnyi dǝ tiyi batata-a kalimo-a ye lan turin yaye, "alpha-CoV" alpaca ye dǝ ikkoram niukliotayid ye fal dǝ ma fǝlejin, adǝye gǝrtǝgǝ 'frame'ye suwudin.

sourceString: Last but not least, the evolution of novel HCoVs is also driven by the selection pressure in their reservoir hosts.
targetString: Dare datǝram lan, fǝlamtǝ (evolution) HCoVwa be dǝ kazǝyi karnobe suro guwom au tiyi sototǝmaye dǝ sha fuwuzǝyin.

sourceString: Asymptomatic or only mild symptoms were detected when bats were infected with CoVs, indicating the mutual adaptation between CoVs and bats.
targetString: Alama nǝm dondiye baa au alama nǝm dondiye gana laa turuna sa batata so CoV soye sandiya sǝtaiyya, adǝye kǝlo ndi kate CoV so-a batata soye-a dǝ fǝlejin.

sourceString: It appeared that bats are well adapted to CoVs anatomically and physiologically.
targetString: Batata so dǝ zauro CoV so-a talina nasha futu tiyinzaye tǝnandǝna-a cidajin-a so yen.

sourceString: For example, defects in the activation of pro-inflammatory response in bats efficiently reduce the pathology triggered by CoVs.
targetString: Misallo, illawa jawawu kau kwasa dǝ cijin ro tiyi batata soye sango dǝ tai dazǝ nǝm dondi CoV soye saudin dǝ fulujin.

sourceString: Besides, the natural killer cell activity in bats is suppressed due to upregulation of inhibitory natural killer cell receptor NKG2/CD94 and low expression level of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules.
targetString: Adǝn kasǝn, cidawa sel yezobe tiyi batata soye dǝ rattǝna dalil na'a awowa sel cejin mowobe NKG2/CD94 dǝ kaltǝgǝyen kuru daraja awo shiro "major histocompatibility complex class I molecules" gulzayin dǝ gana ro fǝletayen.

sourceString: Moreover, the high level of reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated from high metabolic activity of bats could both suppress CoV replication and affects proofreading by exoribonuclease, thus providing the selection pressure for the generation of virus strains highly pathogenic when introduced into a new host.
targetString: Ngǝwutǝ "reactive oxygen species (ROS)" be do cidatǝ ngǝwu tiyi batatasoye suwudin dǝye raksǝ ngǝwutǝ CoVye ratsǝ rojin kuru "exoribonuclease"ye gam yasa ye lejin, adǝgai lan kazǝyi kartabe suwudin jili kuli kwasabe zauro nǝm dondi gǝrzǝyin fando ro sa tiyi sototǝmaye ro tǝkkiya.

sourceString: More pathogenic CoV strains might also evolve by recombination, leading to the acquisition of novel proteins or protein features for host adaptation.
targetString: Jiliwa CoVye zauro nǝm dondi sawudin gade so waltǝm kǝltǝmen fǝlamzana ro waljin, adǝye "novel protein" fando suwudin au alamawa "protein"be fando suwudin yiyi sototǝmaye kǝlo nankaro.

sourceString: Thus, it is not by chance that three novel HCoVs have emerged in the past two decades.
targetString: Adǝ ye fǝlejin, luwo au bayantǝ HCoVwa yakkǝye suro saa findi kozǝnaye dǝn dǝ wawa men wakawono ro.

sourceString: CoVs are non-pathogenic or cause mild symptoms in their reservoir hosts such as bats and camels.
targetString: CoV so dǝ tiyi guwom au tanki sandiya sototǝma jili batata so kalimo soyen nǝm dondi saudimba au saudiyaye gana.

sourceString: They replicate robustly without eliciting a strong host immune response.
targetString: Sandi dǝ taidazana ngǝwuzayin, tiyi sototǝmanzaye sandiya luwalajimba ro.

sourceString: Herein lie the secrets of why asymptomatic carriers are seen and what causes the severe cases in human infection.
targetString: Na adǝ lan ashir am alama nǝm dondiye tiyinzan ba asutinn-a kuru awo do tiyi adammanasoyen nǝm dondi zauro zau suwudin dǝ kara.

sourceString: The severe symptoms are mainly due to the hyperactivation of immune response and the cytokine storm wherein the stronger the immune response, the more severe the lung damage.
targetString: Alamawa nǝm dondibe zauro zau dǝ ngǝwuso ro dalil cidatǝ ngǝwu askǝrra tiyibe-a kuru awo shiro "cytokine response" sayin do cidatǝ askǝrraye dǝ duno'a jin wo son, banna fufube dǝye tǝrayin.

sourceString: In contrast, in asymptomatic carriers, the immune response has been de-coupled from CoV replication.
targetString: Adǝ ro gadezǝna, tiyi gotǝwu alama nǝm dondibe fǝlezzanyi soyen, cidatǝ au katap gotǝ askǝrra tiyibe dǝ ngǝwu tǝ CoVye'a yektǝna.

sourceString: The same strategy of delinking the immune response might have beneficial effects in anti-SARS-CoV-2 therapy.
targetString: Fasal cidatǝ au katap gotǝ tiyibe yektǝbe dǝ tamoramwanzǝ faidajin waniye mbeji nasha kurun dio anti-SARS-CoV-2 be lan.

sourceString: The interferon response is particularly strong in bats.
targetString: Jawawu "interferon"be dǝ taganas ro dunowa tiyi batata soyen.

sourceString: Thus, administration of type I interferon at least in the early phase of SARS-CoV-2 infection in humans should be beneficial.
targetString: Adǝye fǝlezǝna, "type I interferon" badiyaram sa kamma SARS-CoV-2ye sǝtana dǝn ikko dǝ adammana so ro faidajin.

sourceString: In addition, NLRP3 inflammasome activation in bats is defective.
targetString: Adǝ ro nzǝra lan, waltǝm sango "NLRP3 inflammasome" tiyi batatsoye dǝ batti/cidajimba/faidajimba.

sourceString: By this reasoning, inhibition of NLRP3 inflammasome with MCC950 might be useful in the treatment of COVID-19.
targetString: Dalil adǝ futa men, MCC950 lan "NLRP3 inflammasome" daptǝ dǝ waniye kurun COVID-19ye dio ro faidajin.

sourceString: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 follows the general theme by which SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV arose.
targetString: Fǝlangtǝ au luwo SARS-CoV-2be dǝ duluwu fal do SARS-CoV-a MERS-Cov-a cizana dǝ zǝgayin.

sourceString: Whereas a bat beta-CoV sharing 95% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV has been found, there also exists a bat-CoV sharing 96% nucleotide homology with SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Beta-CoV batatabe dǝ ci 95% "nucleotide homology"nzabe SARS-CoV'a jili fal faidatayin, kuru adgaima CoV-batatabe do ci 96% "nucleotide homology"nzabe SARS-CoV-2'a tilo.

sourceString: Whereas civets and other animals in the markets have been found to harbour viruses identical to SARS-CoV, immediate intermediate hosts for SARS-CoV-2 have not been identified.
targetString: Dabba shiro 'civet' sayin dǝ-a dabbawa gade so'a suro kasuwube dǝn sandiya tuwandǝna kuliwa kwasabe SARS-CoV'a samun tiyinzan mbeji gozana fomzain, sototǝma dawube tinibe SARS-CoV-2 be dǝ kǝrmaaro fodutǝnyi.

sourceString: Pangolin beta-CoVs strikingly homologous to SARS-CoV-2 have been found, indicating that pangolins might serve as one of intermediate hosts or pangolin beta-CoVs could contribute gene fragments to the final version of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Beta-CoVwa 'pangolin'be zauro SARS-CoV-2'a "homologous" tuwandǝna, daji adǝye fǝlejin 'pangolin' dǝ naptǝ sosotǝma dawube ro waljin au beta-CoVwa 'pangolin'be dǝ raksǝ waniye awo shiro "gene fragments" sayin dǝ kaanzǝwu cin jili SARS-CoV-2ye darebe dǝ ro.

sourceString: Although questions remain, there is no evidence that SARS-CoV-2 is man-made either deliberately or accidentally.
targetString: Korowa kuwa yaye mbeji yaye, shada do SARS-CoV-2 dǝ adammana sǝtandǝbe dǝ ba wo, walau nadibe ro au tajirwa men.

sourceString: CoVs have returned to the limelight due to the recent outbreak of SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: CoVwa so dǝ ba isa noata ro walzana dalil fǝlangtǝ SARS-CoV-2 karungube dǝ ro.

sourceString: The study of CoVs in bats and other animals has drastically changed our perception of the importance of zoonotic origins and animal reservoirs of HCoVs in human transmission.
targetString: Kǝra au kulashi kǝla CoVwa batatabe-a dabbawa gadebe-a tǝdǝna dǝye notǝnde kǝla faidawa badiyaram kwasawa tartǝyin au faltǝyinbe-a kuru guwom au tankiwa HCoVwa be-a tiyi adammana soyen tartǝgǝnzǝ falzǝna.

sourceString: Pervasive evidence has shown that SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 have a bat origin and are transmitted to humans via intermediate hosts.
targetString: Dalilla dunowabeye fǝlezana SARS-CoV-a, MERS-CoV-a, SARS-CoV-2-a samma so badiyaramnza batatabe mbeji kuru adammana ro falzayin sototǝma dawube men.

sourceString: Given that SARS-CoV infection originates from the contact between humans and civets in the markets, closing wet markets and killing civets therein could have effectively ended the SARS epidemic.
targetString: Nǝm dondi au kwasa SARS-CoVye dǝ kǝltǝ ndikate adammanbe-a civetwa kasuwubeye soye men ciyono daa, kasuwuwa dabbawabe dǝ zaktǝ-a civetwa ronza ro yezo-a dǝ wawa SARSbe dǝ tamozǝyin.

sourceString: By the same reasoning, pangolins should be removed from wet markets to prevent zoonotic transmission, in view of the discovery of multiple lineages of pangolin beta-CoVs closely related to SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Dalil caye dǝ men, 'pangolin' soye kasuwu dabbawabe dǝn ba ro tǝdin tartǝgǝ tiyi dabbawaye men kaltǝgǝ nankaro, jiliwa beta-CoVwa pangolinbe kada SARS-CoV-2'a leyata fodutǝna nanka dǝ ro.

sourceString: However, whether and how SARS-CoV-2 is transmitted to humans through pangolins and other mammals remain to be clarified in future investigations.
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 adammana ro pangolin men faltǝin la faltǝimba kuru futu wi men faltǝin dǝ kulashiwa fuwu lan tǝdin lan asutin.

sourceString: On the other hand, MERS-CoV has existed in dromedary camels for a long time.
targetString: Mukko fallan, MERS-CoV dǝ tiyi kalimowabe lan loktu kuruwu ro dǝgana.

sourceString: These camels serve as an important tool for transportation as well as a main source of meat, milk, leather and wool products for the local people.
targetString: Kalimowa anyi nasha lenǝm areyen zauro faidazayin, kuru sandi futa men da-a, cam-a, karai-a, kuru kunduli-a tuwandin am fato'be ro.

sourceString: They are widely distributed across the Middle East and Africa.
targetString: Sandi kalimowa so dǝ Gǝdi dawube-a Africa-a lan zauro ngǝwu.

sourceString: It is therefore impossible to sacrifice all camels for the control of MERS, as what was done in wild animal markets in China to prevent the spreading of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2.
targetString: Advye sǝkkǝ kalimowa samma so MERS kaltǝgǝ nanka ro yezo dǝ mowonjimba, futu dabbawa karaabe ro kasuwuwa Chinabe lan tǝdǝna dǝ yeyi, tartǝgǝ SARS-CoV-a SARS-CoV-2be-a kaltugǝ nanka ro.

sourceString: To stop the recurrent outbreaks of MERS, a comprehensive approach should be taken to develop effective vaccines against MERS-CoV for camels, in combination with other infection control measures.
targetString: Fǝlangtǝ MERSbe gade dabtǝ nankaro, duluwu kǝske do shi futa men kalimi MERS-coVbe kalimowa ro tando nankaro gotǝna ma ngǝla wo, katapwa gade tartǝgǝ kuli kwasabe daptǝye gotǝn kunten.

sourceString: As we are not able to eliminate these viruses, new genotypes might emerge to cause outbreaks.
targetString: Kuliwa kwasabe anyi ba ro dio andero tiyerǝna daa, jiliwa gade waniye solu fǝlangtǝ sawudin.

sourceString: A variety of zoonotic CoVs are circulating in the wild.
targetString: Jiliwa CoV soye raksa kwasa sawudin ma kada karaa lan fomzayin.

sourceString: Particularly, bat CoVs with zoonotic potential are so diverse.
targetString: Taganas ma ro, CoVwa batatabe so do raksa kwasa au nǝm dondi sawudin so dǝ jilinza ngǝwu.

sourceString: There are plenty of opportunities that these zoonotic CoVs evolve and recombine, resulting in the emergence of new CoVs that are more transmissible and/or deadly in humans in future.
targetString: Duluwuwa kada mbeji sandi men CoVwa kwasa au nǝm dondi sawudin anyiye fǝlamza kuru walta kǝltayin ma, adǝgayin men CoVwa bǝlin do zauro faltǝyin ma kuru/au kǝrmu adammana so ro sawudin ma fuwu lan soluyin.

sourceString: The culture of eating wild animals in some places of China should be abandoned to reduce unnecessary contact between humans and animals.
targetString: Ada dabbawa karaaye gǝrobe na'a laa Chinabe lan tǝdin dǝ koltǝna ma ngǝla wo, kǝla kǝlta au mu'amala ndikate adammana so dabbawa so-a ye mǝradǝtǝnyi fulutǝ nankaro.

sourceString: With the ordeals of SARS, MERS and COVID-19, a better preparedness and response plan should be in place.
targetString: Awowa SARS-a, MERS-a, COVID-19-a futa men turuna dǝye sǝkkǝ, dawari ngǝla-a kuru fasal katap goabe-a ngalwo-a gǝnaata mbeji ma ngǝla wo.

sourceString: In fact, many viruses have existed in the planet for a very long time.
targetString: Tawadǝ ro, kuliwa kwasa sawudin kada dunya lan loktu kuruwu ro kasharu.

sourceString: They stay in their own natural reservoirs until there is a chance for spillover.
targetString: Guwom au tankinza alameye lan kasharu adǝgai do hatta duluwu awo laa gadero cambaltǝm kotabe sowandayin.

sourceString: Although bats have many features that favours the spreading of viruses, the chance for humans to be in contact with bats and other wildlife species can be minimized if people are educated to stay away from them.
targetString: Batata so dǝ hallanzaa kada tartǝgǝ kuliwa kwasabe banazǝyin ma mbeji yaye, duluwu adammana soye batataso dabbawa karaaye gadeso-a letayin dǝ gana ro tǝdǝ kuru am soye kǝla fatǝgǝ sandiro cintuza.

sourceString: Continuous surveillance in mammals is necessary for better understanding of the ecology of CoVs and their natural hosts, which will prove useful in preventing animal-to-human transmission and future outbreaks.
targetString: Dabbawa so ro sambi so ro shim ikko dǝ mbu ro walzǝna na CoV so kǝnǝngatayin-a kuru sototǝmanza alameye au karaaye so asutǝ ngǝla fando ro, adǝye faidajin nasha faltǝgǝ ndikate dabba-a adammana-aye kaltǝgǝ-a kuru fuwu lan fǝlangtǝ kaltǝgǝ-a ro.

sourceString: To conclude, the most effective way to prevent viral zoonosis is for humans to stay away from the ecological niches of the natural reservoirs of the zoonotic viruses.
targetString: Tamotǝram lan, duluwu do zauro "viral zoonosis" (kuli kwasabe dabba futamen gotǝ) kaltǝyin dǝ shima adammana soye na'a guwomwa au tankiwa kuliwa kwasa sawudin anyiye ro cintutǝ dǝ.

sourceString: Several pieces in the puzzle of the zoonotic origin of SARS-CoV-2 are still missing.
targetString: Awowa sǝnana do badiyaram SARS-CoV-2be fǝlejin dǝ kuwayaye ba.

sourceString: First, if bats transmit an ancestral virus of SARS-CoV-2 to pangolins, it will be of interest to see under what circumstances bats and pangolins could share the same ecological niche.
targetString: Kǝn fal me dǝ, batata so dǝ kuli kwasabe SARS-CoV-2be din pangolin so ro falzayin maa, awo wutiya sandǝna dǝ shima kǝnda wi son batata so-a pangolin so-a ye na fallan kasharu.

sourceString: Second, if bats play a more direct role in human transmission, how humans get into contact with bats should be determined.
targetString: Kǝn indi me dǝ, batata so dǝ nasha adammana ro faltǝgǝben katap kura gowotsayin maa, futu adammana soye batata so-a letayin dǝ notǝna ma ngǝla wo.

sourceString: Third, if a third mammal acts as the true intermediate host, how it interacts with the different species including humans, bats and pangolins has to be clarified.
targetString: Kǝn yakkǝ me dǝ, dabba laa kǝn yakkǝ me shima sototǝ ma dawu be jirebeye mbeji maa, futu jiliwa gade-a letayin adammana-a, batata-a, pangolin-a kunten dǝ asutǝna ma ngǝla wo.

sourceString: Finally, since many mammals including domestic animals might be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, both surveillance and experimental infection should be conducted.
targetString: Dare datǝram lan, dabbawa kada hatta dabbawa fatoben kunten sandiya SARS-CoV-2ye mowonǝ sǝtayin daa, faltǝgǝ shim ikkobe-a dim kurube-a ndi so tǝdǝna ma ngǝla wo.

sourceString: Should it be a bat, a pangolin or another mammal, it is expected that SARS-CoV-2 or its parental viruses that are almost identical will be identified in its natural hosts in future.
targetString: Batata, pangolin, au dabba gade ro wallono maa, SARS-CoV-2 au kuli kwasabe sha sambǝna ma do sandi zauro samun dǝ mowonzǝ fuwulan sototǝmanzǝye tiyi lan fodutin ro tǝma'ata.

sourceString: Continued investigations in this area will elucidate the evolutionary pathway of SARS-CoV-2 in animals, with important implications in the prevention and control of COVID-19 in humans.
targetString: Kulashiwa lejin ma do nasha adǝlan tǝdinye zawal fǝlamtǝ SARS-CoV-2ye tiyi dabbawabe dǝ raksǝ sutuluyin, dalilla faidajin nasha COVID-19 tiyi adammana soyen fautǝ-a kaltǝgǝ-a kunte.

sourceString: Updating the diagnostic criteria of COVID-19 “suspected case” and “confirmed case” is necessary
targetString: Kaida kulashi kǝla COVID-19 ye dǝga bǝlintǝgǝ dǝ "kwasa tǝmatǝgǝna ma"-a "kwasa tawatkata ma"-a ye dǝ zauro faida

sourceString: On 6 February 2020, our team had published a rapid advice guideline for diagnosis and treatment of 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection, and this guideline provided our experience and make well reference for fighting against this pandemic worldwide.
targetString: Yim 6 February 2020, cidawu de ye kashimo shawari ye kulashi-a kurun diwo-a ye kǝla koronabairos bǝlin 2019 ye (2019-CoV) ye tartǝgǝ nzǝ ye dǝn lǝbsana, kuru kashimo adǝ ye ilmu nde-a nzukolto kǝla futu kwasa dinaye adǝga dina samman kǝriwtǝye cina.

sourceString: However, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge are gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, kwasa koronabairos 2019 (COVID-19) ye dǝ kwasa dǝwo bǝlin, kǝla fatǝnde-a ilmunde-a dǝ gana ganan tǝrain lǝatar kulashi kǝrmaro tǝdin-a ilmu cida liyitariye-a men, adǝ nankaro, katabwa kulashi-a kurun diwo-a ye so dǝ ye sambiso ro fafaltin.

sourceString: In this letter, we answered one comment on our guideline and provided the newest diagnostic criteria of “suspected case” and “confirmed case” according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (seventh version) that issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China.
targetString: Suro watiya adǝyen, jawawu koro la kǝla kashimo ndeyen yiyena, kuru kaidawa bǝlin kǝla kulashi liyitariye kǝla "kwasa tǝmatǝgǝna"-a "kwasa tawatkata"-a ye dǝn yiyena lǝatar kulashi-a kurun diwo-a bǝlin yen kǝla COVID-19 ye dǝn COVID-19 (seventh version) shi dǝwo ne Komiti Nǝlefa lardǝye lardǝ China ye cina ma dǝ.

sourceString: In December 2019, the 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) has caused an outbreak, which is now officially named as the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and the virus has been named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
targetString: Suro December 2019 yen, kwasa coronavirusye bǝlin 2019 ye (2019-nCoV) dǝ yt sǝkǝ falangtǝ wazǝna, shi dǝwo ne kǝrmaro maila ro sha kwasa koronabairos ye 2019 (COVID-19) lan buwotin dǝ kuru kuli kwasabe dǝ sha kwasa yintǝye zauro zaw coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) lan buwotin.

sourceString: On 11 March 2020, WHO characterized COVID-19 as a pandemic.
targetString: Yim 11 March 2020, WHO ye COVID-19 dǝga kwasa dinaye ro mawwono.

sourceString: In order to fight against the SARS-CoV-2 infection, our team has developed a rapid advice guideline and that has been published online in Military Medical Research on 06 February 2020.
targetString: Tartǝgǝ SARS-CoV-2 ye dǝ fulutǝ ro, cidawu nde ye kashimo shawari ye nagaduye satandana kuru shi dǝwo ne onlayin lan lǝbsana suro kulashi kurun matǝye askǝrra ye dǝn yim 06 February 2020.

sourceString: It has attracted a great attention since published.
targetString: Kawu lǝbtǝna wo so zauro hangal jamaye gǝrzǝna.

sourceString: Note however that COVID-19 is a new disease, our awareness and knowledge is gradually increasing based on the ongoing research findings and clinical practice experience; hence, the strategies of diagnosis and treatment are also continually updated.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma hangal gǝnatǝ, kǝla COVID-19 dǝ kwasa bǝlin yen, kǝla fatǝnde-a ilmunde-a dǝ gana ganan tǝrain lǝatar kulashi kǝrmaro tǝdin-a ilmu cida liyitariye-a, adǝ nankaro katabwa kulashi-a kurun diwo-a ye so dǝ sambiso ro bǝlintǝyin.

sourceString: For instance the Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 issued by the National Health Committee of the People’s Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), among 16 January 2020 to 3 March 2020, has issued a total of seven editions with some contexts being substantively changed.
targetString: Misallo kashimo kulashi-a kurun diwo-a ye kǝla COVID-19 yen dǝwo Komiti Nǝlefa lardǝye lardǝ China ye sutuluwuna dǝ (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/), dawu 16 January 2020 lan sǝta 3 March 2020 ro suwudǝna ǝn, adadu jumla lǝbtǝ kashi tulur ye sutuluwuna kalmawa la faltǝna ro.

sourceString: Now our guideline received a comment by Zhou et al., they introduced a simple scoring proposal based on their clinical experience.
targetString: Kǝrma dǝ kashimo ndǝ ye kǝla dǝn Zhou et al. So ye manazana, sandiye shawari bu gotǝna dǝ ye darajanzǝ asutaye saudǝ lǝatar ilmunza liyitaye ro.

sourceString: Their work added new evidence for our guideline and also make valuable reference for this pandemic worldwide.
targetString: Cidanza dǝ ye kashimo nde dǝro hujja serana kuru nzukolto faida kǝla kwasa dinaye dǝro dina samma so ro sǝdǝna.

sourceString: We endorse their significant work and express our thanks.
targetString: Ande ye chidanza taida dǝga ardinyena kuru askǝrande fǝlenyena.

sourceString: However, their work also needs update according to the latest Diagnosis and Treatment Guidelines for COVID-19 (Trial seventh version) and recently studies.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, cidanza dǝ ye bǝlintǝgǝ mǝradǝzǝna futu kulashi bǝlin-a kurun diwo-a kǝla COVID-19 (Trial seventh version) dǝ ye fǝlezǝna dǝyeyi kuru nazaruwa bǝlin-a

sourceString: According to the seventh edition (3 March 2020), to confirm the suspected case needs to combine any one item of epidemiological history features with two items of clinical manifestations to make a comprehensive analysis, or needs to meet three items of clinical manifestations if without clear epidemiological history:
targetString: Bakta kǝntulur (3 March 2020) ye fǝlezǝnadǝ yeyi, kwasa tǝmata dǝ tawattǝgǝ ro awowa ilmu kwasa tartǝgǝyin ye falnzǝ tuskatǝyin rokko dǝn awowa ndi sheda liyitaye-a bayan ilmu kwasa tartǝgǝyin ye dǝ baro walwono wa:

sourceString: Epidemiological history: (1) a history of travel or residence in Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 cases had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (2) a history of contact with SARS-CoV-2 infectious cases (with positive nucleic acid test); (3) a history of contacting with patients with fever or respiratory symptoms from Wuhan city and surrounding areas, or other communities where COVID-19 had been reported in the last 14 days before symptom onset; (4) a history of contacting with cluster of confirmed cases (≥ 2 cases with fever and/or respiratory symptoms occurred within 2 weeks in small areas, such as home, office, class of school, etc).
targetString: Bayan Nzundu Kwasa Tartǝgǝyin ye : (1) bayan bǝrni Wuhan ye ro bǝlaro tǝna ye-a nabtǝna ye-a kuru bǝlamashi nzǝ-a ye, aw ngurowa gade COVID-19 fǝlangzǝna so-a suro kawu 14 kozǝna dǝ yen kawu alama kwasabe dǝ buro hawal yin badizana dǝn, (2) bayan kǝla kwasawa tartǝgǝyin ma SARS-CoV-2 ye ro letǝgǝye (with positive nucleic acid test); (ǝ) bayan kǝla kam kange aw kwasa yintǝye alama fǝlezǝna-a ro letǝgǝna bǝrni Wuhan-a mashinzǝ-a lan, aw ngurowa gade dǝwo kwasa COVID-19 ye falangzǝna suro kawu 14 yen tǝn kawu bǝro hawal alama dǝ badizana yen,   (4) bayan kǝla am tawadǝro kwasa dǝ ye sǝtana ro letǝgǝnaye (≥ 2 kwasawa kange ya kǝllatǝ kuru/aw alama kwasa yintǝ ye suro mawu 2 yen fǝlezǝna ma gana lan, alam foto, cidaram, aji muwontiye, gade gabsǝna-a).

sourceString: Clinical manifestations: (1) fever and/ or respiratory symptoms; (2) with imaging features of COVID-19 infection; (3) total white blood cell counts showing normal, decreased, or reduced lymphocyte count in the early onset stage.
targetString: Alamawa liyitari Turin: (1) kange-a/aw Alamawa yintǝye; (2) foto alamawa COVID-19 ye sǝtana ye; (ǝ) adadu jumla bu dǝwo shiro white blood cell gultin dǝ ye dǝ kalkal, fulutǝna, aw adadu or reduced lymphocyte ye dǝ loktu badiyaram dǝ man ganazǝna.

sourceString: Diagnosing the confirmed case should base on suspected case with any one item of pathogenic or serological evidence as following: (1) real-time PCR test positive for SARS-CoV-2; (2) viral whole genome sequencing showing high homogeneity to the known novel coronaviruses; (3) positive for the specific IgM antibody and IgG antibody to SARS-CoV-2 in serum test; or a change of the SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG antibody from negative to positive, or titer rising ≥4 times in the recovery phase above that in the acute phase.
targetString: Kwasa tawatkata kulastǝ dǝ lǝatar kwasa tǝmata ye dǝwo awowa adǝ ye falnza sheda kwasa y-a aw ngaltǝ buye-a futu adǝ yeyi ro: (1) real-time PCR test dǝ SARS-CoV-2 mbeji ro fǝlezǝna; (2) viral whole genome sequencing dǝ zauro kwasa bǝlin koronabairos samǝn ro fǝlejin (ǝ) positive for the specific IgM antibody dǝ mbeji kuru IgG antibody to SARS-CoV-2 ye suro serum test yen mbeji; aw  SARS-CoV-2-specific IgG antibody dǝ ye ba lan faltǝ mbeji ro waltǝ, aw titer dǝ habtin gade gade ≥4 ro suro kashi ngatǝ ye dǝn kashi zauro zawye dǝga kozǝna ro.

sourceString: We can see that the real-time PCR test for nucleic acid in respiratory tract or blood samples was added to the second (18 January 2020) and third (22 January 2020) editions.
targetString: Rangnye ruyen futu real-time PCR test nucleic acid ye dǝ suro yintǝram aw bu gotǝna dǝ ye dǝ lǝbtǝ kǝn ndimi ye dǝro tǝrana (18 January 2020)-a kǝn yakkǝmi (22 January 2020) -a so ro.

sourceString: The pathogenic detection of blood sample was added to the fourth (27 January 2020) and fifth (8 February 2020) editions; and then the serological evidence was added to the seventh edition.
targetString: Bu gotǝmen kwasa asuta dǝ lǝbtǝ kǝn diyewmi dǝro tǝrana (27 January 2020)-a kǝn uwumi (8 February 2020)-a; kuru daji Hujjawa bu ngaltǝ ye dǝ lǝbtǝ kǝn tulurmi dǝ ro tǝra.

sourceString: These modifications based on the researchers continued work that to search for an optimal nucleic acid detection kit for rapid diagnosis, as well as the samples from respiratory tract including blood sampling, which increased the availability of different specimens, and supported bringing the specific antibody positive result into the confirmed criteria.
targetString: Nzunduwa adǝ lǝatar kulashi ma so dǝye kasadǝnza lan kǝla optimal nucleic acid detection kit dǝga kulastǝ dǝ nagaduro kulastǝ ro, kuru man galtǝ yintǝram-a buye-a son, shi dǝwo ne awo ngaltǝye gade mbeji ro sǝdǝna ma, kuru balimi kwasa kǝriwtǝye tiyi ye mbeji ma dǝ kaida tawatkata ye dǝro kudo dǝ kasadsǝna ma dǝ.

sourceString: Besides, there are more and more evidence that remind us to caution with the atypical symptomatic and asymptomatic patients.
targetString: Ngawo adǝyen, shaidawa kada mbeji andero taksǝyin kǝla am dondi dǝwo alama fǝlezain-a fǝlezainmba-a so dǝro hangal gǝnatǝ ro.

sourceString: Hence, the flow chart of Zhou et al. should be updated, as they classified the person without clinical symptoms as “low risk”.
targetString: Adǝ nankadǝro, flow chart of Zhou et al. so yedǝ bǝlintǝgǝ, dalil dǝ sandiye kam dǝwo alamawa liyitarin asutin ye Shi lan ba dǝga "tajirwa gana" ro kamza kolzana dǝro.

sourceString: The score system also needs to be verified in further clinical practice and studies.
targetString: Fasal daraja yoye dǝ ye mǝradǝ kulastǝ ye mbeji cida liyitariye-a nazaru fuye-a lan.

sourceString: To conclude, we hope more direct evidence coming up and call for readers to provide their comments.
targetString: Dare daji la men, shaidawa kǝla tilowa ro gade nguwu isayin ro tǝmanyena kuru kǝratuwu so wa buwonyena bayan nguwu ro sadǝ ro.

sourceString: For the diagnosis of “suspected case” and “confirmed case”, we suggest to trace and obey the newest guidelines of their home countries.
targetString: Kulashi "kwasa tǝmata"-a "kwasa tawatkata" dǝro ande ye shawari ya ceye kǝla sursuri bǝlin ma lardǝnzaye dǝga zasa ro.

sourceString: Our team will also timely update our guideline to offer help.
targetString: Cidawu ndeye kǝla kǝlan bayan sadin kǝla kashimo nde yen bana diwo nankaro.

sourceString: Bangladesh reports five new deaths due to COVID-19, a daily highest
targetString: Bangladesh lan am uwu bǝlin ro COVID-19 ye cezo,  shima yimwisowa nǝmnguwu lan kozǝna wo.

sourceString: Yesterday, Bangladesh has confirmed five new deaths due to COVID-19 on the day.
targetString: Biska ro, Bangladeshye kǝla am uwu bǝlin COVID-19 ye yim dǝn cezǝna ye tawatsǝna.

sourceString: This is the highest number of fatalities in a day due to the virus.
targetString: Adǝ shima adadu dǝwo am kuli kwasabe dǝ ye cezǝna nǝm nguwu nzǝ samma so wa kozǝna wo.

sourceString: As of yesterday, Bangladesh's Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) reported the number of recorded infected cases included 114 active cases and 33 recovered cases who were staying home.
targetString: Biska ro, Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research (IEDCR) Bangladeshyedǝ ye hawar kǝla adadu am zamtǝna dǝwo babro tǝkǝnaye dǝ suro dǝn 114 dǝ kǝrmaro dondi kuru 33 dǝ ngazana dǝwo faton namzana ma ro cina.

sourceString: A total of 17 deaths have been recorded.
targetString: Jumla am 17 bazana ye tuwondǝna.

sourceString: In an online news briefing, the director of IEDCR, Dr Meerjady Sabrina Flora, said the fatalities included four males and one female.
targetString: Suro bayan harwa ye onlayin lan tǝdǝna la lan, director IEDCR ye, Dr Meerjady Sabrina Flora, ye wono am bazana dǝ suro nzan kongaa diyew-a kamu fal-a wono.

sourceString: According to Dr Meerjady, two cases were aged above 60, two between 51 and 60, and one 41-50 years old.
targetString: Dr Meerjady ye gultǝnzǝ lan, am dondi ndi dǝ saanza 60 samin, ndi kate kate 51 -a 60-a, kuru fal dǝ kate kate 41-a 50-a yen.

sourceString: She also said two of the victims were from Dhaka.
targetString: Shi kuru waltǝ wono am ndi zamtǝna dǝ Dhaka lan kesho wono.

sourceString: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared COVID-19 a pandemic on March 11.
targetString: World Health Organization (WHO) ye COVID-19 dǝ kwasa dinaye ro mawwono yim March 11.

sourceString: A hospital official told Anadolu Agency, a local news outlet, that one of the deceased was Jalal Saifur Rahman, a director of Bengali Anti-Corruption Commission, who was cared for at the Kuwait Maitree Hospital.
targetString: Cidama liyitariye la ye cidaram Anadolu Agency ro gulzǝna, fato hawarwaye suro lardǝye ma la, kǝla kam fal bazǝna ma dǝ shima Jalal Saifur Rahman, director Bengali Anti-Corruption Commission ye, shi dǝwo ne shiro Kuwait Maitree Hospital lan cistuwuna dǝ.

sourceString: On Saturday, in an online video announcement, Bangladeshi Road Transport and Bridges Minister Obaidul Quader said public transport would be shut down for longer than initially planned, until this coming Saturday.
targetString: Yim Sǝbduwa, mawutǝ la bidiyoye onlayin yen, Bangladeshi ye ministanzǝ awowa kǝmbaye-a Malingo-a so ye Obaidul Quader dǝ ye wono awowa kǝmbaye so zaktin loktu kuruwu ro futu buron nyatǝna dǝma wa kozǝna ro, sai sǝbdǝ fuwuye ishin adǝga duwo.

sourceString: This public transport shutdown had initially started on March 26 and was planned to end on Saturday, April 4.
targetString: Awowa kǝmbaye saktǝ adǝma dǝ buron yim March 26 badiyetǝ kuru yim Sǝbdǝwa April 4 lan dajin ro dawarratǝ.

sourceString: Transport of essential goods -- medical, fuel and food -- was still allowed.
targetString: Karaiyya faidatǝnza mbu so --kurun, kǝndawu-a kǝmbu-a --so dǝ awowa kǝmbaye lan gotǝnza amarrata.

sourceString: The first recorded incidents of COVID-19 infection in Bangladesh were on March 8, in two people who returned from Italy and also the wife of one of them.
targetString: COVID-19 ye zamtǝnzǝ buro hawal ye Bangladesh lan tuwondǝna dǝ shima yim March 8, na am indi dǝwo Italy lan waltana yen, kuru man kamu falnza ye-a lan.

sourceString: As of March 19, these three had already recovered.
targetString: Yim March 19, dǝn sandi yakkǝ adǝ sammaso ngazana.

sourceString: SARS-CoV-2 surpasses one million infections worldwide
targetString: SARS-CoV-2 dǝ am miliyon falyin samin zamzǝna dina samma son.

sourceString: On Thursday, the total number of cases of the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infections surpassed one million worldwide, Johns Hopkins University data indicated.
targetString: Yim Lamisuwa, jumla am SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus ye zamzǝna dǝ miliyon falla kozǝna dina samma son, bayanna Johns Hopkins University ye dǝye fǝlezǝna.

sourceString: At least 52 thousand deaths were linked to COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus.
targetString: Alama kǝrmu duwu 52 ye dǝyeyi COVID-19 ro leyata, kwasa dǝwo coronavirusye suwudǝna ma dǝ.

sourceString: The milestone came the same day Malawi confirmed its first coronavirus infections and Zambia had its first coronavirus-related death.
targetString: Adadu kura adǝ wawono kalkal yim Malawi ye kam buro hawal ro koronabairos ye zamzǝna tawatsǝna dǝn kuro Zambia ye kam buro hawal yin coronavirus ye cezǝna yen.

sourceString: North Korea claimed, as of Thursday, it was one of the few countries remaining free of coronavirus infections.
targetString: North Korea ye wono, Lamisua lan, shi dǝ suro lardǝwa gabsǝna gana dǝwo kwasa coronavirus dǝ ye zamzǝnyi so dǝ yen wono.

sourceString: By yesterday, the World Health Organization reported 1,051,635 confirmed cases, including 79,332 cases in the twenty four hours preceding 10 a.m. Central European Time (0800 UTC) on April 4.
targetString: Biska ro, World Health Organization ye rifot am 1,051,635 tawadǝro kwasa dǝ ye zamzǝna ye cina, suro dǝn am 79, 332 suro awa findi diyeri yen ngawo sa 10 a.m. Central European Time (0800 UTC) on April 4 yen.

sourceString: In the United States, over 244 thousand coronavirus cases were recorded, linking to at least 5,900 deaths.
targetString: Suro United States yen, am duwu 244 samin coronavirus ye zamzǝna tuwondǝna, kǝrmu alama 5,900 yeyi ro fǝraksǝna.

sourceString: CBS News reported, citing Johns Hopkins University data, there were over 1,000 US deaths on Wednesday caused by coronavirus infections.
targetString: CBS News ye hawar cina, bayanna Johns Hopkins University lan hujja koktǝ men, am 1,000 samin US ye bazana yim Larafawa dalil coronavirus yen.

sourceString: Around the world, countries announced stricter measures to inhibit the disease from spreading.
targetString: Dina samma son, lardǝwa so ye katabwa zaw zaw mawuzana kwasa dega tartǝgǝ dabtǝ ro.

sourceString: On Thursday, Sergei Sobyanin, the mayor of Moscow, extended the city lockdown to May 1.
targetString: Yim Lamisuwa, Sergei Sobyanin, mayor Moscow ye dǝ ye, bǝrni dǝga zaktǝ dǝ gǝrzǝgǝ May 1 ro ciyado.

sourceString: Nationally, President Vladimir Putin declared Russians would continue to be paid without going to work until April 30.
targetString: Lardǝ dǝ samman, kura lardǝye Vladimir Putin ye mawuzǝna kǝla am Russia ye dǝ sandiya kawonza adutǝyin cida ro lezanyi yayi har April 30.

sourceString: The parliament of Portugal voted to extend the national state of emergency by 15 days; the vote passed with 215 votes in favor, ten abstentions, and one vote against.
targetString: Majiliswu Portugal ye karno sadǝna kǝla hal nabtǝ duwasashi ye dǝga kawu 15 ro yira ro; karno dǝ kuriya 215 lan kǝnasar cido kasadsana, meu dǝ kǝdǝk sadǝ, kuru fal dǝ kasadtǝro wano.

sourceString: Saudi Arabia extended curfews in the holy cities of Mecca and Medina to last the entire day; previously, the curfew was only in effect between 3 p.m. and 6 a.m.
targetString: Saudi Arabia ye howom fomtǝba ye dǝga bǝla Makka-a Madina-a ye dǝn gǝrzǝgǝ dubdo ro cado; burodǝn, howom fomtǝba ye kate kate 3 p.m.-a 6 a.m.-a yen.

sourceString: Thailand planned to implement a curfew between 10 p.m. and 4 a.m.
targetString: Thailand ye howom fomtǝba ye kate kate 10 p.m.-a 4 a.m.-a yen yiko ro nyazǝna.

sourceString: The governor of Ohio, Mike DeWine, announced the state had extended its stay-at-home order until May 1.
targetString: Gomna Ohio, Mike DeWine, dǝ ye mawuzǝna kǝla kǝrwe dǝ howomnzǝ faton naptә ye dǝ serana har sai May 1 ro.

sourceString: Stores in Australia lower toilet paper limits per transaction
targetString: Kantiwa Australia la dǝn kakkadi ngawdin faidatǝ ye dǝ liwaya wo son fuluzana.

sourceString: On Sunday and Saturday evening, Australian store chains Woolworths and Coles lowered their purchase restrictions on toilet paper to two and one package per transaction in all stores on national level, respectively.
targetString: Yim Ladǝ-a Sǝbdǝ-a kajiri, kantiya Australia ye chains Woolworths-a Coles-a kakkadi ngawdin faidatǝ ye dǝ yowonza fuluzana ndi-a fal-a ro liwaya wo son cedo kanti wo son lardǝ samma son.

sourceString: ALDI also introduced a one-pack limit, on Monday.
targetString: ALDI ye faket fal ro fuluzǝna, yim Litǝlinna.

sourceString: These limitations were posted as messages on the checkouts, and on the chains' Facebook pages.
targetString: Fulutǝ adǝ so dǝ tiyi garu so bakkata, kuru Facebook chain ye-a son.

sourceString: Buyers were reportedly stocking up due to fears of COVID-19 in case people need to self-isolate.
targetString: Liwayawu so dǝ fitana cesuwin ritǝ COVID-19 ye ro waneye mǝradǝ kǝla kortǝ ye la sandiya suwondin wa ro.

sourceString: On Wednesday, Woolworths also limited toilet paper purchases for home delivery to one pack per order.
targetString: Yim Larafawa, Woolworths ye kakkadi ngawdin faidatǝ ye dǝ lodo fuluzǝna am faton faidatain so ro faket fal luwaya wo son ro.

sourceString: These changes followed the previous four-pack per transaction restriction introduced by Woolworths and Coles on March 4 and 5 respectively.
targetString: Faltǝ adǝ ngawo buron faket diyew luwaya wo son ye zǝa shi dǝwo Woolworths-a Coles-a ye yii March 4-a 5-a lan badizana dǝ.

sourceString: Coles, in its March 8 media release, reported that with the four-pack restriction in place, "many stores are still selling out within an hour of delivery", and called the demand "unprecedented", while ALDI, in a Facebook post on Tuesday, called it "unexpected".
targetString: Coles, suro jawawnzǝ Hawarwu in its March 8 cin la dǝn, wono dabtǝ faket diyewa kojimba ye dǝ man "kantiwa so dǝ kariy suwondaiyya suro awa fal yen solodǝ dajin", kuru mǝradǝ dǝga "tǝmatǝnyi" lan buwono, kuru ALDI ye, suro tartǝgǝnzǝ Facebook yǝ lan yim Talawwa ye dǝn, sha "tǝmatǝnyi" lan buwono.

sourceString: Sales went up in a "sharp increase" last week, according to a Woolworths spokesperson.
targetString: Luwaya dǝ "taidaze tǝrana" mawu kozǝna dǝn, futu cina Woolworths ye dǝ yayi.

sourceString: Costco's store in Canberra also limited the allowed amount to two packs last week.
targetString: Costco's store ye Canberra lan adadu amartǝna dǝga fuluzǝ faket ndi ro cido mawu kozǝna dǝn.

sourceString: To further alleviate the shortage, Coles ordered bigger packages from suppliers and increased delivery frequency, Woolworths ordered extra stock, while ALDI made stocks for a planned Wednesday special available early.
targetString: Kǝzǝbkǝ ba dǝ fultu ro, Coles ye faket kura kura mazǝna kuru nǝm nguwu kudoye dǝ sǝrana, Woolworths ye karaiyya nguwu ro mazǝna, kuru while ALDI ye karaiyya Larafa ro dawartǝna dǝ daten suwudǝna.

sourceString: Russell Zimmerman, executive director of the Australian Retailers Association, said that retailers try to raise stock, but local council restrictions on the timing of truck-deliveries make it hard.
targetString: Russell Zimmerman, executive director of the Australian Retailers Association dǝye, wono am kasuwu sǝnana so dǝ karaiyya nguwu ro yira badizana, amma howomwa huma gana do ye dǝ kǝla loktu motowa so ye karaiyya saudin dǝn ye dǝ sha zauro dǝdǝ.

sourceString: He expects rising production costs, as suppliers try to meet demand, and fewer specials.
targetString: Shi ye tǝmazǝna taman tando ye dǝ tǝrain ro, futu kudoma so ye mǝradǝga galzayin dǝ yeyi.

sourceString: On Tuesday, ALDI announced that following the early release of stock, some stores can't run the Wednesday special.
targetString: Yim Talawwa, ALDI ye wurmazǝna kǝla ngawo daten karaiyya koltǝna dǝyeyi, kantiwa la su dǝ kasuwu Wednesday social ye dǝ zawin ba.

sourceString: In a News.com.au report, Dr Gary Mortimer, retail expert from Queensland University of Technology, said the stores fill the stock every night.
targetString: Suro rifot la News.com.au yen, Dr Gary Mortimer, gurdoma masku Queensland University of Technology ye, wono kantiwa fǝ karaiyyan kek sambuyin bune wo son.

sourceString: He remarked toilet paper is a bulky item, leading to low quantity of stocks in numbers, and, when sold out, leaves vast shelf spaces empty, hardening the feeling of a shortage.
targetString: Shi wono kakkadiwa ngawdin faidatǝ ye dǝ zauro kura, adadu karaiyya ye dǝga fulujin, kuru sa tulodiya, na kura la suro kanti dǝ yen kulǝ koljin, nǝm karaiyya ba ye fantǝ dǝga sǝrayin.

sourceString: "Coles and Woolworths have a view [that] if there was plenty of stuff on the shelf, if product like toilet rolls and sanitiser could be [bought] and are there in quantities, you would probably minimise the panic" said Russell Zimmerman per ABC News.
targetString: Coles-a Woolworths-a ye kuru nzan [wada] na gǝbatǝram dǝn karaiyya nguwu mbeji wa, kakkadi ngawdin faidatǝ ye so shawul musko tultaye so [cesuyiyya] kuru mbeji ma, rangnǝm karuwu kam dǝga fulunǝmin wono Russell Zimmerman per ABC News ye.

sourceString: Recycled toilet paper producer Who Gives a Crap said on last Wednesday they'd run out of stock.
targetString: Kam la kakkadi ngawdin faidatǝ ye dina gonǝm bǝlin tando ma ye Larafa kozǝna dǝga wono karaiyya nza dajin wono.

sourceString: Kimberly-Clark, which makes Kleenex Toilet Tissue, and Solaris Paper which makes Sorbent, emphasized they were working 24/7 to maintain the supply, according to the News.com.au report.
targetString: Kimberly-Clark, shi dǝwo Kleenex Toilet Tissue sǝtandin dǝ, kuru Solaris Paper-a Shi dǝwo Sorbent sǝdin dǝ, sandi ye wada 24/7 ro cidazain karaiy dǝ wande kamzǝnyi ro, futu rifot News.com.au yen isǝna dǝ yeyi.

sourceString: Domain.com, a real estate site, reported some property sellers offering free toilet paper to the first bidder on auctions in Melbourne, when fewer auctions were held because of buyers having time off on the long weekend of Labour Day.
targetString: Domain.com, a real estate site, ye rifot cina kǝla am gar lodoma la so ye am ro kakkadi ngawdin faidatǝ ye dǝ dero sadin kam buro hawal yin yiwo badizana dǝro suro Melbourne yen, sa luwaya gana ro waljiya sawo yiwo ma so dǝ batalla lan dare mawye kurùwu lan.

sourceString: The Thursday edition of NT News, a daily printed in Darwin, included an eight-page insert meant to be cut up and used as toilet paper.
targetString: Lǝbtǝ Lamisuye NT News ye dǝn, jerida la kullumye suro Darwin yen, suro dǝro ruwo la felle wuskuwa kǝlzǝgǝna sha kamtǝ kakkadi ngawdin faidatǝ ye ro faidatǝ ro.

sourceString: The stores were originally reluctant to impose restrictions, according to a report from ABC Australia on March 3 in which they said they had no plans to introduce restrictions on the purchases.
targetString: Kantiwa dǝ buron kal yiko dǝ saranyi, futu hawar la ABC Australia yen yim March 3 tuwondǝna dǝyeyi sandiye nyanza luwaya dǝro kal yikoe ba wada.

sourceString: Russell Zimmerman added that other products are also in high demand, including masks, sanitiser, dried goods, handwash and flour.
targetString: Russell Zimmerman ye waltǝ bayan sǝrana kǝla karaiyya gade zauro mǝradǝtǝna, suronzan zambu ciye, shawul musko tultaye, karaiyya harrata, awo musko tultaye-a fǝlawa-a

sourceString: Similarly, outside of Australia, on Sunday evening online British supermarket Ocado was observed limiting purchases of Andres toilet paper to two 12-roll packs.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, diya Australia lan, yim Lardǝwa kajiri Supermarket la onlayin ye British ye Ocado shiya luwaya kakkadi ngawdin faidatǝ ye Andres ye dǝ fuluzǝ ndi ro sǝdǝna faket wo son -12.

sourceString: World Health Organization declares COVID-19 pandemic
targetString: World Health Organization ye COVID-19 dǝ kwasa dǝwo dina samma ye ro bawwono.

sourceString: On Wednesday, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared the ongoing outbreak of COVID-19 — the disease caused by coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 — to be a pandemic.
targetString: Yim Larafawa, World Health Organization (WHO) ye falangtǝ kǝrmaro wajin COVID-19 ye dǝ — kwasa dǝwo coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 ye suwudin ma dǝga — kwasa dina samma so ye ro bawwono.

sourceString: Although the word "pandemic" only refers to how widely a disease has spread, not how dangerous specific cases are, the WHO noted the need to drive governments to action:
targetString: Son yayi kalma dǝwo "pandemic" dǝ mananzǝ futu kwasa dǝ kura ro tartǝgǝna dǝ bas yayi, nǝm tajirwa kwasa musamman ye gǝnyi, WHO ye mǝradǝ gomnatiwa so dǝga buwotǝ kǝla dǝn katab gotǝye mbeji:

sourceString: "All countries can still change the course of this pandemic.
targetString:
Lardǝwi yo so raksǝ letǝram kwasa dinaye adǝga faljin. 	Wikinews_6:1159	https://en.wikinews.org/wiki/World_Health_Organization_declares_COVID-19_pandemic	CC_BY-SA_2.5	unk
en	kr	 If countries detect, test, treat, isolate, trace and mobilize their people in the response, said Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the Director-General of the WHO.
stringID: Sa lardǝwa so dǝ ye kulassan asuzaiyya, ngalzaiyya, kurun sadiya, kozaiyya, sursuri dǝ zasaiyya, kuru amza sabsaiyy kǝla bana tǝ dǝyen," Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus ye wono, kasazadla WHO ye.

sourceString: "We are deeply concerned both by the alarming levels of spread and severity and by the alarming levels of inaction."
targetString: Ande ye zauro zǝktǝkǝna kǝla futu tartǝgǝ -a nǝm zaw ǝd-a kuru futu abi ma kǝla dǝn tǝdǝnyi ye dǝn.

sourceString: According to Dr. Tom Frieden, formerly the director of the United States' Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the pandemic is "unprecedented."
targetString: Futu Dr. Tom Frieden ye gulzǝna dǝn, ngawon kazadala formerly the director of the United States' ye daudinzǝ kwasa kǝriwtǝye-a katǝgǝye-a ye, kwasa dinaye dǝ "tǝmmaro tǝmatǝgǝnyi" wono.

sourceString: He said, in remarks published by CNN in February, "other than influenza, no other respiratory virus has been tracked from emergence to continuous global spread."
targetString: Shi ye wono, suro jawaw la CNN ye lǝbsanaye lan suro February yen, "tantayi lan nguron, Kuli kwasabe yintǝ ye jili wi ma sursuri nzǝ sa fǝlangzǝnan tayi dina dukso ro tartanze ro kuden tǝanyi."

sourceString: Ghebreyesus expressed a similar view, saying "we have never before seen a pandemic sparked by a coronavirus."
