targetString: Ghebreyesus ye kururam jili tilowa bayanzǝna, wono "ande ye ngaltema kwasa dinaye koronabairos ye tarzǝyin ruyende."

sourceString: He continued, "and we have never before seen a pandemic that can be controlled at the same time."
targetString: Shi ye waltǝ wono, "kuru ngaltema kwasa dinaye dǝwo raktǝ sha loktu falyin katǝgǝyin ma ruyende."

sourceString: The new status as a pandemic follows the WHO's decision in January to declare the outbreak a public health emergency of international concern.
targetString: Daraja bǝlin kwasa dinaye dǝ shawari WHO ye suro January yen tǝdǝna dǝ zǝayin fǝlangtǝ dǝga shuwal nǝlefa ye dǝwo dina samma lezǝna ro wurmawono.

sourceString: The United States' National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease's director, Dr. Anthony Fauci, said of the outbreak, "bottom line, it's going to get worse."
targetString: United States ye kazadalanzǝ National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease ye, Dr. Anthony Fauci dǝ ye wono, kǝla falangtǝ dǝ ǝ yen, "jirenzǝ dǝ shima zauro tǝrayin."

sourceString: As of Thursday, Associated Press reported there were at least 126,000 cases of COVID-19 worldwide, resulting in over 4,600 deaths.
targetString: Lamisuwa ro, Associated Press ye hawar cina kǝla kwasa COVID-19 ye gananzǝ yayi 126,000 dina samma son, kǝrmu 4,600 samin suwudǝ.

sourceString: The 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic is an ongoing pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
targetString: 2019–20 ye coronavirus nzǝ dǝ kwasa dinaye dǝwo kǝrmaro wajin ma dǝwo kwasa coronavirus 2019 ye (COVID-19), sha kwasa yintǝye zauro zaw ma coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) ye suwudin ma.

sourceString: The outbreak was identified in Wuhan, China, in December 2019, declared to be a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on 30 January 2020, and recognized as a pandemic on 11 March 2020.
targetString: Falangtǝ Wuhan, China lan asuwotǝ, suro December 2019 ye lan, shuwal nǝlefa jamaye duwasashi ye dǝwo dina samma lezǝna ma ro mawwotǝ yim 30 January 2020 lan, kuru sha kwasa dǝwo dina samma so ro tartǝgǝna ma ro gowotǝ yim 11 March 2020 lan.

sourceString: As of 10 April 2020, approximately 1.61 million cases of COVID-19 have been reported in 210 countries and territories, resulting in approximately 97,000 deaths.
targetString: Yim 10 April 2020 lan, tǝadir am miliyon 1.61 ye dǝyeyi COVID-19 ye zamzǝna ye hawar tuwondǝna suro lardǝwa 210 yen, kǝrmu alama tǝadir am 97,000 ye dǝyeyi suwudǝ.

sourceString: About 364,000 people have recovered.
targetString: Alama am 364,000 yeyi ngazana.

sourceString: The case fatality rate has been estimated to be 4% in China, while globally ranging from 13.04% in Algeria to .08% in New Zealand.
targetString: Kǝrmu kwasa dǝ ye dǝ kashi 4% yen ro tǝadirrata suro China yen, adǝyeyi ma dina samman kate kate 13.04% suro Algeria yen-a. 08% suro New Zealand ye-a lan.

sourceString: Common symptoms include fever, cough and shortness of breath.
targetString: Alamawa kǝndondibe nowata so dǝ surozǝn kange, nzasǝra-a yintǝ kǝraw-a

sourceString: Complications may include pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
targetString: Kǝrawnzǝ dǝ suronzǝn kwasa namǝsuye-a kwasa yintǝ kǝratǝye dǝga so mbeji.

sourceString: The time from exposure to onset of symptoms is typically around five days, but may range from two to fourteen days.
targetString: Loktu dǝwo letǝgǝ-a alamawa kǝndondibe baditǝnzǝn ye-a dǝ kara kawu uwu yen, amma kate kate kawu ndi-a meu deri-a yen kara.

sourceString: There is no known vaccine or specific antiviral treatment.
targetString: Kalimi la nowata ba aw kurun kuli kwasabe kǝriwtǝ ye musamman ye so ba.

sourceString: Primary treatment is symptomatic and supportive therapy.Recommended preventive measures include hand washing, covering one's mouth when coughing, maintaining distance from other people, and monitoring and self-isolation for people who suspect they are infected.
targetString: Kurun dǝwo badiyaram ye dǝ alama kǝndondibe kuru kurun banatǝgǝ ye. Katabwa kǝla nzǝdkawo ye amarrata so dǝ suro nzan musko tultǝ, ci zaktǝ sa kamye sasǝrayin ma, am so ro fattǝgǝ ba, kǝla ro hangal gǝnatǝ-a kǝla kortǝ-a am sandiya zamtǝna ro tǝmazǝna so ye.

sourceString: Authorities worldwide have responded by implementing travel restrictions, quarantines, curfews, workplace hazard controls, and facility closures.
targetString: Gomnatiwa dina samman hangalnza sadǝna wuwom bǝlaro dabtǝye so, kortǝ wuwom fomtǝba ye so, na cidayen tajirwa fulutǝ so, ba zaktǝ so men.

sourceString: The pandemic has led to severe global socioeconomic disruption, the postponement or cancellation of sporting, religious, political and cultural events, and widespread shortages of supplies exacerbated by panic buying.
targetString: Kwasa dinaye adǝ ye zauro lamar kasuwuye-a dinaye e bannazǝna, lamarra biske ye, adinye, siyasa ye-a lamarra kasuwu ye-a mǝradǝ kuru karaiyya kasuwu ye fulut-a luwaya karuwu kamye ye.

sourceString: Schools and universities have closed either on a nationwide or local basis in 193 countries, affecting approximately 99.4 percent  of the world's student population.
targetString: Muwontiwa so-a jamiya-a samma zakkata lardǝ dukson aw huma gana wo son suro lardǝwa 193 yen tǝadir furawa dinaye kashi 99.4 suro miya yen lezǝ.

sourceString: Misinformation about the virus has spread online, and there have been incidents of xenophobia and discrimination against Chinese people, other people of East and Southeast Asian descent and appearance, and others from areas with significant virus cases.
targetString: Hawar fǝrtǝba kǝla kuli kwasabe dǝ yen tarratǝgǝ onlayin lan, kuru Kusoto watǝ so ngaytǝ so wawazǝna am China ye ro, am gade East-a Southeast Asia ye-a am sandiya samǝn-a so ro am na gade kwasa dǝ nguwu ro wazǝna so-a kunten.

sourceString: Due to reduced travel and closures of heavy industry, there has been a decrease in air pollution and carbon emissions.
targetString: Sawo bǝlaro so fulutǝna kuru kamfoniwa so ye zakkata dǝ ye sǝkǝ kasam Bannatǝ so carbon tulo so dǝ ye fulutǝna.

sourceString: Health authorities in Wuhan, China (the capital of Hubei province) reported a cluster of pneumonia cases of unknown cause on 31 December 2019, and an investigation was launched in early January 2020.
targetString: Wumawa nǝlefa ye Wuhan, China lan (bǝrni kura bǝla Hubei ye) dǝ ye rifot kǝla kwasa namusu ye dǝwo fǝrtǝ notǝnyiya ma ye cina yim 31 December 2019 lan, kuru kulashi baditǝna badiyaram yim January 2020 ye lan.

sourceString: The cases mostly had links to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market and so the virus is thought to have a zoonotic origin.
targetString: Kwasawa dǝ nguwu so kasuwu kǝmbu njiye dǝro leyata adǝ nankaro kwasa dǝ dabba men gotin ro tǝmatǝ

sourceString: The virus that caused the outbreak is known as SARS-CoV-2, a newly discovered virus closely related to bat coronaviruses, pangolin coronaviruses, and SARS-CoV.The earliest known person with symptoms was later discovered to have fallen ill on 1 December 2019, and that person did not have visible connections with the later wet market cluster.
targetString: Kuli kwasabe dǝwo falangtǝ dǝga suwudǝna dǝ sha SARS-CoV-2 lan nuwotǝ, kuli kwasabe dǝwo bǝlin ro Asutǝna ma koronabairos batata ye, psngolinye, ro leyata ma, kuru SARS-CoV-a. Kam dǝwo buro hawal yin alamawa kǝndondibe dǝ fǝlezǝna ma dǝ dare isǝ dondizǝna ro asuwotǝ yim 1 December 2019 lan, kuru kam adǝ awo sha kasuwu kǝmbu njiye dǝga fete farak ro kǝlzǝna ba.

sourceString: Of the early cluster of cases reported in December 2019, two-thirds were found to have a link with the market.
targetString: Kwasa dǝwo buron hawaratǝgǝna ma suro December 2019 ye dǝ, kashi ndi suro yakkǝ yen so kasuwu dǝro leyata.

sourceString: On 13 March 2020, an unverified report from the South China Morning Post suggested that a case traced back to 17 November 2019, in a 55-year-old from Hubei province, may have been the first.On 26 February 2020, the WHO reported that, as new cases reportedly declined in China but suddenly increased in Italy, Iran, and South Korea, the number of new cases outside China had exceeded the number of new cases within China for the first time.
targetString: Yim 13 March 2020, hawar la tawattǝnyi South China lan Jarida Suwala ye la ye wono kam kwasa la yim 17 November 2019 tǝngata la, kam la ngǝli 55 bǝla Hubei ye, waneye shima kam kǝn buroye ro waljin. Yim 26 February 2020, WHO ye wono, kwasa China dǝn fulutǝna dǝn amma tǝmatǝnyi lan Italy, Iran, South Korea lan tǝrana, adadu kwasa dǝ bǝlin ya ye dǝ diya China yen dǝn adadu suro China ye dǝga kowono kǝn hawal ro.

sourceString: There may be substantial underreporting of cases, particularly among those with milder symptoms.
targetString: Waneye adadu am dǝwo hawar nza fantinmba ye mbeji suro am alamawa kǝndondibe nza kambayi ye dǝn.

sourceString: By 26 February, relatively few cases had been reported among youths, with those 19 and under making up 2.4% of cases worldwide.The United Kingdom's chief scientific adviser, Patrick Vallance, estimated that 60% of the British population would need to become infected before effective herd immunity could be achieved.
targetString: Yim 26 February, adadu kwasa dǝye gana tuwondǝ suro zairowa so yen, saa 19 cidaan dǝ kashi 2.4% kwasawa dinaye sammaso ye. United Kingdom ye shawarimanzǝ kura Ilmuye, Patrick Vallance, ye tǝadir zǝna kǝla kashi 60% am British ye dǝ samma sai kwasa dǝ ye zamjiya dǝwo kawu kalimi kwasa dǝye ngǝlama tuwondin dǝ wono.

sourceString: Cases refers to the number of people who have been tested for COVID-19, and whose test has been confirmed positive according to official protocols.
targetString: Cases dǝ mananzǝ adadu am dǝwo COVID-19 ro ngaltǝnadǝ, kuru am dǝwo ngaltǝnza dǝye mbeji ro fǝlezǝna ma so dǝ futu kaidawa mailaye men isǝna ma.

sourceString: As of 23 March, no country had tested more than 3% of its population, and many countries have had official policies not to test those with only mild symptoms, such as Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, and Switzerland.
targetString: Yim 23 March lan, lardǝwi ma jamanzǝ kashi 3% kozan ngalzǝna ba, of kuru lardǝwa kada kaidawanza mailaye kǝla wande am dǝwo alamawa kǝndondibe kambayiya so dǝga ngaltǝnyi ye mbeji, alama Italy, the Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland-a so yeyi.

sourceString: A study published on 16 March found that in China, up to 23 January, an estimated 86% of COVID-19 infections had not been detected, and that these undocumented infections were the infection source for 79% of documented cases.
targetString: Nazaru la yim 16 March lǝbtǝna dǝ ye fǝlezǝna kǝla suro China yen, 23 January kawdo wo so, tǝadir alama kashi 86% am COVID-19 ye zamzǝna so tuwondǝnyi, kuru am dǝwo zamtǝna asutunyi so dǝ and that these undocumented infections were the infection source for 79% of documented cases.

sourceString: A statistical analysis published 30 March estimated that numbers of infections in Italy were considerably greater than the reported cases.
targetString: Kulashi la yisawuye yim 30 March lǝbtǝna dǝ ye tǝadirzǝna kǝla adadu zamtǝye dǝ suro Italy ye dǝn zauro adadu rifot tina ye dǝga gozǝna.

sourceString: The initial estimates of the basic reproduction number (R0) for COVID-19 were 1.4 to 2.4.
targetString: Tǝadir buroye kǝla adadu yamboye dǝwo shiro reproductio number (R0) gultin ye COVID-19 ye dǝ were 1.4 sǝta 2.4 ro kedo.

sourceString: A study published by the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention has concluded that it may be 5.7.
targetString: Nazaru la US Center for Disease Control and Prevention ye lǝbsana dǝ 5.7 ro kamzǝ kolzǝna.

sourceString: Most people with COVID-19 recover.
targetString: Am COVID-19 sǝtana nguwu so ngazain.

sourceString: For those who do not, the time from development of symptoms to death has been between 6 and 41 days, with the most common being 14 days.
targetString: Am dǝwo ngazainmba so dǝ, loktu alamawa kǝndondibe baditǝnzǝn tai kǝrmu ro kude dǝ kate kate kawu 6 tai 41 ro koden kara, nguwu so ro wajin dǝ kawu 14 dǝma.

sourceString: As of 10 April 2020, approximately 97,000 deaths had been attributed to COVID-19.
targetString: Yim 10 April 2020 lan, tǝadir alama batǝ 97,000 yeyi COVID-19 ro leyata.

sourceString: In China, as of 5 February about 80% of deaths were in those over 60, and 75% had pre-existing health conditions including cardiovascular diseases and diabetes.Official tallies of deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic generally refer to dead people who tested positive for COVID according to official protocols.
targetString: China lan, yim 5 February kǝrmu kara kashi 80% dǝ suro am ngǝlinza 60 kozǝna yen, kuru kashi 75% dǝ buroman kwasa la gade tiyinzan mbeji suro dǝn kwasa karuwuye so, shiwurye so mbeji. Komno kǝrmuye mailaye COVID-19 ye dǝ am bazana dǝwo COVID ye sǝtana so futu kaida maila ye men ma so dǝ nganzatǝ.

sourceString: The number of true fatalities from COVID-19 may be much higher, as it may not include people who die without testing - e.g. at home, in nursing homes, etc.
targetString: Adadu am jireyi ro COVID-19 ye cezǝna dǝ waneye adǝga kojin, dalilnzǝ dǝ am ngaltǝnyi dǝwo bazana so dǝ kǝltǝnyi dǝro - misallo fato lan, fato am ro jistuwuuen, gade gabsǝna-a.

sourceString: Partial data from Italy found that the number of excess deaths during the pandemic exceeded the official COVID death tally by a factor of 4-5x.
targetString: Bayan la reta reta dǝwo Italy lan tuwondǝna dǝ ye fǝlezǝna kǝla adadu kǝrmu ma kozǝna ye loktu kwasa dinaye dǝn adadu kǝrmu COVID ye dǝga kozǝna 4-5x lan

sourceString: A spokeswoman for the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) acknowledged "We know that [the stated death toll] is an underestimation", a statement corroborated by anecdotal reports of undercounting in the U.S. Such underestimation often occurs in pandemics, such as the 2009 H1N1 swine flu epidemic.The first confirmed death was in Wuhan on 9 January 2020.
targetString: Kǝshana la cima U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) ye wono acknowledged "Ande ye nonyena kǝla [adadu kǝrmuye gultǝna ma dǝ] fuluwata ro", mana la dǝwo ne rifot la kǝzǝbkǝ gǝnyi i ro gǝriyata kǝla US lan yisaw fuluwata ro tǝdin yen. Yisaw fulutǝ jili adǝ nguwu so ro suro wawa kwasa dinaye so dǝn tǝdin, alama loktu kwasa such as 2009 H1N1 tantayi godu ye dǝ lan. Kam tawadǝro buro hawal yin bazǝna dǝ Wuhan lan yim 9 January 2020.

sourceString: The first death outside mainland China occurred on 1 February in the Philippines, and the first death outside Asia was in France on 14 February.
targetString: Kǝrmu buro hawal ye diya China ye dǝ yim 1 February suro Philippines yen wawono, kuru kǝrmu buro hawal ye diya Asia ye dǝ suro France yen yim 14 February.

sourceString: By 28 February, outside mainland China, more than a dozen deaths each were recorded in Iran, South Korea, and Italy.
targetString: Yim 28 February, diya China ye lan, kǝrmu mewun indin samin tuwondǝna ndaso wo so suro Iran, South Korea, Italy-a yen.

sourceString: By 13 March, more than forty countries and territories had reported deaths, on every continent except Antarctica.Several measures are commonly used to quantify mortality.
targetString: Yim 13 March, lardǝwa-a kalangayya-a fidew yin samin hawar kǝrmu tuwondǝna ye sadǝna, lardǝwi yo son illa Antarctica gǝnyi ma. Katabwa jili tilowa kada lan faidatǝna kǝrmu dǝ isabtǝro.

sourceString: These numbers vary by region and over time, and are influenced by the volume of testing, healthcare system quality, treatment options, time since initial outbreak, and population characteristics such as age, sex, and overall health.The death-to-case ratio reflects the number of deaths divided by the number of diagnosed cases within a given time interval.
targetString: Adaduwa adǝ fafaltin lǝatar nasha-a loktu gotǝ-an, kuru adadu ngaltǝye, nǝm ngalaw fasal nǝlefaye, karno kurun diwoye, loktu gǝrtǝna tǝn sa buro hawal yin falangzǝna yen, kuru siffa jamaye-a alama ngǝli, jinsu, nǝlefa. Yisaw kǝrmu-kwasaye dǝ fǝlejin adadu kǝrmuye dǝ gonǝm adadu kwasa tuwondǝna ye dega yangnǝmiya suro loktu la nuwata ye ma nyiro cin.

sourceString: Based on Johns Hopkins University statistics, the global death-to-case ratio is 6.0% (97,039/1,617,204) as of 10 April 2020.
targetString: Futu yisawu Johns Hopkins University ye ladǝn, yisaw kǝrmu-kwasaye dinaye dǝ shima 6.0% (97,039/1,617,204) yim 10 April 2020.

sourceString: The number varies by region.
targetString: Adadu fafaltin lǝatar nasha dǝye ro.

sourceString: In China, estimates for the death-to-case ratio decreased from 17.3% (for those with symptom onset 1–10 January 2020) to 0.7% (for those with symptom onset after 1 February 2020).Other measures include the case fatality rate (CFR), which reflects the percent of diagnosed people who die from a disease, and the infection fatality rate (IFR), which reflects the percent of infected (diagnosed and undiagnosed) who die from a disease.
targetString: China lan, tǝadir kǝrmu-kwasa ye dǝ fulutǝna  17.ǝ% lan (am buro hawal yin alama kǝndondibe fǝlezǝna so 1–10 January 2020) ro 0.7% (am alama kǝndondibe fǝlezǝna so ngawo 1 February 2020).Ngalno la so dǝ suronzan yisaw kǝrmu kwasa ye (CFR), shi dǝwo adadu am kulastǝ dǝwo bazana ye, kuru adadu am zamtǝna dǝwo bazana ye-a (IFR), shi dǝwo ne kashi zamtǝna ye fǝlejin (kulastǝna-a kulastǝnyi-a) dǝwo kwasa la lan bazana so.

sourceString: These statistics are not timebound and follow a specific population from infection through case resolution.
targetString: Yisawwa dǝ loktu so ba kuru jama la musamman ro zǝayin zamtǝm sǝta kortǝ ro cado.

sourceString: A number of academics have attempted to calculate these numbers for specific populations.
targetString: Ilmuwu kada adadu adǝga jama la musamman ye ro isabtǝro Kasadǝ sadǝna.

sourceString: The University of Oxford's Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine estimates that the infection fatality rate for the pandemic as a whole is between 0.1% and 0.39%.
targetString: University of Oxford's Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine ye tǝadirzǝna kǝrmu zamtǝye dǝ shio 0.1% -a 0.39% -a wono.

sourceString: The upper estimate of this range is consistent with the results from the first random testing for COVID-19 in Germany, and a statistical study analysing the impact of testing on CFR estimates.
targetString: Tǝadir samiye yisaw adǝyeyi dǝ natija ngalte COVID-19 buro hawal ye Germany lan tǝdǝna dǝga kalkal, kuru nazaru la yisawuye bayan kǝla ngalte CFR yen sǝdin ma.

sourceString: The WHO asserts that the pandemic can be controlled.
targetString: WHO dǝ ye tawatsǝna kǝla kwasa dinaye dǝ raktǝ katǝgǝyin ro.

sourceString: The peak and ultimate duration of the outbreak are uncertain and may differ by location.
targetString: Falangtǝ dǝ ye cotnzǝ-a loktu ndawuro tusshin-a notǝnyi kuru waneye fafaltin lǝatar naye ro.

sourceString: Maciej Boni of Penn State University stated, "Left unchecked, infectious outbreaks typically plateau and then start to decline when the disease runs out of available hosts.
targetString: Maciej Boni Penn State University ye dǝye wono, kwasawa kulastǝnyi koltǝna so dǝ, buron samijin daji kuru zǝbcin sa ma nabtǝye suwondǝnyi ma.

sourceString: But it's almost impossible to make any sensible projection right now about when that will be".
targetString: Amma kǝrma dǝro muwonzǝ sabi wajin ro notinmba wo."

sourceString: The Chinese government's senior medical adviser Zhong Nanshan argued that "it could be over by June" if all countries can be mobilized to follow the WHO's advice on measures to stop the spread of the virus.
targetString: Gomnati Chinese ye shawarima nzǝ kura kǝla nǝlefa yen Zhong Nanshan dǝye wono "muwonzǝ ba ro waljin June lan" lardǝwi yo so amnza sabsa shawariwa WHO ye kǝla futu kuli kwasabe dǝ tartǝgǝ dabtǝgǝ dǝye zasaya.

sourceString: On 17 March, Adam Kucharski of the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine stated that SARS-CoV-2 "is going to be circulating, potentially for a year or two".
targetString: Yim 17 March, Adam Kucharski the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine ye dǝye wono SARS-CoV-2 dǝ "kokortin, saa fal aw ndi yeyi ro".

sourceString: According to the Imperial College study led by Neil Ferguson, physical distancing and other measures will be required "until a vaccine becomes available (potentially 18 months or more)".
targetString: Futu koleji kǝraye Imperial College study dǝwo fuwumanzǝ shima Neil Ferguson shi kurawu ma dǝ ye gulzana dǝ, kam so wa cintutǝ-a katabwa gade so-a dǝ mǝradǝtin "sayi sa kalimi la tuwondiya (kǝntawu 18 aw adǝga kozǝna yeyi)".

sourceString: William Schaffner of Vanderbilt University stated, "I think it's unlikely that this coronavirus—because it's so readily transmissible—will disappear completely" and it "might turn into a seasonal disease, making a comeback every year".
targetString: William Schaffner dǝwo Vanderbilt University ye dǝ ye wono, "tǝmagǝnyi coronavirus adǝ -nagaduro tartǝgǝnzǝ dǝye sǝkǝ- cotro ba ro waljin ro" kuru shi"waneye faltǝ kwasa zaman ye ro waljin, lejiya waltǝ saa wo son Ishin."

sourceString: The virulence of the comeback would depend on herd immunity and the extent of mutation.
targetString: Nǝm kǝraw Waltǝm kǝnshenzǝ ye dǝ lǝatar duno tiyibe kwasa kǝriwtǝye dǝ-a futu alau kwasa dǝye dǝ faltǝna dǝn kara.

sourceString: Symptoms of COVID-19 can be relatively non-specific and infected people may be asymptomatic.
targetString: Alamawa Symptoms of COVID-19 ye dǝ raksǝ awo la fal nowata gǝnyi ro waljin kuru am zamtǝna dǝ alama kǝndondibe so ba yayi ro waljin.

sourceString: The two most common symptoms are fever (88%) and dry cough (68%).
targetString: Alamawa nzǝ kura kura ndi nowata ma sandima kange (88%)-a kasawu ngamdu (68%)-a.

sourceString: Less common symptoms include fatigue, respiratory sputum production (phlegm), loss of the sense of smell, shortness of breath, muscle and joint pain, sore throat, headache, chills, vomiting, hemoptysis, diarrhea, or cyanosis.The WHO states that approximately one person in six becomes seriously ill and has difficulty breathing.
targetString: Alamawa dǝwo nguwu ro notǝnyi dǝ sandima yimbaro, bulubulu tulo (phlegm), kǝnzamen kaino fantǝ ba, yintǝ kǝrawtǝ, tiyi-a kǝndǝw-a sǝrǝn, dawu lilimta, kǝla sǝrǝn, kaku fantǝ, fitǝ, kasaw buye, shidada, aw lawnǝ tiyiye kǝli ro waltǝ. WHO ye wono tǝadir alama kam fal suro arakkǝyen zauro dondi ro waljin kuru yintǝ kǝraw ro waljin.

sourceString: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) lists emergency symptoms as difficulty breathing, persistent chest pain or pressure, sudden confusion, difficulty waking, and bluish face or lips; immediate medical attention is advised if these symptoms are present.Further development of the disease can lead to severe pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis, septic shock and death.
targetString: U.S. ye daudinzǝ kwasa kǝriwtǝye-a katǝgǝye-a sha Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) lan buwotin dǝ ye alamawa kǝndondibe duwasashi ye isabsǝna alama yintǝ kǝraw yeyi, karuwu sǝrǝn aw kǝraw kamjinmba ma, loktu falyin kǝlajetǝ, kǝnǝmyin fatǝ kǝraw, fuska aw ka ciye lawnǝ kǝliye ro waltǝ; tinyi ro liyitari ro letǝn galatǝna alamawa kǝndondibe adǝ mbeji ma. Kwasa dǝ fuwujiya isǝ kwasa namusu ye kǝraw ma, kwasa yintǝ ye kǝraw ma, tiyi ye kurunna so watǝ, kǝndǝwu tiyi cidazainmba ro waltǝ, kǝrmu-a ro fǝraksǝyin.

sourceString: Some of those infected may be asymptomatic, with no clinical symptoms but with test results that confirm infection, so researchers have issued advice that those with close contact to confirmed infected people should be closely monitored and examined to rule out infection.
targetString: Am la sandiya zamtǝna so dǝ alama afiye ma fǝlejinmba, alama liyitariye so ba amma natija ngalte dǝ ye dǝ mbeji fǝlejin, adǝ nankaro kulashiwu so ye shawari sadǝna kǝla am dǝwo kam dondi tawatkata ro letana so dǝro ngǝlaro hangal gǝnaza kuru sandiya ngalte kwasa dǝ gozanyi ro tawattǝgǝ ro.

sourceString: Chinese estimates of the asymptomatic ratio range from few to 44%.
targetString: China ye tǝadir yisawnzǝ adadu am dǝwo alama kǝndondibe fǝlezainmba ye dǝ gana lan sǝta 44% ro ciwudo.

sourceString: The usual incubation period (the time between infection and symptom onset) ranges from one to 14 days; it is most commonly five days.As an example of uncertainty, the estimate of the fraction of people with COVID-19 who lost their sense of smell was initially 30% and later fell to 15%.
targetString: Loktu nzǝ kaltǝ tambin nowata ma dǝ (loktu kate kate sa zamtǝna dǝga sa alama fǝletǝ badizana ye) kate kawu falyin sǝta 14 ro sadǝna yen; nguwu so ro kawu uwu. Alama misal tawadǝba yeyi, tǝadir yisaw am dǝwo iCOVID-19 ye sǝta kǝnzanzan kayino fanzayinmba ro walzǝna ye dǝ buro dǝn kashi 30% kuru dare 15% ro zǝbkono.

sourceString: Some details about how the disease is spread are still being determined.
targetString: Bayan kǝla futu jilibi men kwasa tarratǝgǝ ye dǝ kwamison notǝnyi.

sourceString: The disease is believed to be primarily spread during close contact and by small droplets produced during coughing, sneezing, or talking; with close contact being within 1 to 2 metres (3 to 6 feet).
targetString: Kwasa dǝ buro hawal yin sa kamro letǝgǝ men kuru tollo dǝwo kam kasaw zajin, watiska sǝkin, aw manajin lan suluyin dǝ men; tartǝgǝyin ro kasadtǝna; nǝm karǝngǝ suro mita 1 sǝta 2 ro suwudǝna ma (gowodǝ 3 sǝta 6 ro suwudǝna).

sourceString: Studies have found that an uncovered coughing can lead to droplets travelling up to 4.5 metres (15 feet) to 8.2 metres (27 feet).
targetString: Nazaruwa ye fǝlezǝna kǝla nzasǝra ci zaktǝnyi ye dǝ tollo yirzǝ har mita 4.5 ro lejin (gowod315) mita 8.2 (gowodǝ 27) ro lejin.

sourceString: Some have proposed that the virus may also be transmitted by small droplets that stay for more prolonged periods in the air, that may be generated during speech.Respiratory droplets may also be produced during breathing out, including when talking, though the virus is not generally airborne.
targetString: Am la so ye kurunzan wada Kuli kwasabe dǝ waneye muwonzǝ tollo sǝnana dǝwo raksǝ loktu kuruwu ro kasam yin nabchin men tartǝgǝyin, Shi dǝwo loktu manatin lan suluyin dǝ men. Tollo yintǝram ye ye muwonzǝ suluyin loktu yintǝye lan, suro dǝn sa manatin so, son yayi shi kuli kwasabe adǝma dǝ kwasa dǝwo kasam men lejin so gǝnyi.

sourceString: The droplets can land in the mouths or noses of people who are nearby or possibly be inhaled into the lungs.
targetString: Tollo dǝ raksǝ suro ci au kǝnza am karǝngǝ ye ro gayin au yintǝ fufu ro kamzǝ kojin.

sourceString: Some medical procedures such as intubation and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) may cause respiratory secretions to be aerosolized and thus result in airborne spread.
targetString: Cidawa liyitaye la so alama as intubation -a cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) -a so dǝ raksǝ nji yintǝram ye so dǝga kasam ro fussǝyin kuru adǝyeyi men kasam men tartǝgǝ ro fǝraksǝyin.

sourceString: It may also spread when one touches a contaminated surface, including skin, and then touches their eyes, nose, or mouth.
targetString: Kuru man raksǝ tartǝgǝyin sa kam ye na la kwasa nabsǝgǝna lejiya, kaziyi yin kunten, kuru waltǝ shimnzǝ, kǝnza au cinzǝ lejiya.

sourceString: While there are concerns it may spread by faeces, this risk is believed to be low.
targetString: Bǝli men tartǝgǝyin ro am la so ye sorin dǝwo yayi, tajirwa adǝma dǝ gana.

sourceString: The Government of China denied the possibility of faecal-oral transmission of SARS-CoV-2.The virus is most contagious during the first three days after onset of symptoms, although spread may be possible before symptoms appear and in later stages of the disease.
targetString: Gomnati China dǝ SARS-CoV-2 ye tartǝgǝnzǝ bǝli men aw ci men ye dǝga kasadsǝnyi. Kuli kwasabe dǝ zauro dunonzǝ tartǝgǝ ye-a suro kawu yakkǝ dǝwo alama dǝ fǝlezǝna dǝ yen, son yayi tartǝgǝ dǝ Muwonjin kawu alama dǝ fǝlejin dǝ yayi ro kuru suro dareye kwasa dǝ yen yayi.

sourceString: People have tested positive for the disease up to three days before onset of symptoms suggesting transmission is possible before developing significant symptoms.
targetString: Am la so ngaltǝna dǝn kwasa dǝ mbeji fǝlezǝna kawu alama fǝlejin ye kawu yakkǝa lan, adǝyeyi fǝlejin kǝla tartǝgǝ dǝ Muwonjin kawu alama la bayantin ma ro.

sourceString: Only few reports of laboratory-confirmed asymptomatic cases exist, but asymptomatic transmission has been identified by some countries during contact tracing investigations.
targetString: Jawawu kulashi ye gana kam alama ba yen kwasa dǝ mbeji ro tawadsa, amma tartǝgǝ kam alama fǝlezǝnyi dǝ lardǝwa la so ye suwondana sa am letanaso dǝ barayin lan.

sourceString: The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) states that while it is not entirely clear how easily the disease spreads, one person generally infects two to three others.The virus survives for hours to days on surfaces.
targetString: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) ye wono kwamison jilibi men kwasa nagaduro tartǝyin ro asutǝnyi yayi, kam fal ye raksǝ am ndi aw yakkǝ ro tarzǝyin. Kuli kwasabe t kǝla awo la yen raksǝ awa kada aw kawu kada ro raksǝ dǝayin.

sourceString: Specifically, the virus was found to be detectable for up to three days on plastic (polypropylene) and 304 stainless steel, for one day on cardboard, and for up to four hours on copper.
targetString: Musamman ma ro, kuli kwasabe dǝ turin kawu ro kǝla ruba yen (polypropylene)-a shiwu 304 -a lan, kawu fal kǝla kakkadi yen, kuru awa diyew ro kǝla njirkime yen.

sourceString: This, however, varies based on the humidity and temperature.Pets and other animals have tested positive for COVID-19.
targetString: Adǝye, adǝyeyi ma, lǝatar kulongu-a kawudo-a yen kara. Dabbawa la fato ye so ye ngaltǝ kwasa COVID-19 ye dǝ sayi lan mbeji ro fǝlezǝna.

sourceString: There is no evidence animals can pass the virus on to humans, though British authorities advise washing one's hands after contact with animals, like after contact with other surfaces infected people could have touched.
targetString: Hujja dǝwo dabbawa so ye kwasa dǝ kam so ro tarzayin ye ba, son yayi gomnati Britishye dǝ am so wa galazana kǝla musko tultayen sa dabba letǝya futu kam tyinzǝn kwasa dega ye awo la lejiya musko tultin dǝ yeyi ro.

sourceString: Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is a novel virus, first isolated from three people with pneumonia connected to the cluster of acute respiratory illness cases in Wuhan.
targetString: Kwasa yintǝ ye kǝraw ma koronabairos 2 (SARS-CoV-2) dǝ kwasa bǝlin, buro hawal yin am yakkǝ kwasa namusu ye sǝtana dǝwo kwasa yintǝye Wuhan ye dǝro leyata ma.

sourceString: All features of the novel SARS-CoV-2 virus occur in related coronaviruses in nature.Outside the human body, the virus is killed by household soap, which dissolves its protective envelope.SARS-CoV-2 is closely related to the original SARS-CoV.
targetString: Siffawa All features of the novel SARS-CoV-2 ye samma so coronavirus sha samǝnga samma son wajin. Tiyi kam yigǝnyi ma kuli kwasabe dǝ shawul fatoye dǝ ma ye sha cejin, awo dǝwo ne sha faijin dǝ fajin. SARS-CoV-2 dǝ sha SARS-CoV dǝga zauro karǝngǝ.

sourceString: It is thought to have a zoonotic origin.
targetString: Fǝrtǝnzǝ dabba men kedo ro tǝmata.

sourceString: Genetic analysis has revealed that the coronavirus genetically clusters with the genus Betacoronavirus, in subgenus Sarbecovirus (lineage B) together with two bat-derived strains.
targetString: Kulashi alauye ye fǝlezǝna kǝla coronavirusdǝ alau men genetically clusters with the genus Betacoronavirus dǝga kǝltana, suro subgenus Sarbecovirus (lineage B) yen rokko kwasa ndi batata ye-a.

sourceString: It is 96% identical at the whole genome level to other bat coronavirus samples (BatCov RaTG13).
targetString: Shi kashi It is 96% ro samǝn coronavirus batata ye gade so dǝga (BatCov RaTG13).

sourceString: In February 2020, Chinese researchers found that there is only one amino acid difference in certain parts of the genome sequences between the viruses from pangolins and those from humans.
targetString: February 2020 lan, kulashiwu China ye asuzana kǝla Kate kate alai kuli kwasabe pangolinye-a adamngana ye-a dǝn amino acid fal lang dǝma wada.

sourceString: Whole-genome comparison to date has found at most 92% of genetic material shared between pangolin coronavirus and SARS-CoV-2, which is insufficient to prove pangolins to be the intermediate host.
targetString: Rataltǝgǝ Whole-genome ye dǝ ye ku wo so ro nguwunzǝ 92% suwondǝna awowa alauye kate kate koronabairos pangolinye SARS-CoV-2 ye-a, adǝ ye kǝzǝbkǝ gǝnyi pangolin dǝ shima daw daw dǝn gǝnatǝma wo ro.

sourceString: Infection by the virus can be provisionally diagnosed on the basis of symptoms, though confirmation is ultimately by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) of infected secretions or CT imaging.
targetString: Kuli kwasabe dǝ ye zamtǝ dǝ raktǝ alamawa men kulastin yayi tawattǝgǝ dǝ reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) tollo zamtǝna yen aw CT imaging men.

sourceString: A study comparing PCR to CT in Wuhan has suggested that CT is significantly more sensitive than PCR, though less specific, with many of its imaging features overlapping with other pneumonias and disease processes.
targetString: Nazaru la kǝla PCR dǝ CT ro rataltǝyin lan suro Wuhan ye lan fǝlezǝna kǝla CT dǝ PCR dǝga kozǝna, dǝwo musamman gǝnyi, fotonz dǝ nguwu so suro kwasa namusu ye dǝ ro gana.

sourceString: As of March 2020, the American College of Radiology recommends that "CT should not be used to screen for or as a first-line test to diagnose COVID-19".
targetString: March 2020 lan, American College of Radiology ye shawari cina kǝla "CT dǝ wande shilan faidatǝ aw wande shima zawal ngal ye buroye walzǝnyi kulashi COVID-19 yen".

sourceString: The WHO has published several RNA testing protocols for SARS-CoV-2, with the first issued on 17 January.
targetString: WHO dǝye kaidawa ngalte RNA ye kada lǝbsǝna SARS-CoV-2 ro, buro hawalmi dǝ yim 17 January cetolo.

sourceString: The test uses real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR).
targetString: Ngalte dǝ real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) lan faidatin.

sourceString: The test can be done on respiratory or blood samples.
targetString: Ngalte muwonzǝ yintǝram au bu gotǝna ro tǝdin.

sourceString: Results are generally available within a few hours to days.
targetString: Natija dǝ suro awa au yim gana yen tuwondin.

sourceString: Generally this test is carried out on a nasopharyngeal swab though a throat swab may also be used.A number of laboratories and companies are developing serological tests, which detect antibodies.
targetString: Nguwu so ro ngalte adǝ sha kǝla nasopharyngeal swab yen tǝdin dǝwo yayi a throat swab yayin faidatin. Jimwa ngalye-a kamfoniwa kada-a ye ngaltǝ buye dawartǝ sadin, shi dǝwo ne balimi tiyi ye kwasa kǝritǝye asujin ma.

sourceString: As of 6 April 2020, none of these has been proved sufficiently accurate to be approved for widespread use.
targetString: Yim 6 April 2020, sandi adǝn ndaso ma kǝzǝbkǝ ro tawttǝgǝna ma ba ndarason faidatǝ ro.

sourceString: In the US a serological test developed by Cellex has been approved for emergency use by certified laboratories only.
targetString: US la dǝn ngaltǝ buye la Cellex ye sǝtandǝna dǝ duwasashi faidatǝ ro amari tina Jimwa ngalye sadkata so ye bas.

sourceString: Characteristic imaging features on radiographs and computed tomography (CT) of people who are symptomatic include asymmetric peripheral ground glass opacities and absent pleural effusions.
targetString: Characteristic imaging features dǝ radiographs ye dǝn kuru computed tomography (CT) am dǝwo alamawa kǝndondibe ya dǝ suro dǝn asymmetric peripheral ground glass opacities-a absent pleural effusions -a ye mbeji.

sourceString: The Italian Radiological Society is compiling an international online database of imaging findings for confirmed cases.
targetString: Italian Radiological Society ye bayanna lardǝwa diyaye onlayin men sabcin kǝla fotowa kwasawa tawatkataye dǝn.

sourceString: Due to overlap with other infections such as adenovirus, imaging without confirmation by PCR is of limited specificity in identifying COVID-19.
targetString: Sawo kwasawa gade so wa tuskatin dǝye sǝkǝ alama adenovirus so yeyi, foto diwo PCR ye tawattsǝnyi lan dǝ faidanzǝ gana na COVID-19 asutuye dǝn.

sourceString: A large study in China compared chest CT results to PCR and demonstrated that though imaging is less specific for the infection, it is faster and more sensitive, suggesting its consideration as a screening tool in epidemic areas.
targetString: Nazaru la kura China lan tǝdǝna ye natija chest CT ye results to PCR ro ratalzǝgǝna kuru fǝlezǝna kǝla foto dǝ kwasa dǝ gǝnyi musamman ro ganzazǝ son yayi, shima daiy yo ye kuru jawaw tuwondin wo ye, fǝlezǝna kǝla shilan naa kwasa dinaye fǝlangtǝna so dǝn faidatǝ ro.

sourceString: Artificial intelligence-based convolutional neural networks have been developed to detect imaging features of the virus with both radiographs and CT.
targetString: Artificial intelligence-based convolutional neural networks tǝtandǝna Siffawa fotoye asutu ro kuli kwasabe dǝ ye with both radiographs -a CT-a men.

sourceString: Strategies for preventing transmission of the disease include maintaining overall good personal hygiene, washing hands, avoiding touching the eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands, and coughing or sneezing into a tissue and putting the tissue directly into a waste container.
targetString: Katabwa kwasa dǝ tartǝgǝ ro dabtǝye so dǝ suronzan nǝm ngǝla kǝlaye ro cistuwu, musko tultǝ, shim, kǝnza, ci so musko tultǝ nyi lan letǝba, aw nzasǝra aw watiska suro tawulye ro diwo-a tawul dǝ suro ngubdola ye ro koltǝgǝ-a.

sourceString: Those who may already have the infection have been advised to wear a surgical mask in public.
targetString: Am dǝwo caman kwasa dǝ ye zamzǝna so dega galatǝna dawu jamaye ro tamiya zambu ciye sakǝ ro.

sourceString: Physical distancing measures are also recommended to prevent transmission.Many governments have restricted or advised against all non-essential travel to and from countries and areas affected by the outbreak.
targetString: Katabwa kam ro cintǝtuwu ye shi ye shawari tina tartǝgǝ dǝ dabtǝ ro. Gomnatiwa kada ye bǝlaro dalil baye so dǝ dabsana aw shawari wande tǝdǝnyi ye sadǝna lardǝ ro gawu aw luwo ro kuru naa kwasa dǝ fǝlangzǝna so-a son.

sourceString: However, the virus has reached the stage of community spread in large parts of the world.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, kuli kwasabe dǝ ba tartǝgǝ bǝlaye ro nazǝgǝna dina samma son.

sourceString: This means that the virus is spreading within communities, and some community members don't know where or how they were infected.Health care providers taking care of someone who may be infected are recommended to use standard precautions, contact precautions, and eye protection.Contact tracing is an important method for health authorities to determine the source of an infection and to prevent further transmission.
targetString: Adǝyeyi mananzǝ dǝ shima kuli kwasabe suro jama so yen tartǝgǝyin, kuru am la suro jama dǝ ye dǝn futu aw ma sandiya zamtǝna dǝ ma nozanyi. Cidawu liyitariye dǝwo kam zamtǝna ro cidayin so dǝ ye katabwa nzǝdkawo ye amarrata so dǝn faidatǝ ro, nzǝdkawo letǝgǝ ye-a shimye-a. Kam letǝgǝna baratǝ dǝ nzundu dǝwo zauro faida tartǝgǝ dǝ dabtǝ ro.

sourceString: The use of location data from mobile phones by governments for this purpose has prompted privacy concerns, with Amnesty International and over 100 other organizations issuing a statement calling for limits on this kind of surveillance.
targetString: Telfon men na kam dǝgana manǝm gotǝ dǝwo gomnati ye sǝdǝna dǝ shiwalla ashir faitǝye kada sǝsangǝna, rokko Amnesty International-a karabkawa gade 100 samin-a kawlu sotoluwuna kǝla sursuri kǝnga jili adǝ fulutǝ ro.

sourceString: Various mobile apps have been implemented or proposed for voluntary use, and as of April 7, 2020, over a dozen expert groups were working on privacy-friendly solutions, such as using Bluetooth to log a user's proximity to other cellphones.
targetString: Mobile apps kada koltǝna aw loktu ro nyatǝna kǝlanzǝko ro faidatǝ ro, kuru yim April 7, 2020, maskuwa mewun indin samin cidazain kǝla nǝske ashirra lejinmba ma tulo ro, alama bluetooth lan faidatǝm nǝm karǝngǝ telfon gadeya so notǝ so.

sourceString: Users then receive a message if they've been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19.Misconceptions are circulating about how to prevent infection; for example, rinsing the nose and gargling with mouthwash are not effective.
targetString: Am faidatǝna so dǝ daji watiya la sawundain sandiro kam COVID-19 ye sǝtana karǝngǝn kǝltana wa ro. Hawar fǝrtǝba la fomjin suro jama yen kǝla futu kwasa dǝn ta dabtǝyen, Misallo, kǝnza tultǝ- ci kurun ci tultaye lan gulumtǝ-a samma faidatinmba.

sourceString: There is no COVID-19 vaccine, though many organizations are working to develop one.
targetString: Kalimi COVID-19 ye ba amma karabkawa la Kasadǝ tandoye sadinna kasheru.

sourceString: Hand washing is recommended to prevent the spread of the disease.
targetString: Musko tultǝ dǝ shawari tina kǝla kwasa dǝ tartǝgǝ dabtǝ yen.

sourceString: The CDC recommends that people wash hands often with soap and water for at least twenty seconds, especially after going to the toilet or when hands are visibly dirty; before eating; and after blowing one's nose, coughing, or sneezing.
targetString: CDC ye shawari cina kǝla am so kǝla kǝlan muskonza shawu-a nji-a lan tulza gananzǝ sekon findi ro, musamman ma ro sa ngawdin saluwiya aw sa musko dǝ zahir ro kadawwa ro waljiya; kawu kǝmbu boyen; kuru ngawo kamye kǝnzanzǝ titciya, nzasǝra aw watiska yen.

sourceString: This is because outside the human body, the virus is killed by household soap, which bursts its protective bubble.
targetString: Adǝye dalil dǝ shima kuli kwasabe dǝ diya tiyi kam ye dǝn shawul fatoye dǝ sha cejin, awonzǝ sha faijin ma dǝga kwaljin.

sourceString: CDC further recommended using an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol by volume when soap and water are not readily available.
targetString: CDC ye waltǝ shawari cina kǝla kǝndawu musko tultaye dǝwo shi ro alcohol-based hand sanitizer sayin ma dǝwo suronzǝn 60% alcohol mbejiya ma dǝn faidatǝ ro sa nji-a shawul-a ba ro waljiya.

sourceString: The WHO advises people to avoid touching the eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands.
targetString: WHO ye am so wa galazana kǝla wandǝ shim, kǝnza, au ciya musko tultǝnyi lan lezanyi ro.

sourceString: Surfaces may be decontaminated with a number of solutions (within one minute of exposure to the disinfectant for a stainless steel surface), including 62–71% ethanol, 50–100% isopropanol, 0.1% sodium hypochlorite, 0.5% hydrogen peroxide, and 0.2–7.5% povidone-iodine.
targetString: Kǝla awoye so dǝ awowa kada lan tultin (suro minti fal yen sa awo tultǝye fitǝgǝgnan kǝla shiwu yen), suro dǝn 62–71% ethanol, 50–100% isopropanol, 0.1% sodium hypochlorite, 0.5% hydrogen peroxide, kuru 0.2–7.5% povidone-iodine mbeji.

sourceString: Other solutions, such as benzalkonium chloride and chrohexidine gluconate, are less effective.
targetString: Kurunna la gade alama benzalkonium chloride -a and chrohexidine gluconate -a so dǝ, faidazainmba.

sourceString: The CDC recommends that if a COVID case is suspected or confirmed at a facility such as an office or day care, all areas such as offices, bathrooms, common areas, shared electronic equipment like tablets, touch screens, keyboards, remote controls, and ATM machines used by the ill persons, should be disinfected.
targetString: CDC dǝ ye shawari cina kǝla sa kwasa COVID ye ro zantǝgǝya aw sa tawattǝgǝya na la ofis so yeyyi aw na am ro cistuwu ye so, naa dǝ samma alama ofis son ngawudi so naa ndo so ye faidatin so, awo ndusoye faidatin so alama tabǝlet so, toch skǝrin so, kibod so, rimotkontururol, ATM so dǝwo kam dondi ye lezǝna so dǝ rultǝ.

sourceString: Health organizations recommended that people cover their mouth and nose with a bent elbow or a tissue when coughing or sneezing, and disposing of any tissue immediately.
targetString: Karabkawa nǝlefabe (Health organizations) am so ro shawari cina kǝla cinza-a kǝnza-a zaksai njuromi namngat men aw tawul men sa nzasǝra aw watiska ka dajin ma, kuru tawul dǝga tinyi ro gǝbsa.

sourceString: Surgical masks are recommended for those who may be infected, as wearing a mask can limit the volume and travel distance of expiratory droplets dispersed when talking, sneezing, and coughing.
targetString: Zambu fǝskaye dǝ yiko ro shawari tina am dewo zamtǝna so dǝ ro, zambu yiko dǝ tollo yintǝram ye dǝga cintu ro letǝro dabcin mantin, watiska tǝkin, aw nzasǝra tǝdin ma.

sourceString: The WHO has issued instructions on when and how to use masks.
targetString: WHO ye kashimo sutuluwuna kǝla futu zambu yiko yen.

sourceString: According to Stephen Griffin, a virologist at the University of Leeds, "Wearing a mask can reduce the propensity [of] people to touch their faces, which is a major source of infection without proper hand hygiene."Masks have also been recommended for use by those taking care of someone who may have the disease.
targetString: Futu Stephen Griffin, liyita Kuli kwasabe la University Leeds yen, "Zambu yiko dǝ am so ye fuska letǝnza fulujin, Adǝ ye futu kwasa gota kura fal musko ngǝla ro tultin ba ma. Zambu dǝ kuru man shawari tina am dǝwo kam dondi ro cidayin so dǝ ye sakǝ ro.

sourceString: The WHO has recommended the wearing of masks by healthy people only if they are at high risk, such as those who are caring for a person with COVID-19, although they also acknowledge that wearing masks may help people avoid touching their face.
targetString: WHO ye am kǝkewanza do wa zambu yiko ro galawono illa sa zauro suro tajirwa yen ro walzaiyya, alama kam COVID-19 ba ro cistuwuyin ma, Son yayi kasadsana kǝla zambu yiko dǝ sǝkǝ am so dǝ fuskanza lezainmba.

sourceString: Several countries have started to encourage the use of face masks by members of the public.
targetString: Lardǝwa kada ye am so zambu dǝ yiko ro galatǝ badizana.

sourceString: In the U.S., the CDC recommends wearing non-medical face mask made out of cloth.China has specifically recommended the use of disposable medical masks by healthy members of the public, particularly when coming into close contact (1 metre (3 ft) or less) with other people.
targetString: U.S. lan, CDC dǝye shawari cina kǝla zambu dǝwo liyitariye ma gǝnyi dina lan tǝdǝna ma. China ye musamman ro Zambu fal ro faidatin ma dǝ dǝ am kǝkewanza so ye dakǝ, ro galawono dǝga sakǝ ro, musamman ma ro sa karǝngǝ ro isayin ma (1 metre (ǝ ft) or less) aw am gade so-a.

sourceString: Hong Kong recommends wearing a surgical mask when taking public transport or staying in crowded places.
targetString: Hong Konga ye zambu yiko dǝn galawono sa am so moto kasuye ro zawain ma aw jama nguwa la kasheru ma.

sourceString: Thailand's health officials are encouraging people to make cloth facemasks at home and wash them daily.
targetString: Cidawu nǝlefabe Thailand ye so dǝ am so wa galazana kǝla zambu fuskaye dinaye satandǝro fato lan kuru kullum ro sha tulza ro.

sourceString: The Czech Republic and Slovakia banned going out in public without wearing a mask or covering one's nose and mouth.
targetString: The Czech Republic -a Slovakia -a suro jama ye ga dabsana zambu tǝkǝnyi aw kǝnza-a ci-a zaktǝnyi ma.

sourceString: On 16 March, Vietnam requested everyone to wear a face mask when going to public areas in order to protect themselves and others.
targetString: Yim 16 March, Vietnam ye nduso ro zambu fuskaye sǝkǝ sa dawu jamaye ro gayin ma.

sourceString: The Austrian government mandated that everyone entering a grocery store must wear a face mask.
targetString: Gomnati Australia ye ye ndu yayi kanti karaiykǝli ye ro gayin ma zambu sǝkǝ ro amari cina.

sourceString: Israel has asked all residents to wear face masks when in public.
targetString: Israel ye am lardǝ dǝn dasana samma ro Zambu fuskaye sǝkǝ suro jama yen wono.

sourceString: Taiwan, which has been producing ten million masks per day since mid-March, required passengers on trains and intercity buses to wear face masks on 1 April.
targetString: Taiwan, dǝwo kǝrmaro zambu miliyon mew wajiya son sǝtandin tǝn dawu March yen ma dǝ, kǝmbawu so wa mǝradǝzǝna Zambu fuskaye sakǝ ro yim 1 April.

sourceString: Panama has made it obligatory to wear a face mask whenever going outside, while also recommending the manufacture of a homemade face mask for those who cannot purchase face masks.
targetString: Panama ye zambu fuskaye lan faidatǝ mbu ro sǝdǝna suro jama yen, kuru man zambu jili fatoye tandoye shawari cina am raksa cesoyinmba so ro.

sourceString: Face masks have also been widely used in Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, and Singapore.
targetString: Zambu fuskaye so dǝ Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore-a so yen faidatǝna.

sourceString: Social distancing (also known as physical distancing) includes infection control actions intended to slow the spread of disease by minimizing close contact between individuals.
targetString: Jama cintutǝ (zadǝ cintutǝ yayi gultin) suro dǝn cidawa kwasa kaltǝgǝye kwasa tartǝgǝ fulutǝ ganzatǝ kam so wa letǝgǝ fulutǝ men.

sourceString: Methods include quarantines; travel restrictions; and the closing of schools, workplaces, stadiums, theatres, or shopping centres.
targetString: Nzunduwa dǝ suro dǝn kotǝ; bǝlaro dabtǝ; muwontiwa zaktǝ; na cidaye, naa bol baktǝye; naa biske ye aw naa kasuwu ye so zaktǝ.

sourceString: Individuals may apply social distancing methods by staying at home, limiting travel, avoiding crowded areas, using no-contact greetings, and physically distancing themselves from others.
targetString: Am raksa jama cintutǝ dǝga sadin faton nabtǝ men, bǝlaro fulutǝ, naam nguwuwa ro ga koltǝ, lewa tiyi kǝltǝ ba ye diwo, kuru zadǝnza men kam gade sowa cintutǝ.

sourceString: Many governments are now mandating or recommending social distancing in regions affected by the outbreak.
targetString: Gomnatiwa kada kǝrmadǝ mbu ro aw shawari sadin jama cintutǝ dǝro ba dǝwo falangzǝna so dǝn.

sourceString: The maximum gathering size recommended by US government bodies and health organizations was swiftly reduced from 250 people (if there was no known COVID-19 spread in a region) to 50 people, and later to 10 people.
targetString: Adadu nguwu am sabtǝye dǝwo gomnati US ye amarzǝna dǝ duwaro fuluwotǝ 250 lan (nasha dǝn falangtǝ COVID-19 ye so ba ma) am 50 ro ciwudo kuru dare am 10 ro walwono.

sourceString: On 22 March 2020, Germany banned public gatherings of more than two people.Older adults and those with underlying medical conditions such as diabetes, heart disease, respiratory disease, hypertension, and compromised immune systems face increased risk of serious illness and complications and have been advised by the CDC to stay home as much as possible in areas of community outbreak.In late March 2020, the WHO and other health bodies began to replace the use of the term "social distancing" with "physical distancing", to clarify that the aim is to reduce physical contact while maintaining social connections, either virtually or at a distance.
targetString: Yim 22 March 2020, Germany samno am indiya kozǝnye dabsǝna. Am ngǝlinza lezǝna zo-a kwasa laye zǝksǝna alama kwasa shiwurre, kwasa karuwuye, kwasa yintǝye, kwasa buye, kuru balimi tiyi ye kwasa kǝritǝye duno ba ro walzǝna sodǝ sandima zauro tajirwa so kuru CDC ye sandiya galazǝna kǝla faton nabtǝ ro naa falangzǝna so dǝn. Dare March 2020 lan, WHO -a cidaramwa nǝlefa ye gade so wa ye kalma "social distancing" ye dǝ falza with "physical distancing" ro kalakkada, awo ngazatǝna dǝ zadǝ karǝngǝtǝ fulutǝ sa am so wa kǝltuwin dǝn bayantǝ ro, kazahir gǝnyi men aw cintu lan.

sourceString: The use of the term "social distancing" had led to implications that people should engage in complete social isolation, rather than encouraging them to stay in contact with others through alternative means.Some authorities have issued sexual health guidelines for use during the pandemic.
targetString: Kalma kamro kasamyiye din "social distancing" yen faidatǝ dǝ kaziyi kada sǝkǝna am so cetro am kamtǝ ro gowada, susu sandiya yikǝm kamanza so wa kǝlakǝlzayin zawal gade men dǝro. Gomnatiwa la so kashimo futu jima'i diwo ye satoluwuna suro loktu kwasa yeadǝn faidatǝ ro.

sourceString: These include recommendations to only have sex with someone you live with, who does not have the virus or symptoms of the virus.
targetString: Suro dǝn shawari wande jima'i tǝdǝnyi sai kam dǝwo kallo dǝawa gǝnyi ma, shi dǝwo ne kwasa dǝ tiyinzǝn ba ma aw alama kwasa dǝ ye ba ma.

sourceString: Self-isolation at home has been recommended for those diagnosed with COVID-19 and those who suspect they have been infected.
targetString: Kǝla kortǝye shawari tina am dǝwo kulashi COVID-19 ye tǝdǝna so dǝro-a am sandiya zamtǝna ro zanzana so-a ro.

sourceString: Health agencies have issued detailed instructions for proper self-isolation.Many governments have mandated or recommended self-quarantine for entire populations living in affected areas.
targetString: Cidaramwa nǝlefa ye so ye kashimo sotoluwuna kǝla futu ngǝlaro kǝla kortǝ yen. Gomnatiwa kada ye mbu aw shawari sadǝna kǝla kǝla kortǝ yen naa dǝwo kwasa falangzǝna son.

sourceString: The strongest self-quarantine instructions have been issued to those in high risk groups.
targetString: Kǝla kortǝ dunowa ma dǝ am dǝwo hal zauro tajirwan dasana so tina.

sourceString: Those who may have been exposed to someone with COVID-19 and those who have recently travelled to a country or region with widespread transmission have been advised to self-quarantine for 14 days from the time of last possible exposure.
targetString: Am dǝwo waneye kam COVID-19 ye zamzǝna ro letana so-a am dǝwo karǝngǝn bǝlawa falangzǝna ro bǝlaro zana so-a dǝga galatǝna kǝlanza korza ro kawu 14 ro loktu dareye letana lan.

sourceString: Strategies in the control of an outbreak are containment or suppression, and mitigation.
targetString: Katabwa falangtǝ yitkawye dl sandima kǝriwtǝ aw rattǝ-a fulutǝ-a.

sourceString: Containment is undertaken in the early stages of the outbreak and aims to trace and isolate those infected as well as introduce other measures of infection control and vaccinations to stop the disease from spreading to the rest of the population.
targetString: Kǝriwtǝ dǝ tǝdin sa buro hawal loktu falangzǝna dǝ lan kuru mǝradǝ dl shima am zamtǝna t kulastǝ fondo-a kortǝ-a kura katabwa gade kwasa kaltǝge ye kudo-a kalimi-a kwasa dǝga jama gade tarratǝgǝ dabtǝ ro.

sourceString: When it is no longer possible to contain the spread of the disease, efforts then move to the mitigation stage: measures are taken to slow the spread and mitigate its effects on the healthcare system and society.
targetString: Sa kwasa kǝriwtǝro teriya, Kasadǝ kuwa fulutu ro waltin: katabwa gotin kwasa dǝ tartǝgǝ fulutǝ ro kaziyiyya dǝwo fasal nǝlefaye -a jama ye-a ro suwudin dǝga fulutu ro.

sourceString: A combination of both containment and mitigation measures may be undertaken at the same time.
targetString: Katabwa kǝriwtǝye-a fulutǝ ye-a so loktu falyin gotin.

sourceString: Suppression requires more extreme measures so as to reverse the pandemic by reducing the basic reproduction number to less than 1.Part of managing an infectious disease outbreak is trying to decrease the epidemic peak, known as flattening the epidemic curve.
targetString: Fattǝgǝ dǝ katabwa zauro zaw gotǝ mǝradǝzǝna kwasodǝga ngawo ro kalaktǝ ro yanmbonzǝ sǝ 1 yin cidaan ro kundo ro. Suro kwasa Nzunduwa kwasa dinaye kaltǝge yen nǝm nguwu nzǝ fulutǝ mbeji, shiro flattening the epidemic curve gultin.

sourceString: This decreases the risk of health services being overwhelmed and provides more time for vaccines and treatments to be developed.
targetString: Adǝ ye tajirwa liyitariya yimbuloye dǝga fulujin kuru loktu kalimi -a kurun -a diwoye nguwu cin.

sourceString: Non-pharmaceutical interventions that may manage the outbreak include personal preventive measures, such as hand hygiene, wearing face-masks, and self-quarantine; community measures aimed at physical distancing such as closing schools and cancelling mass gathering events; community engagement to encourage acceptance and participation in such interventions; as well as environmental measures such surface cleaning.More drastic actions aimed at containing the outbreak were taken in China once the severity of the outbreak became apparent, such as quarantining entire cities and imposing strict travel bans.
targetString: Bnawa kurunye gǝnyi ma dǝwo falangtǝ dǝga fulujin dǝ suro dǝn kǝlaro cistuwu, alama musko tultǝ, zambu fǝskaye yiko, kǝla kortǝ; katabwa jama ro cintutǝgǝ ye alama muwonti zaktǝ so, kuru jama nguwu sabtǝ so; kǝla jamaye fatǝgǝ kada fando ro; alama kor fǝratǝ yeyi so. Katabwa zau gade China lan gotǝna fǝlangtǝ dǝ dabtǝ ro sa falangtǝ dǝ zauro Asutǝna dǝn, alama bǝla dǝ samma kortǝ-a bǝlaro dabtǝ-a yeyi.

sourceString: Other countries also adopted a variety of measures aimed at limiting the spread of the virus.
targetString: Lardǝwa la so ye katabwa kada gozana kuli kwasabe dǝ tartǝgǝ fulutǝ ro.

sourceString: South Korea introduced mass screening and localized quarantines, and issued alerts on the movements of infected individuals.
targetString: South Korea ye am nguwu ngaltǝ-a faton kortǝ-a, kuru je zǝndǝna kǝla fomtǝ am zamtǝna yen.

sourceString: Singapore provided financial support for those infected who quarantined themselves and imposed large fines for those who failed to do so.
targetString: Singapore ye bana kawoye am dǝwo kǝlanza korzana dǝ ro cina kuru ha kuru kǝla am diwo ro wazana so ye dǝro gǝnazǝgǝna.

sourceString: Taiwan increased face mask production and penalized hoarding of medical supplies.Simulations for Great Britain and the United States show that mitigation (slowing but not stopping epidemic spread) and suppression (reversing epidemic growth) have major challenges.
targetString: Taiwan ye zambu ciye tando dǝ sǝrana kuru am gǝrazain so dǝga hazǝna. Jarabtǝ Great Britain-a United States-a dǝ ye fǝlezǝna kǝla fulutǝ (gultu cotro ba ro diwo gǝnyi)-a rattǝgǝ (kwasa dǝ ngawo ro kaltǝgǝ)-a dǝn kaziyiyya kura mbeji ro.

sourceString: Optimal mitigation policies might reduce peak healthcare demand by 2/3 and deaths by half, but still result in hundreds of thousands of deaths and health systems being overwhelmed.
targetString: Tartib tajirwa flutuye ngalam dǝ nǝm nguwu nǝlefa ro cistuwu ye dǝga 2/ǝ lan fulujin kuru kǝrmu reta ro fulujin, amma kwamison kǝrmu duwu kada suwudin kuru naa nǝlefa ro cistuwu ye so dǝ kek sǝmbuluwuna.

sourceString: Suppression can be preferred but needs to be maintained for as long as the virus is circulating in the human population (or until a vaccine becomes available, if that comes first), as transmission otherwise quickly rebounds when measures are relaxed.
targetString: Rattǝgǝ dǝ shima kattin amma mǝradǝ nglaro cistuwu ye mbeji kuli kwasabe dǝ suro jama yen fomjin wo so ro (aw hatta sai kalimi tuwondiya dǝwo, adǝma dǝ shima buron isǝ ma) adǝ gǝnyi ma tartǝgǝ e waltǝ cayibaro ishin sa katabwa koltiya.

sourceString: Long-term intervention to suppress the pandemic causes social and economic costs.
targetString: Loktu kurùwu ro kwasa dǝ rattǝgǝ ro banatǝ dǝ kaziyi jamaye -a kungǝnaye-a suwudin.

sourceString: There are no specific antiviral medications approved for COVID-19, but development efforts are underway, including testing of existing medications.
targetString: Kurun la musamman ye COVID-19 ro kasatkata so ba, amma Kasadǝ tondoye sadinna kara, suro dǝn Kurunwa kǝrmaye dǝga ngaltǝ ye mbeji.

sourceString: Taking over-the-counter cold medications, drinking fluids, and resting may help alleviate symptoms.
targetString: Kurun tantayi ye kemisye kǝnza so, awo njiya njiye ya so, bunǝm tiyinǝm kǝrǝntǝ so dǝ waneye alama kǝndondibe habtǝ ro banajin.

sourceString: Depending on the severity, oxygen therapy, intravenous fluids, and breathing support may be required.
targetString: Nǝm kǝraw lǝatar ro, kasam yintǝ banatǝgǝ ye yiko, nji yira, kuru yintǝ ro banatǝgǝ so mǝradǝtin.

sourceString: The use of steroids may worsen outcomes.
targetString: steroids lan faidatǝ cayibaro natija dǝga bannajin.

sourceString: Several compounds that were previously approved for treatment of other viral diseases are being investigated for use in treating COVID-19.
targetString: Kurunwa kada caan COVID-19 ro amarrata so dǝ waltǝ kulastin.

sourceString: The WHO also stated that some "traditional and home remedies" can provide relief of the symptoms caused by SARS-CoV-19.
targetString: WHO ye wono "Kurunwa kaduwye la so dǝ" raksǝ nǝske suwudin alama kǝndondibe SARS-CoV-19 ye suwudǝna so dǝ ro.

sourceString: Increasing capacity and adapting healthcare for the needs of COVID-19 patients is described by the WHO as a fundamental outbreak response measure.
targetString: Duno yira-a kuru mǝradǝwa nǝlefa ye COVID-19 ye zamzǝna so dǝro cistuwu dǝ WHO ye shima bana kura kǝla falangtǝ dǝye wo wono.

sourceString: The ECDC and the European regional office of the WHO have issued guidelines for hospitals and primary healthcare services for shifting of resources at multiple levels, including focusing laboratory services towards COVID-19 testing, cancelling elective procedures whenever possible, separating and isolating COVID-19 positive patients, and increasing intensive care capabilities by training personnel and increasing the number of available ventilators and beds.
targetString: ECDC-a cidaram European regional office WHO ye-a dǝ ye kashimo la sotoluwuna liyitari so-a cidaram nǝlefa ye badiyaram ye-a karaiyya cidaye so dǝga saworza nasha kada lan, suro dǝn cidawa jim kulashiye kǝl COVID-19 so dǝro hangal yo so, awowa mbu gǝnyi so dǝ dawartǝ so, am COVID-19 ye sǝtana so karnǝm kortǝ so, am dondi tiyinzan mbeji ro fǝlezǝna so, kuru nzundu cidawa am zaw so ro cistuye yira ilmu cidawu ye yira men kuru man adadu awo yintǝ banatǝye dǝga yira-a men.

sourceString: There are various theories about where the very first case (the so-called patient zero) may have originated.
targetString: Nazaru kada mbeji kǝla ndaran kam dǝwo buro hawalmin kwasa dǝ ye sǝtana dǝ fǝrtǝnzǝ wo ro.

sourceString: The first known case of the novel coronavirus may trace back to 1 December 2019 in Wuhan, Hubei, China.
targetString: Kam buro hawal yin Koronabairos ye zamzǝna ro nowata dǝ 1 December 2019 suro Wuhan, Hubei, China yen.

sourceString: Within a month, the number of coronavirus cases in Hubei gradually increased.
targetString: Suro kǝntawu fal yen, adadu am coronavirusye zamzǝna dǝ Hubei dǝn gana ganan tǝra.

sourceString: These were mostly linked to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, which also sold live animals, and one theory is that the virus came from one of these kinds of animals; or, in other words, has a zoonotic origin.A pneumonia cluster of unknown cause was observed on 26 December and treated by the doctor Zhang Jixian in Hubei Provincial Hospital, who informed the Wuhan Jianghan CDC on 27 December.
targetString: Anyi nguwuso kasuw kǝmbu njiye Huanan Seafood Wholesale ye dǝ ro leyata, shi dǝwo kuru dabba riwa ye tǝlodin dǝ kuru nazaru dǝ ye awo fǝlezǝna dǝ shima Kuli kwasabe dǝ ma dabba adǝ ye falzan kedo; aw, fǝrtǝnzǝ dabbaa men kedo. Kwasa namusu ye la nowata ma turuna yim 26 December kuru kuin sǝdǝna doctor Zhang Jixian ye suro Hubei Provincial Hospital yen, shi dǝwo ne Wuhan Jianghan ye CDC dǝ ro gulzǝna yim on 27 December.

sourceString: On 30 December, a group of doctors at Wuhan Central Hospital alerted their colleagues of a "SARS-like coronavirus".
targetString: Yim 30 December, liyitawa la suro Wuhan Central Hospital yen kamanza ro je zǝndǝna kǝla "SARS-like coronavirus" yen.

sourceString: Eight of these doctors, including Li Wenliang, were admonished by the police for spreading false rumours, and another, Ai Fen, was reprimanded by her superiors for raising the alarm.
targetString: Liyitawa adǝ ye wuskǝ nza so, Li Wenliang-a so, darewa so ye sumonza gǝrzana mana fanem dane fǝrtǝ ba tartǝgǝ yen, kuru Ai Fen, ye amnzǝ kurawye sumonzǝ gǝrzana kǝla fane dane tartǝgǝ yen.

sourceString: The Wuhan Municipal Health Commission later released a public notice on 31 December and informed the WHO.
targetString: Wuhan Municipal Health Commission ye dare jama ro mawwono yim 31 December kuru WHO ro gullono.

sourceString: Enough cases of unknown pneumonia had been reported to health authorities in Wuhan to trigger an investigation in early January.During the early stages of the outbreak, the number of cases doubled approximately every seven and a half days.
targetString: Kwasa namusu ye kǝla notǝnyiya kada cidaram nǝlefa ye Wuhan ye dǝro rifot tadǝna sǝkǝ kulashi badiyetǝ badiyaram January yen. Loktu buro buro falangtǝ yen, adadu kwasa dǝ ye kawakcin alama tǝadir kawu tulur reta yeyi yin.

sourceString: In early and mid-January 2020, the virus spread to other Chinese provinces, helped by the Chinese New Year migration and Wuhan being a transport hub and major rail interchange.
targetString: Suro badiyaram-a dawu January 2020 ye-a lan, Kuli kwasabe dǝ bǝla China i gade so ro tarratǝgǝ, China ye bǝlaronzǝ saa bǝlin ye dǝ ye banazǝ kuru Wuhan ye shima dawudi bǝlaro ye-a awowa kǝmbaye-a wo.

sourceString: On 20 January, China reported nearly 140 new cases in one day, including two people in Beijing and one in Shenzhen.
targetString: Yim 20 January, China rifot cina kǝla am alama reported nearly 140 yeyi bǝlin ro kwasa dǝ ye zamgono suro kawu fal yen, suro dǝn am indi Beijing ye kuru kam fal dǝ Shenzhen ye.

sourceString: Later official data shows that 6,174 people had already developed symptoms by 20 January 2020.As of 26 March, the United States has overtaken China and Italy with the highest number of confirmed cases in the world.As of 9 April 2020, more than 1.61 million cases have been reported worldwide; more than 97,000 people have died and more than 364,000 have recovered.
targetString: Daren bayanna maila ye am 6,174 dǝ alama kǝndondibe fǝlezǝna ro fǝlewono yim 20 January 2020.Yim 26 March, shi United States dǝ China-a Italy-a kamzǝ kozǝna adadu am tawatkata ro zamzǝna yen dina samma son shima nguwu. Yim 9 April 2020, am miliyon 1.61 samin kwasa dǝ ye sǝtana ye tuwondǝna; more than am 97,000 samin bazana kuru am 364,000 samin ngazana.

sourceString: Around 200 countries and territories have had at least one case.
targetString: Alama lardǝwa-a kuru bǝla-a 200 yeyi kwasa dǝ gananzǝ yayi fal suwondana.

sourceString: Due to the pandemic in Europe, many countries in the Schengen Area have restricted free movement and set up border controls.
targetString: Sawo kwasa dinaye dǝro Europe lan, lardǝwa kada nasha many Schengen ye dǝn fomtǝ dabsana kuru kǝla kalangaiye kuru badizana.

sourceString: National reactions have included containment measures such as quarantines (known as stay-at-home orders, shelter-in-place orders, or lockdown) and curfews.As of 2 April, nearly 300 million people, or about 90% of the population, are under some form of lockdown in the United States, more than 50 million people are in lockdown in the Philippines, about 59 million people are in lockdown in South Africa, and 1.3 billion people are in lockdown in India.
targetString: Bana lardǝye dǝ suro dǝn katabwa kǝriwtǝye mbeji alama kortǝ yeyi (known as stay-at-home orders, shelter-in-place orders, or lockdown) so lan notǝna dǝ kuru fomno dabtǝ-a. Yim 2 April, am miliyon 300 karǝnga aw alama kashi million 90% jama dǝ ye, suro hal am zaktǝ yen kasheru suro United States yen, am miliyon more than 50 samin dǝ suro hal zaktǝ yen suro Philippines yen, alama am miliyon 59 yeyi suro hal zaktǝ yen suro South Africa yen kuru am biliyon 1.ǝ suro hai zaktǝ yen India lan.

sourceString: On 26 March, 1.7 billion people worldwide were under some form of lockdown, which increased to 2.6 billion people two days later—around a third of the world's population.
targetString: Yim 26 March, am biliyon 1.7 dina samma son suro hal zaktǝ yen kasheru, Shi dǝwo biliyon 2.6 ro tǝrana ngawo kawu indi yen- alama kashi yakkǝ jama dunyabedǝ yayi.

sourceString: The first confirmed case of COVID-19 has been traced back to 1 December 2019 in Wuhan; one unconfirmed report suggests the earliest case was on 17 November.
targetString: Kam buro hawal yin COVID-19 y sǝtana dǝ yim 1 December 2019 lan suro Wuhan yen; rifot la tawatka la ye wono waatǝnzǝ buro ye dǝ 17 November lan.

sourceString: Doctor Zhang Jixian observed a cluster of pneumonia cases of unknown cause on 26 December, upon which her hospital informed Wuhan Jianghan CDC on 27 December.
targetString: Doctor Zhang Jixian ye kwasa namusu ye la fǝrtǝnzǝ notǝnyi ma yim 26 December asuzǝna, kǝla adǝ yen liyitarinzǝ dǝ ye Wuhan Jianghan CDC ro gullono yim 27 December.

sourceString: Initial genetic testing of patient samples on 27 December 2019 indicated the presence of a SARS-like coronavirus.
targetString: Ngalte buye buro ye yim 27 December 2019 lan tǝdǝna dǝ ye fǝlezǝna kǝla SARS-like coronavirus mbeji ro.

sourceString: A public notice was released by Wuhan Municipal Health Commission on 31 December.
targetString: Wuhan Municipal Health Commission ye bowutǝ la jama ro sǝdǝna yim 31 December lan.

sourceString: The WHO was informed on the same day.
targetString: Yim shima dǝga dǝn WHO ye ro gullatǝ.

sourceString: As these notifications occurred, doctors in Wuhan were warned by police for "spreading rumours" about the outbreak.
targetString: Sa wurmatǝgǝ adǝ wazǝna dǝn, liyitawa so dǝ darewu so ye sunonza gǝrzana Wuhan lan kǝla fane dane fǝrtǝ ba kǝla fǝlangtǝ yen tarta yen.

sourceString: The Chinese National Health Commission initially claimed that there was no "clear evidence" of human-to-human transmission.
targetString: Chinese National Health Commission ye buron wono "hujja kate kate adamngana yen tartǝgǝ ye ba" sǝna.

sourceString: In late January, the Chinese government launched a radical campaign later described by the Chinese Communist Party general secretary Xi Jinping as a "people's war" to contain the spread of the virus.
targetString: Suro dare January lan, gomnati China ye kǝla amma fatǝgǝ la dunowa kǝrtǝro sǝkǝna shi dǝwo ne dare Chinese Communist Party general secretary Xi Jinping ye sha "kǝriw jamaye" Kuli kwasabe dǝ kǝriwtǝ ro lan buwozǝna dǝ.

sourceString: In what has been described as "the largest quarantine in human history", a cordon sanitaire was announced on 23 January stopping travel in and out of Wuhan, which was extended to a total of 15 cities in Hubei, affecting a total of about 57 million people.
targetString: Suro futu gutǝna yen kǝla "am kortǝ dǝwo kura ma ngalte ma am so ye sorunyi ma" am zaktǝgǝ dl yim 23 January cedo luwo-a gǝaw-a suro Wuhan ye ro ba ro cedo, shi dǝwo ne bǝrniwa gade 15 ro girtǝna suro Hubei yen, am alama miliyon 57 yeyi lezǝ.

sourceString: Private vehicle use was banned in the city.
targetString: Bǝrni dǝn motowa so kǝritǝ dabtǝna.

sourceString: Chinese New Year (25 January) celebrations were cancelled in many places.
targetString: Kǝlele saa bǝlin ye China ye yim (25 January) dǝ dawartǝna naa kada lan.

sourceString: The authorities also announced the construction of a temporary hospital, Huoshenshan Hospital, which was completed in 10 days.
targetString: Humawa so dǝ ye kuru man liyitari tamdaneye gartǝ mawuzana, liyitari Huoshenshan Hospital ye, suro kawu 10 yen tamowotǝ.

sourceString: Another hospital was built afterwards, Leishenshan Hospital, to handle additional patients.
targetString: Liyitari gade ye gartǝna ngawo adǝyen, liyitari Leishenshan ye, am dondi gade ro cistuwu ro.

sourceString: In addition to newly constructed hospitals, China also converted 14 other facilities in Wuhan, such as convention centers and stadiums, into temporary hospitals.On 26 January, the government instituted further measures to contain the COVID-19 outbreak, including issuing health declarations for travellers and extending the Spring Festival holiday.
targetString: Liyitariwa bǝlin gartǝna dawunmba ro, China ye waltǝ naa gade 14 liyitari ro kalaksǝna suro Wuhan yen, alama convention centers-a and stadiums-a, so yeyi yim. On 26 January, gomnati ye waltǝ katabwa gade kǝrtǝro sǝkǝna falangtǝ COVID-19 ye dǝ kǝriwtǝro, suro dǝn bǝlarowu so ro shada nǝlefaye kǝnjo so kuru batalla Spring ye dǝ yira so mbeji.

sourceString: Universities and schools around the country were also closed.
targetString: Jamiyawa so-a muwontiwa so lardǝ dǝ samman zaktǝna.

sourceString: The regions of Hong Kong and Macau instituted several measures, particularly in regard to schools and universities.
targetString: Bǝlawa Hong Kong -a Macau -a katabwa kada kǝrtǝro sakǝna, musamman ma ro kǝla muwontiwa-a jamiya-a yen.

sourceString: Remote working measures were instituted in several Chinese regions.
targetString: Katabwa cintun cidatǝ ye kǝrtǝro tǝkǝna bǝlawa China ye kada lan.

sourceString: Travel restrictions were enacted in and outside of Hubei.
targetString: Suro Hubei ye ro ga-a luwo-a kal tǝkǝna.

sourceString: Public transport was modified, and museums throughout China were temporarily closed.
targetString: Awo kǝmbaye so ro fasal bǝlin tǝdǝna kuru naa biske ye-a hawar kuruye-a so dǝ loktu la ro zaktǝna.

sourceString: Control of public movement was applied in many cities, and it has been estimated that about 760 million people (more than half the population) faced some form of outdoor restriction.After the outbreak entered its global phase in March, Chinese authorities took strict measures to prevent the virus from "importing" from other countries.
targetString: Fomno am ye ro kal tǝkǝna bǝlawa kadan, kuru tǝadir alama am miliyon 760 yeyi (reta jama dǝye ma kozǝna) diyaro luwoba ye gǝrezǝna. Ngawo falangtǝ dǝ dina samma ro tartǝgǝna yen suro March yen, China ye katabwa dunowa gozǝna kǝla wande kuli kwasabe dǝ lardǝ gade men tǝkǝnyi ro.

sourceString: For example, Beijing has imposed a 14-day mandatory quarantine for all international travellers entering the city.On 23 March, mainland China only one case had transmitted domestically in the five days prior, in this instance via a traveller returning to Guangzhou from Istanbul.
targetString: Misal ro, Beijinye bǝlagurowu bǝrni dǝ ro gasarayin samma so ro kǝla sǝgǝri ro tulo kau 14 mbuye gǝnazǝgǝna. Kǝntagǝ Marchye kaunzǝ 23, suro China naskube lan kes fal dǝma faltǝgǝ fato lan suro kauwwa uwu burobe dǝn, shi adǝ ma adǝye bǝlaguro maa laa Istanbullen Guanzhou ro waltin men.

sourceString: On 24 March 2020, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang reported that the spread of domestically transmitted cases has been basically blocked and the outbreak has been controlled in China.
targetString: Kǝntagǝ Marchye kaunzǝ 24, saa 2020be'a, firayim minista lardǝ Chinabeye wono kessa tartǝgǝ kwasadǝye fatobe dǝ ba tuttǝna kuru fǝlangtǝ dǝ China lan kaltǝgǝna.

sourceString: The same day travel restrictions were eased in Hubei, apart from Wuhan, two months after the lockdown was imposed.The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced on 26 March 2020 that entry for visa or residence permit holders would be suspended from 28 March onwards, with no specific details on when this policy will end.
targetString: Yim ka'idawa bǝlagurobe Hubei lan kǝskǝtǝgǝna la dǝn, Wuhan dawun ba ro, bǝrni zaktǝnaye ngawo kǝntagǝ indiyen. Cidaram lamarwa dunyabe ro cistǝgǝma lardǝ Chinabeye yim 26 kǝntagǝ Marchbe lan warmajio igama gawobe au rotǝwu izǝni naptabe so dǝ kǝntagǝ Marchye kaunzǝ 28 fuwun lan hapsayin sǝ warmajio, bayan loktu ka'ida adǝ haptinye jili wi ma ba ro.

sourceString: Those who wish to enter China will have to apply for visas in Chinese embassies or consulates.
targetString: Am doni China ro gasaraiyya saraana dǝ ofissa 'embassy' sayin au ' consulate' sayin dǝn igama/visa maza.

sourceString: The Chinese government encouraged businesses and factories to re-open on 30 March, and provided monetary stimulus packages for firms.The State Council declared a day of mourning to begin with a national three-minute moment of silence on 10:00 4 April, coinciding with Qingming Festival, although the central government asked families to pay their respects online in observance of physical distancing as to avoid a renewed COVID-19 outbreak.
targetString: Gomnati lardǝ Chinabeye kasuwwa-a cidaramma-a so dǝ kǝntagǝ Marchye kawunzǝ 30 walta furumza sǝ yita ndǝlamzǝgǝna, kuru jero bana kungǝnabe so cidaram so ro cina. Majalis kǝriyebe dǝ ye kau fal karǝgǝ kuttabe warmazǝna shi doni minti yakkǝ mana so baye lardǝbe lan sa 10:00 lan baditǝna ma kau kǝn 4 kǝntagǝ Aprilye lan, adǝye kǝlele Qingmingbe'a yimnza fal ro wallono, gomnati kura dǝye yalla so ro tajinza intanet men sadǝ gulzǝna yaye, adǝye kam soye kamanza so ro cintuza wande fǝlangtǝ COVID-19ye bǝlin wakazǝnyi nanka ro.

sourceString: COVID-19 was confirmed to have spread to South Korea on 20 January 2020 from China.
targetString: COVID-19dǝ lardǝ South Koreabe ro kǝntagǝ Januaryye kaunzǝ 20 saa 2020be'a lan artǝgǝ lewyono ro tawattǝgǝna.

sourceString: The nation's health agency reported a significant increase in confirmed cases on 20 February, largely attributed to a gathering in Daegu of a new religious movement known as the Shincheonji Church of Jesus.
targetString: Cidaram nǝlewabe lardǝ dǝye ye kǝntagǝ Februarybe kaunzǝ 20'a lan rifot ngǝwutǝ kessa tawattǝgǝna sǝdǝna, adǝye samno laa adin bǝlinye shiro Shincheonji Church of Jesus sayin do Daegu lan tǝdǝna dǝ ro kǝrratǝgǝ.

sourceString: Shincheonji devotees visiting Daegu from Wuhan were suspected to be the origin of the outbreak.
targetString: Am adin Shincheonji zasa'ain do Wuhan lan Daegu ro isana dǝ sandima badiyaram fǝlangtǝ dǝye ro zantǝna.

sourceString: As of 22 February, among 9,336 followers of the church, 1,261 or about 13% reported symptoms.South Korea declared the highest level of alert on 23 February 2020.
targetString: Kǝntagǝ Februarybe kaunzǝ 22be lan, suro am coci dǝ zasa'ain 9,336be lan am 1,261 au ci 13% yedei rifot alamawa kwasa dǝye sadǝ. Lardǝ South Koreabe ye kǝntagǝ Februarybe kaunzǝ 22 hangal gǝnatǝ shiyeyi ba ma kokkono.

sourceString: On 28 February, more than 2,000 confirmed cases were reported in Korea, rising to 3,150 on 29 February.
targetString: Kǝntagǝ Februarybe kaunzǝ 28 na, kessa 2000 ma kozǝna tawattǝgǝ, adǝye 3,150 ro juwa wazǝnanzǝ'a au kǝntagǝ Februarybe kaunzǝ 29'a.

sourceString: All South Korean military bases were quarantined after tests confirmed that three soldiers were positive for the virus.
targetString: Na'a askǝrrabe South Koreabe samma so dǝritǝ kǝltǝna au "quarantine" ro tǝkkǝna ngawo tes tǝdǝnaye askǝrra yakkǝ tiyinzan kuli kwasabe dǝ mbeji ro tawatsǝgǝna yen.

sourceString: Airline schedules were also affected and therefore they were changed.South Korea introduced what was considered the largest and best-organized programme in the world to screen the population for the virus, and isolate any infected people as well as tracing and quarantining those who contacted them.
targetString: Loktuwa citǝ maarabe soye letǝna kuru sau adǝye ro falzana. South Koreaye faraskǝram doni dunya lan nǝm kura-a nǝm ngalwo lan shi yeyi ba ma yita gatsǝgǝna nǝm ngǝwu kuli kwasabe dǝ kulas nǝm notǝ ro, kuru am kwasa dǝ tiyinzan mbeji dǝ ruwunza ro tulo-a kuru am sandiye letaanaye shiti ro tulo-a.
